urn:contentItem:5RYY-BND1-JBHT-D032-00000-00Global Markets Rolled by Trade War Fears; Trump's China Tariffs; Congress Approves $1.3 Trillion Bill; New York Firefighter Killed; United Passenger Gets $10,000 Travel Voucher; Heavy Rain Southern California Could Trigger Mudslides; House Panel Subpoenas DOJ; Kansas State Beats Kentucky; Hornets Make History; Eric Reid Says He Will Stop Anthem Protests2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal Markets Rolled by Trade War Fears; Trump's China Tariffs; Congress Approves $1.3 Trillion Bill; New York Firefighter Killed; United Passenger Gets $10,000 Travel Voucher; Heavy Rain Southern California Could Trigger Mudslides; House Panel Subpoenas DOJ; Kansas State Beats Kentucky; Hornets Make History; Eric Reid Says He Will Stop Anthem ProtestsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hang Seng in Hong Kong down 2.5 percent and the KOSPI in Korea down better than three percent. European indices look like it's sharply lower. FT-100, down a one percent. CAC Quarante down almost two percent and the DAX Index down better than two percent.

We have a deal, lawmakers avoided a government shutdown passing a massive $1.3 trillion spending bill early this morning. We are breaking down those numbers as it heads to the President's desk now. McMaster is out, Bolton is in, more changes coming to the White House as President Trump announces he will replace National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster to former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, John Bolton.

Not the only the change, the details as the President's top lawyer in the Russia probe resigns.

And tragedy in New York City to report, a firefighter killed after a fire breaks out on the set of an Edward Norton movie in Harlem, more on the devastating fire alarm blaze coming up.

And then a bump to the bank account, United Airlines delivering a massive cheque to give one passenger to give up her seat, the first-class pay day, coming up.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX News Business Network, Dagen McDowell. The King's College Business and Economic, Professor Brian Brenberg and Kadina Groups President, Gary B. Smith is here. Good to see you, Gary.

GARY B. SMITH, PRESIDENT, KADINA GROUPS: Nice to be here.

BARTIROMO: On a day that we are expecting this market to completely roll over. Good morning Brian and Dagen.

BRIAN BRENBERG, BUSINESS AND ECONOMIC PROFESSOR, THE KING'S COLLEGE: Good morning, good to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: My last thought yesterday at the end of this program was markets look out below.

BARTIROMO: That's right. That's what she said. That was your final comment.

MCDOWELL: Yes, it was. Because, again, it's not just the beginnings of a trade war with China. It is not the upset, but it's the fact that you have Congress passing the spending bill, we're running up deficits, we're running up our national debt, which gives us less power to fight.

SMITH: You sound so bearish, Dagen. Are you thinking the market's going down?

MCDOWELL: Did yesterday.

BARTIROMO: So, the cost of our debt is going up.

MCDOWELL: You've got the Fed -- the Fed raising rates, reducing its balance sheet, you have a Congress that has no understanding of fiscal responsibility at the same time we try to take on China, the largest owner, foreign owner of our national debt, doesn't add up.

SMITH: And yet, I will tell you one thing, I am optimistic.

MCDOWELL: Get down or up.

BARTIROMO: On the back cracking on the economy, what are you most bullish on?

SMITH: Bullish on -- bullish on the market, not right now, not today.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SMITH: Bullish on the economy, I'm bullish, I think Trump is basically getting it right and we we're going to talk more about this whole tariffs thing. I think, I am optimistic right now.

BRENBERG: Well it's certainly not unexpected, right? And he'd been talking about this, and talking at this maybe came later than people thought at but it was going to come.

SMITH: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And the uncertainty to all of this, the trade story is exactly what people were worried about going into the election. Remember when the market was down 700 points on election night it was because of uncertainty around NAFTA, what will Donald Trump do. And this is what we're seeing right here. Coming up this morning joining the conversation, Florida Congressman and House Freedom Caucus Member, Ron DeSantis is with us.

Remember the (INAUDIBLE) -- Caucus was among the first to say, we're not in on this bill, former FDIC Chairman and founder a Systemic Risk Council, Sheila Bair is with us this morning. Then the author of The Coming Collapse Of China, Gordon Chang will weigh in along with the CEO of Deloitte Cathy Engelbert is here. Plus elevation partner, cofounder, managing director and investor and Mark Zuckerberg's mentor, Roger McNamee, one of the leader shareholders in Facebook for some time. We're going to talk with Roger about what took place on Facebook and this market this week.

But first, we want to kick it off right now, with the trade war hitting global markets, stocks across Asia tumbled, following directions from Wall Street. Take a look at the numbers here, of course we know that all the majors in Asia were down between three and 4.5 percent. Japan being the worst down 4.5 percent.

Back in the U.S., the Dow closed down more than 700 points yesterday after President Trump proposed tariffs of up to $60 billion on imports from China along with tighter restrictions on the country's acquisition and technology transfers, It was in response to what the administration is calling China's unfair trading practices.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're doing things for this country that should've been done for many, many years. We've had this abuse by many other countries and groups of countries that were put together in order to take advantage of the United States and we don't want that to happen. We're not going to let that happen. I t's probably one of the reasons I was elected, maybe one of the main reasons.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Hours later the Chinese government fired back saying that it plans to roll out its own retaliatory tariffs of up to $3 billion on U.S. goods in response to the tariffs on steel and aluminum which go into effect today. The U.S. now says some allies including Canada, Mexico and the E.U. among others will get a brief exemption from the tariffs. Joining us right now to talk more about that is Congresswoman Claudia Tenney of New York, a former small business owner, congresswoman good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us. And I know you're back on a lot to talk about small business and about lending money get into that. But first, let's talk about these tariffs, good idea or are you against?

REP. CLAUDIA TENNEY (R), NEW YORK: I tend to be more on Gary's side. Gary B's got the idea. I think, the terms on to something, I did a Pentagon article last year 2016 about the problem we have with China. That was the tariffs hacking, what's happening overall in terms of currency. All this things affects small businesses. I'm a small business owner in upstate New York. And put together with the -- all the things that China's doing, I mean, we're trying to move in a direction that we're kind of correct, trying to correct this, I think, that's what you're seeing in the market, I hoping that's a correction, I hope Dagen's dire prediction here is not true.

BARTIROMO: What do you say about the fact that China is coming back now and saying, really, we're going to tariff you? And so now we are looking at a serious retaliatory story.

TENNEY: Yes, I think it's stupid, I mean, Kim Jong-un also reacted to President Trump, to some strong language. But think about what's happening here tough, China actually has the biggest marketplace in the world that you want to have access to, and that's the United States. We are where the consumers are and so, they want to get access to us too. So, that's something that they've got to weigh in to the negotiation. They're business model I think is flawed in the end. We know that they've set up these state-run businesses that -- and that's how they operate. I mean, much like what's done in New York State under our current governor, but we know that that kind of cronie is in that kind of set up of state-run businesses in the long run doesn't work which is why I tend to favor that we've got to do something now, how long are we going wait? How long are we going to let China cheat? How long are we going, you know, steeling our intellectual property from our steel companies and others and I think that's what Wilbur Ross and the President are recognizing and something has to be done and maybe this is a very short-term pain that may end up being, you know, long-term gain for us.

BRENBERG: What about the uncertainty this creates for small businesses? You are small business owners, you understand they're trying to make plans, now they're saying, you know, which of this 1300 products is going to be hit by a tariff, how big is the tariff? That's very hard for a small shop to deal with, is that a big concern here or do you think that's very, very temporary?

BARTIROMO: Prices will go up.

TENNEY: Right, it is a concern especially for the smaller businesses. We have some of the small business in area. We have a company called share manufacturing which took over the older night limited which went under and went to Asia where there's manufacturing, they're dependent on purchasing steel as well, but I also have another number of companies in my district that also are steel companies and they like to see a little bit of help. And, they're use to buy older steel from American based companies and now they're buying it from overseas. I do think we need -- we're going to see an adjustment in the market, but I think making tariffs in more targeted way, using currency, looking at the tax reform is something that's going to be helpful to us in the long run, especially, this past through businesses. In my region which is the order of the day, we do know they produce most of the jobs. This is the only way you're going to bring the Rust Belt back, I lived in the Rust Belt of New York.

SMITH: Well Congresswoman you bring up a very interesting point and I think some people ignore it. We're a China's biggest buyer --

TENNEY: Absolutely.

SMITH: -- by almost 4-1. How can you have a trade war, an active trade war with your biggest buyer?

BARTIROMO: And they already have a $375 billion surplus on us. Where are the 375 billion deficit? So, are they going to threaten that huge surplus with these tariffs?

SMITH: It'd be like 3M selling tape to Wal-Mart, having a trade war with Wal-Mart. You know, they buy a lot more tape than Wal-Mart buys from 3M, so it would be silly, wouldn't it?

TENNEY: I agree with you. It's -- we are the market place. Where are they going to sell goods and services, they create this enormous state- owned businesses, this big plants and companies, fancy new equipment. And then they say, come in and we'll run these for you. Remember, people that move to China, they don't own their businesses, they're owned by the state. And so people have to recognize that this isn't a situation where you have, you know, you have this actual free market going on. You have government run the industries against a supposed free market enter the United States that we something we're trying to get back.

BARTIROMO: All true but they are still out this morning saying that they're going to put this retaliatory tariffs in place. Look, we've got to talk about this $1.3 trillion spending bill, congresswoman. You averted a shutdown and of course, looking to a $1.3 trillion spending package, deliver to the President's steps now. It includes defense as well as domestic spending, the measure is headed to the President's desk for signature but a lot of pushback here, you voted yes.

TENNEY: I did and it was a very hard vote. I'm a fiscal conservative. I hate the fact that we're spending, I don't like the fact that we're dependent in all of this deafen deficit. We tried to get this done through our American Health Care Act. Remember, we had significant reforms to the mandatory spending side. We didn't get that done. We got a thumbs down vote from one person in the Senate, that prevented us from getting to that mandatory spending side, which is so large with the eclipse is what we do in the discretionary side. But that being said, we have a short-term fix, it's ugly, they called it the big ugly when I was in New York States, somebody when a woman I would call it the big ugly now.

BARTIROMO: Why can't you just say no -- why can't you just say no to the Democrats that want all the spending?

TENNEY: To be honest, I would love to say no, the President actually supported this. My biggest concern and my son is an active duty Marine Officer who's -- who has indicated to me and we have met with General Mattis and numerous people on that side, we have seriously degraded our military over the years.

BARTIROMO: Agreed.

TENNEY: And that is being held as a big club to us and when you see more of our good servicemen and women are hardworking, honourably serving people, die in training than in combat. There is a problem with what we're doing in our military side and General Mattis has said, the only thing more dangerous than our most dangerous enemies is Congress. And we need to act and we needed to do something with our military. Sadly it came at a price.

MCDOWELL: 80 billion in defense spending increase above the 2011 sequester levels, 63 billion increase in domestic spending, the issue is because now Congress, Republicans and Democrats have signed off on higher spending levels, we now get into the trillion dollar annual budget deficits. What that ultimately will do given the $21 trillion that we have in debt already. We're going to be spending more on interest on our debt in less than a decade in just a matter of years than we spend on our military. So, this might be a short-term fix for the spending in our military and those who are serving this country. However, we put that very spending and put our safety in jeopardy because we can't rein in our spending. That is the catch --

TENNEY: But I think we can reign on our spending. Let me -- let me -- let me understand, we do not have 51 reliable votes in the Senate. OK, we don't -- forget 60, we don't have 51 reliable votes. We proved that in our attempt to pass the American Health Care act through reconciliation. A lot of this things --

BARTIROMO: Right and you got a big this --

TENNEY: Right, a lot of the things we could fix, we could do on regulate order if we had enough votes, even a simple majority I would advocate to the Senate to go back to the simple majority. We don't have 51 reliable votes and think about this, in my district alone, we once had an Air Force base that was closed. We now have one of the most significant assets, that's called Roam Labs, this asset is producing cutting-edge technology for the future of our military conflicts. Will create efficiencies, will make us able to be deal with the ace of symmetrical enemies that we face now. So, it's really important that some of things happened.

They also produced a lot of jobs in my region which have been lost. I have some of the largest at migration in the state of New York in the country. And so, these are companies that are, you know, companies that are also part of the former Air Force base, companies that are dependent, that our military has depended on for many of our technologies. So advocated for those for me to turn around and say, I'm advocating for these in appropriation side, and to say, by the way, I'm not going to vote for it because I don't like what happened on the domestic side because we had to meet the needs of what? The Democrats.

MCDOWELL: The irony is though, the Republicans are now at even greater risk of losing the majority in the House and the Senate because of the tariffs and the retaliation from China. If you look at hawk-producing states and soy bean producers, those dairy farmers because of the retaliation by China and the U.S. actions are going to get smacked on the face and those are the very areas of this country that Trump won. These are the states like Iowa that sent him over the top in terms of Electoral College.

TENNEY: There were technical corrections though in the appropriation process in some of this issues that were in the tax bill that would help us some of the trade and somebody issues in there. We still need to revisit NAFTA, we still need to revisit all this trade deals and even I think I knew on unilateral basis. I don't think -- Trump what he say, (INAUDIBLE) the word of the day reciprocal trade now, we've gone from free fair to reciprocal.

BARTIROMO: Well, China's calling it retaliatory. Real quick on John Bolton, H.R. out, Bolton in, your thoughts.

TENNEY: Yes, you know, I like John Bolton, I think it's -- I just think it's interesting that the President's choices and let's see how that works out but I think John is very strong person, I think he's going to be an interesting to see the strong personalities in the White House. Although we've had a number of them in the past, we'll see where they end up.

BARTIROMO: Thanks, Claudia, thanks very much, great to see you.

TENNEY: Thank you, great to see you too.

BARTIROMO: Practical approach from Claudia Tenney joining us there. Breaking news right now, the President is tweeting this morning, here's what he says: House Intelligence Committee voting to release final report, the finding: One: no evidence provided of collusion between Trump campaign and Russia, number two: the Obama administrations post-election response was insufficient and three: Clapper, inconsistent, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Well, it's going to be another tough day at the office as we've been saying. Look at the Dow Industrials down 150 points right now, on top of the 700 plus selloff yesterday. We are watching markets this morning, NASDAQ down 60.

Meanwhile a tragic night in New York, a city firefighter killed in a raging five-alarm fire in a Harlem film set. Lauren Simonetti, with the details and headlines. Lauren, good morning to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, fatal fire, Maria. Flames broke out last night in a, you know, in a movie set in the basement of closed club, firefighter Michael Davidson, Engine Company first to arrive, rushed to the basement of the club but officials say once they got down there, the fire was too strong, it forced them to retreat, Davidson somehow got separated from the other firefighters and when they found him, he was unconscious and could not be revived. He's 37 year's old and leaves behind his wife and four young children.

Well, liquidation sales at Toys "R" Us they are set to start today, the company apologizing for what it calls unforeseen circumstances. They were expected to begin yesterday, push back to today. Toys "R" Us it's lasting prices as it prepares to close about 800 U.S. stores. And a sad note, Toys "R" Us founder, Charles Lazarus died yesterday, he was 94 year's old.

And this, a woman bumped from a United Airlines flight gets a $10,000 travel voucher. This after she launched a pretty angry Tweet storm after the airline oversold the flight and asked her specifically to get off the plane because she paid the least for her ticket out of everyone else on board. One of her Tweets said, United tried to get me to sign a document that says I volunteered my seat on this plane when I was involuntarily denied boarding. But now she says after that voucher, it was the best place ever. $10,000, you can go to a lot of places.

BARTIROMO: I guess yes, thank you Lauren. Coming up thousands of students from across the country will march in Washington against gun violence in the wake of the Parkland massacre. One of the shooting survivors will tell us why he's not attending.

And then a bright spot amid the rough week, the technology stocks as Dropbox debuts on the Nasdaq with a higher than expected share price. We'll see what happens to the stock at the opening in a down market, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, investors' concerns over possible trade war rocking Wall Street today and yesterday Futures currently indicating a decline at the start of trading of 160 points. That's two-thirds of one percent. Nasdaq and S&P 500 also down one percent and 1/2 of a percent. It's coming after its sharp selloff yesterday, the Dow was down better than 700 points yesterday. It was the biggest one-day percentage decline since early February. Joining us right now to weigh in, is a Chief Investor Strategist for CFRA research, Sam Stovall. Sam, good to see you. Thanks for joining us.

SAM STOVALL, CHIEF INVESTOR STRATEGIST, CFRA: Well, happy to be here.

BARTIROMO: Well, you're talking about a backdrop which is pretty positive. How do you see these markets here?

STOVALL: Well, this is the correction that people that have been talking about. And actually, I believe it's more of the retest of the correction that had bottomed in February 8th. Maybe we go and we touch the rising 200 day moving average which is around 25-85, so there's probably further downside to go but at the same time, I remind investors that we're down less than eight percent from the January 26 high, and so, therefore, the numbers look large but on a percentage basis, it's actually a run of the mill kind of decline.

BARTIROMO: So, you're not as worried. Gary B., you just said the same thing? (INAUDIBLE) optimistic.

SMITH: I'm optimistic, here's the only, not the only, maybe one of the flies (INAUDIBLE) the fang stocks that pretty much been leading, carrying the market on their shoulders. We've seen a little bit of, you know, correction --

BARTIROMO: Or a lot, 10 percent down on Facebook. Facebook down 10 percent --

SMITH: What are the future -- yes, what's the future of those stocks, do you think?

STOVALL: Well, I still think that the future looks pretty good. We actually are technology set to group heads, Scott Kessler upgraded Facebook to a strong buy, feeling that this is being overdone and that there is more opportunity there. If you look to those groups that are trading above their ten week, 50 day moving averages, still, you do have the internet stocks above that moving average, so Netflix looking at Amazon are still doing relatively well.

SMITH: What's the next -- I think, everyone wants to know, what's the next fang stock? We got those, what's going to be the next one? That's what we want to buy, right?

BARTIROMO: The CISCO's of the world are not trading the way Facebook is in terms of valuation, I'm just saying, it's a --

STOVALL: Exactly. And also the semiconductor, semiconductor equipment, application software, those groups are trading above their 50 day --

SMITH: No, no, what I want to know, I want to know what is going to be, we're going to look five years from now, I wish I had bought that stock. You can't say Amazon or Netflix.

STOVALL: Well, thanks for the opportunity to do this research ahead of time. (CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: We all want that answer. On the near term, you're expecting for the decline, for longer term you sound like you're still pretty bullish on this market?

STOVALL: Yes, I do. I don't think Trump wants to go down as the next Republican President to initiate a recession even though every single one since Teddy Roosevelt had one occur in the first two years in office.

BARTIROMO: Right.

STOVALL: So, I don't think he wants to continue that tradition.

BRENBERG: So, does the trade spat here and quickly?

STOVALL: I think that similar to what we have seen with the tariffs on aluminum and steel that were broad base to begin with, now we have special exemptions for our favorable trading partners. I think, that this still looks like it's more of a negotiation ploy that could then be softened as we move forward.

MCDOWELL: By coming from a businessman that's a wrench in to people who do business in this country through used steel and aluminum. Because they're sitting around the last several weeks. So, how much is my steel going to cost? I source it from these countries, are they going to be exempt, calling people on the phone, going, can you give us some clarity on this and it's still not that clear.

STOVALL: Well, you're going to see a real-life example in a couple of minutes because I was chatting with your next guest in the green room and he has challenges because of that.

BARTIROMO: Well, thank you for that tease. We really appreciate that.

STOVALL: No charge.

BARTIROMO: And coming up, Sir Sam Stovall, good to see you. Thank you so much, what a week it's been. We've had a great show here following all the ups and downs out of Washington, take a look at some of the top moments from this program.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Do you worry that any of this growth story which obviously is a big reason coming from the tax plan is going to get impacted by this tariffs?

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R), CALIFORNIA: Yes, we are growing, we don't want to harm or slow it down but I also think, we have to stand up to China what they've been doing. As the President stands up to China, China realizes they've done something wrong and now they're finally standing up to North Korea, they realize, there's a new sheriff in town and the world's going to be a little different in this administration.

PETER NAVARRO, WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL TRADE COUNCIL DIRECTOR: All we want is to defend ourselves against economic aggression and I see this as bullish for corporate America. China is doing a lot better with this trade relationship than we are. I don't see them wanting to jeopardize that. They know -- they know what they've been doing and taking from us and actually they're probably surprised that finally a President is willing to stand up for the American people and for American companies.

SEN. ORRIN HATCH (R), UTAH: I don't agree with Mr. Navarro. I don't think that he's living in the real world. This other countries are not going to put up with it. It's -- I think it's ridiculous between you and me. I expect to push back from China. I don't think there's any question about that. But the question is, are we in a position economically to really fight them?

HERMAN CAIN, TALK RADIO HOST: Everybody take a chill pill. This is how you get the Chinese to the table. When you impose a tariff which I agree with others on your panel, it is a tax, this is how you get them to the table, this is how you have serious talks about levelling the playing field.

BARTIROMO: I want to read you, Governor, MiKE Huckabee's tweet. He (INAUDIBLE), I will be on @MariaBartiromo and will let loose on GOP for collapsing and surrendering to Pelosi and Schumer on a disgusting spending bill.

REP. STEVE WOMACK (R), ARKANSAS: Look, Mike Huckabee is a great friend of mine. And that's easy to say from the outside looking in but as I said before, I believe strongly that we have a mandate to provide for the security of this country and in order to be able to get the gains that we did for the Pentagon and for national -- the national security apparatus, there were concessions that had to be made.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I love it. He's a great Congressman, but I'm going to just say this, tell the Democrats we're going to fund the military but we're not going to fund some of your pet projects and you can either be the ones that keep us from having a strong military or you can join us, and if you think that we are wrong, then you go get elected to the majorities. These guys are got to start learning to play some hardball.

MCDOWELL: I think the biggest headline is, now we know at least one person who is not going to be running for the presidency ever, Mark Zuckerberg.

BARTIROMO: We know that these companies have more power than they ever had and more information about Americans than they ever had.

REP. CHRIS COLLINS (R), NEW YORK: We'll be holding hearings, there's no two ways about it. But the irony here is a lot of Americans are OK with what we would call this edge providers, whether it's Google or Facebook or Amazon knowing something about you so they can give you recommendations. A lot of Americans are fine with that and a lot are not. The problem is right now, is in many cases no one's asking your permission.

BARTIROMO: And you say you wish you really would have known the importance of having a budget.

CHRIS HOGAN, FINANCIAL EXPERT: The importance of having a budget is just being in control. You telling your money where to go instead of wondering where it went.

MCDOWELL: Here's what I learn in my 20's, for your first marriage go to the Courthouse and tell people send you cheques.

BARTIROMO: Forget all the China thing, you said you love and you think you're going to use it. You're not going to use the China.

HOGAN: Maria, what we need to do is all get together and collaborate and make a book for these new millennials out there to help them to avoid some of this traps.

BARTIROMO: The best thing about Washington, now, Marlon Bundo is making big literary debut.

KAREN PENCE, SECOND LADY OF THE UNITED STATES: This is my first book to illustrate and we've had lot of fun.

BARTIROMO: You must have fun just working together.

PENCE: We really do. And Marlon is great, he really -- he poses, he knows, he thinks as, you know, this is my best side.

BARTIROMO: How funny and adorable.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Friday. It is Friday, March 23rd; your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Stocks battered on Wall Street and the selling continues this morning, the major indices selling off over growing fears of a trade war, President Trump, signing his tariffs against China, yesterday, and that triggering even more selling.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have a trade deficit depending on the way you calculate of $504 billion. Now, some people would say it's really $375 billion. But any way you look at it, it is the largest deficit of any country in the history of our world. It's out of control.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: China is firing back this morning. It is announcing its own tariffs on U.S. goods going into China. Global markets are following the U.S. lower. Take a look at the selloffs underway right now. The FT-100, down three quarters of one percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down one and two-thirds percent, also one and two-thirds lower, on the DAX Index in Germany. In Asia overnight, sharp declines across-the-board, the Nikkei Average, the worst performer, down 4-1/2 percent in Japan.

Shanghai and Korea, both down better than three percent. Looking ahead to the open, more selling, Futures are indicating a lower opening. Now, this is off of the lows of the morning. Nonetheless, we're expecting a decline at the start of trading of 122 points, that's one half of one percent. The S&P is down nine points and the NASDAQ is down 56, that's almost one percent. Then there's this, the House Judiciary Committee, making it official.

It issued a subpoena to the Justice Department for documents in the Clinton e-mail investigation, as we told you, it would. New questions in the Uber self-driving car accident, the focus, now, turning to the test driver and how the company selects those drivers, the woman behind the wheel was a convicted felon. One NFL player walking back his anthem protest, why he helps the move, will have teams picking up the phone. And Sister Jean and Loyola Chicago, living on a prayer, and some great play on the court, with the latest from Sweet 16, where Michigan dominated again.

All that coming up, but first, students set to hold a march for our lives rally in Washington D.C., another cities across the country, tomorrow, as they push for stricter gun laws in the wake of the recent school shooting. Joining us now is the -- a survivor of the Parkland School shooting, Marjory Stoneman Douglas junior, Kyle Kashuv. Kyle, good to see you, thanks very much for joining us again.

KYLE KASHUV, JUNIOR, MARJORY STONEMAN DOUGLAS: Thank you for having me on.

BARTIROMO: You will not be attending that march, why not?

KASHUV: I'm going to be too busy meeting with legislators and pushing for actual change.

BARTIROMO: OK, do you not see it as important to be -- to be there with your classmates and others?

KASHUV: One thing, it's definitely amazing that they can march but if -- I mean, I'm taking the fast track that's actually pushing a change, because I really don't want to see Parkland ever happen again. And, I could march, but I think my time would be much better well spent meeting with legislators.

BARTIROMO: Good for you.

BRENBERG: Kyle, how did your classmates respond to this? I mean, you're spending some time with them but you're not doing a lot of the important things that they are doing. Are they pushing back hard against this? Did they welcome the fact that you're taking an alternative view point? How do you respond?

BARTIROMO: I mean, there he is in the White House with the President and the First Lady. This is what he's doing.

BRENBERG: It's amazing. I'm just curious how they respond to that.

KASHUV: Well, a lot of them view what they're doing as more productive and effective than meeting with legislators to (INAUDIBLE) I think that meeting, first hand, with legislators and trying to explain to them your point of view and to explain to them what's necessary and what needs to be done, is more important than walking down on Washington D.C., and which is fine, even if from point of opinion. But I truly believe that if you want change, you go to legislators.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Kyle, quick question, what percentage of your classmates are actually marching?

KASHUV: I don't know the percentage, but I would give you most likely, 90 plus percent of all my peers will be marching whether in Parkland or Washington D.C.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So, you got a large percentage of your classmates, marching. Do you think there's certainly -- I mean, I remember my days from high school, you think most of these are really just viewing the marches up, just the way to goof off or do you think they're really serious?

KASHUV: I mean, I think there are definitely some people who are coming seriously, but a lot of people saw that -- that you could get a free 40- trip to Washington D.C.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Exactly.

KASHUV: then why not.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let me ask you because we see this Time Magazine covers. Several of your classmates are on the latest cover of Time, titled Enough. You were not in this picture, on the cover of Time Magazine. Did they ask you to be on the shot?

KASHUV: Well, they didn't ask me. But honestly, I didn't know Time Magazine was still a thing. I know I wasn't asked. No.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think that is?

KASHUV: I don't -- maybe -- I think maybe they're trying to represent only one point of view, the Democrat point of view and the anti-gun -- the anti- gun. A movement -- I honestly couldn't tell you because if they are really trying to get the full perspective they would ask me and especially Patrick Patty.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'm wondering if you are in fact, seeing pushback because you take a different view, a more conservative view on this topic. I know that you had a recent incident with Spirit Airlines. You tweeted about it. We're going to show you tweet right here, Kyle. You say, just landed in Baltimore on Spirit Airlines and the steward is felt compelled to give us all a speech about the March for Our Lives, which openly says on the petition, are trying to categorically ban AR-15s and made everyone clap.

Can anything just be non-political anymore? Spirit tweeted an apology after your tweet. And Spirit Airlines said, while we appreciate that one team members -- our Team Members are individuals, we don't believe politics should be part of the Guest experience. We're looking into the incident. We apologize to any guests offended by these comments. Is this apology enough for you, Kyle?

KASHUV: I mean, I want -- I wasn't offended to begin with. I just thought that what they're doing was stupid and unnecessary that they're giving a speech for all the passengers, how much they support the March. I just thought it was unnecessary.

BARTIROMO: But go back and talk to us about your views here, because this is the whole crocs of the story. I mean, the fact that you've taken a different position, you're not looking for, you know, specific, you know, an impact on the second amendment. You say that there are rules in place that should've been followed and there were missed signals. Where are you on this? Tell us why you think you're seeing some pushback against your views?

KASHUV: Well, I think, I'm definitely getting some pushbacks because I'm not taking, like, the mass majority opinion on this, so just everyone's just following each other, inspiringly in a loop of talking points. I mean, I've taken a step back and I've looked at all the facts and I have come to the conclusion that what I think I'm doing right now is what needs to be done versus just marching and screaming about gun control.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: Kyle, it's Dagen McDowell, have you met with both Democrat and Republican law makers?

KASHUV: Yes, across the board.

MCDOWELL: And where do you see consensus among them in terms of tightening gun regulations, we have gun regulations in this country or where do you think that they can all come together and do something again? FixNix was kind of easy, closing some of the loopholes or trying to tighten up the background check database.

KASHUV: Well, I think first hand, every legislator I talk to, across the board, they truly care and they don't want to see this happen -- they really do --they don't want to see this ever happen to any of the constituents, ever again. What I think that every single lawmaker agreed on, was that they want to see that people who are mentally disturbed, can acquire weapon., and they want to make sure there are background check systems is actually being implemented, and all the information is going through. They want to see the clear reporting and the full reporting of information of disturbed individuals.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, there are some changes happening to your school right now, in terms of security. Let's talk about that for a second, Kyle.

KASHUV: Yes.

BARTIROMO: The superintendent says that students are now going to be required to use clear backpacks and metal detectors may be installed. Do you agree with these moves? What about this clear backpack?

KASHUV: I mean, I honestly think that it's going to protect our schools and if this is what determined that it's absolutely necessary to make sure this won't happen again, then, we shouldn't be opposed to -- we should be in favor of it. Yes, it'll be a little bit of discomfort, but look, that's the price you pay for going to school safely. I mean, I would prefer that I could come to school safely, not have to fear if that man having a clear backpack.

BARTIROMO: OK. And the metal detectors you're also comfortable with. I mean, you have said in the past that what's wrong having an armed guard at the school, right?

KASHUV: Yes, I mean, let's do everything possible to make sure that school is safe. Yes, it might cause some discomfort for some kids. We don't have to wait a few minutes to get to the metal detectors, hopefully not three hours, but that's what it is.

BARTIROMO: Kyle, thanks so much for weighing in this morning. Good to see you again.

KASHUV: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kyle Kashuv, joining us there. Coming up, getting answers, House Judiciary Committee officially subpoenas the justice department over the Hillary Clinton e-mail server probe. We knew it was coming. We've got more on in this morning, and then another night at bracket-buster, as March madness rolls toward the elite eight, the upsets and the triumphs, coming up, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right. Markets are off of their lows, as you just saw them. Meanwhile, heavy rains in Southern California have residents on alert this morning for possible flash flooding, mudslides. Lauren Simonetti with all the details and headlines now, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Hi, Maria, this threat is just two months after deadly mudslides struck killing 21 people. Rainfall rate this time around could be as high as an inch per hour and Santa Barbara County's 30,000 people told to evacuate.

We're also learning more about Sunday's fatal crash in Arizona, involving a self-driving Uber vehicle. According to Arizona state records, and we've shown you this video, it is disturbing to watch. The safety driver right there, Rafael Vasquez, 44-years-old, was a convicted felon for attempted armed robbery along with the number of traffic violations. A police video shows him looking down, as you can see right before the car struck and killed a female pedestrian. Uber says, Vasquez met standard background check requirements and that he does still work for the company.

Well, the House Judiciary Committee is slapping the Justice Department with a subpoena for documents related to the Clinton e-mail server investigation. Chairman Bob Goodlatte saying he had no choice since they have only received a fraction of the roughly 1.2 million documents that they requested months ago. Goodlatte spoke about this on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", Maria.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BOB GOODLATTE (R-VA), CHAIRMAN OF THE HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: We need to have those documents. The department and the bureau have been slow. I would say, now, very slow in getting them to us. The last time I was on your program I expressed confidence that we would have those documents forthcoming, and here we are several weeks later, still don't have them. So, this is coming to a hit.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Here we are. The Justice Department has two weeks to comply with this subpoena.

Well, it's the day for an IPO. The cloud storage company, Dropbox, bumping the price of its shares in its initial public offering to $21.00, that's the second hike for Dropbox. They had previously set a range of $16.00- $18.00 a pop. The bump up shows strong demand among the investors. Shares start trading today on the NASDAQ, the symbol is DBX, the company is valued at over $8 billion. So, we're talking about the big tech company struggling lately. How are the unicorns going to do?

BARTIROMO: Well, we'll see how the deal does today even in the face of a down market. Lauren, thank you so much. Dropbox -- I want to get your take on that later. Dagen, this subpoena, we knew this was coming. Bob Goodlatte told me on Sunday that it was coming. I find it extraordinary that they can request 1.2 million documents and only get 3000 back. How is it possible that the FBI just blows off the committee that has jurisdiction over it?

MCDOWELL: And I think some of the blame needs to be directed at Attorney General Jeff Sessions, that I think that it's the entrenched old-school lifelong government workers who are part of the problem here. But again, who's running the FBI? Jeff Sessions, I know, he's recused himself in any matters dealing with Russia, but what about Rod Rosenstein?

BARTIROMO: Well, you're right. I mean, somebody has got to enforce this.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And they've only received 3000 of the documents.

BRENBERG: The numbers look so ludicrous. I mean, 3000 over -- it looks like, forget about it, just told defiance. I think Americans feel like, there's a million document, let's give a big chunk of those and see what's there.

BARTIROMO: And by the way, don't forget when our friend, Jason Chaffetz, was running the Oversight Committee and he went into a hearing and said, you are officially served. He handed the subpoena to the FBI, months before this subpoena, and they still didn't comply. So, I don't know, but you're right, it's up to Jeff Sessions. Somebody has to enforce this to get those documents within this investigation.

MCDOWELL: I'm still -- I'm (INAUDIBLE) awaiting the inspector general's report, particularly. It's only been -- it's been less than a week since Andrew McCabe got fired.

SMITH: You're right about one thing: you're fighting the real backbone, which is the entrenched government employees, which typically lean to the left. And they're certainly as we've seen time and time after again, they're anti-Trump.

MCDOWELL: They only sleep on their left side.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: We're going to have Devin Nunes on.

MCDOWELL: You know, your hair is thin on the one side.

BARTIROMO: Yes, then your arm hurts you. We're going to have Devin Nunes on, on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", Chairman of the Intel Committee, to take more about that. We'll take a quick break right here. NFL Free Agent, Eric Reid, walking away from kneeling. We will tell you why a big supporter of Colin Kaepernick is saying now, what he's saying now about the pregame protest. Plus, the sting of the Hornets -- Charlotte makes NBA history with a massive blowout win. Sports is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right. Here's our -- four games, three upsets in the NCAA March Madness. Jared Max with the highlights, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: March Madness indeed, Maria. Out of 17.3 million brackets in ESPN's tournament challenge, you know how many picked all four that won last night? 349, which is actually somewhat remarkable considering the unlikelihood of these results -- a matchup of Wildcats. Kentucky favored to beat Kansas State, but K-state cats, scratched this tie breaking layup for Barry Brown with 19 seconds left, K- state scores the upset 61-58. One win for the first final four since 1964.

The number nine seeded Wildcats play Saturday in the elite eight? the 11- seated Ramblers from Loyola Chicago. When it's time for leaving, I hope you understand, I was born a rambling man in Rambler. Its town says, it's not time for leaving yet. Loyola Chicago beats Nevada, 69-68. They're in the elite eight for the first time in 55 years since 98-year-old Team Chaplan, Sister Jean. Getting lots of brotherly love from the Ramblers players. So, we're number nine seed one -- a number 11 seed one.

And another number nine, football powerhouse, Florida State knocked out last year's runner-up, Gonzaga. Seminoles win 75 to 60 in the regional finals for the third time. The only game that went as expect, third seed, Michigan, won its 12th straight. The Wolverines eliminated Texas A&M, 99- 72. Michigan plays Florida State four more games tonight, including the only number one seeds left, Kansas and Villanova in action.

Record-setting night in the NBA: Charlotte Hornets became only the sixth team ever to win a game by 60 points or more. Wild night, Dwight Howard, not part of the mix. He served the one-game suspension; didn't matter. As the Hornets did something we haven't seen in 20 years with this type of blowout. Kemba Walker hit 10, three-pointers, a team record. They win by 61 points. Walker at 46 points and only 28 minutes -- nobody had ever scored that many in so few minutes since the shot clock came to date.

Hey, Johnny Manziel, making a comeback, former high spin trophy winner, sober, looking healthy, full-faced, in football shape, attracted scouts from 13 NFL teams yesterday at a pro-day work at San Diego. Unemployed NFL free safety, Eric Reid, one of the original national anthem kneelers with former teammate, Colin Kaepernick, says he's not going to kneel anymore. He says, the message was understood that they didn't kneel to protest the national anthem. Question: when you and your significant other do yoga, do you ever try to re-create the scene in dirty dancing? As Patriots Quarterback, Tom Brady, Gisele Bundchen did. They've had the time of their lives and, Maria, they've never felt this way before.

BARTIROMO: Wow! Look at that.

BRENBERG: I don't want to know that, Jared. I just -- I don't what to know that last piece.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Tom Brady is pretty and tolerable, but somehow he just managed to become even more.

(LAUGHTER)

BRENBERG: Come on! Keep it to yourself.

BARTIROMO: He's doing yoga.

BRENBERG: Keep it to yourself.

SMITH: What you do in privacy of your yoga sessions. Johnny Manziel, you can't keep your eyes off of him. Is he going to sign with them or anything?

MAX: I think so. The 13 scouts there to watch throw. He looks healthy. He looks like he's ready to play football. Because he looks so sick for a while and not doing well.

BRENBERG: I love the comeback stories. I'd love to see it happen.

MAX: We love the comebacks. You know, Tiger Woods, we're all rooting for now.

MCDOWELL: Let's not compare Johnny Manziel to Tiger Woods.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Johnny Manziel has proved that --

MAX: Correct.

MCDOWELL: -- he can't play professional football.

BRENBERG: I want the comeback story here.

MCDOWELL: O wanted Tom Brady to fall on, still.

BARTIROMO: But he did it. They are perfect. You need to understand they're perfect. That's it, Dagen. Jared, thank you. Jared's sports reports Fox News Headlines 24/7 and SiriusXM 115, catch him. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good morning. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks for joining us this Friday. It is Friday, March 23rd, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VR6-S5N1-DY0W-401V-00000-00Global Markets Rolled by Trade War Fears; Trump's China Tariffs; Congress Approves $1.3 Trillion Bill; New York Firefighter Killed; United Passenger Gets $10,000 Travel Voucher; Heavy Rain Southern California Could Trigger Mudslides; House Panel Subpoenas DOJ; Kansas State Beats Kentucky; Hornets Make History; Eric Reid Says He Will Stop Anthem Protests2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal Markets Rolled by Trade War Fears; Trump's China Tariffs; Congress Approves $1.3 Trillion Bill; New York Firefighter Killed; United Passenger Gets $10,000 Travel Voucher; Heavy Rain Southern California Could Trigger Mudslides; House Panel Subpoenas DOJ; Kansas State Beats Kentucky; Hornets Make History; Eric Reid Says He Will Stop Anthem ProtestsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hang Seng in Hong Kong down 2.5 percent and the KOSPI in Korea down better than three percent. European indices look like it's sharply lower. FT-100, down a one percent. CAC Quarante down almost two percent and the DAX Index down better than two percent.

We have a deal, lawmakers avoided a government shutdown passing a massive $1.3 trillion spending bill early this morning. We are breaking down those numbers as it heads to the President's desk now. McMaster is out, Bolton is in, more changes coming to the White House as President Trump announces he will replace National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster to former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, John Bolton.

Not the only the change, the details as the President's top lawyer in the Russia probe resigns.

And tragedy in New York City to report, a firefighter killed after a fire breaks out on the set of an Edward Norton movie in Harlem, more on the devastating fire alarm blaze coming up.

And then a bump to the bank account, United Airlines delivering a massive cheque to give one passenger to give up her seat, the first-class pay day, coming up.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining me to talk all about it, FOX News Business Network, Dagen McDowell. The King's College Business and Economic, Professor Brian Brenberg and Kadina Groups President, Gary B. Smith is here. Good to see you, Gary.

GARY B. SMITH, PRESIDENT, KADINA GROUPS: Nice to be here.

BARTIROMO: On a day that we are expecting this market to completely roll over. Good morning Brian and Dagen.

BRIAN BRENBERG, BUSINESS AND ECONOMIC PROFESSOR, THE KING'S COLLEGE: Good morning, good to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: My last thought yesterday at the end of this program was markets look out below.

BARTIROMO: That's right. That's what she said. That was your final comment.

MCDOWELL: Yes, it was. Because, again, it's not just the beginnings of a trade war with China. It is not the upset, but it's the fact that you have Congress passing the spending bill, we're running up deficits, we're running up our national debt, which gives us less power to fight.

SMITH: You sound so bearish, Dagen. Are you thinking the market's going down?

MCDOWELL: Did yesterday.

BARTIROMO: So, the cost of our debt is going up.

MCDOWELL: You've got the Fed -- the Fed raising rates, reducing its balance sheet, you have a Congress that has no understanding of fiscal responsibility at the same time we try to take on China, the largest owner, foreign owner of our national debt, doesn't add up.

SMITH: And yet, I will tell you one thing, I am optimistic.

MCDOWELL: Get down or up.

BARTIROMO: On the back cracking on the economy, what are you most bullish on?

SMITH: Bullish on -- bullish on the market, not right now, not today.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SMITH: Bullish on the economy, I'm bullish, I think Trump is basically getting it right and we we're going to talk more about this whole tariffs thing. I think, I am optimistic right now.

BRENBERG: Well it's certainly not unexpected, right? And he'd been talking about this, and talking at this maybe came later than people thought at but it was going to come.

SMITH: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And the uncertainty to all of this, the trade story is exactly what people were worried about going into the election. Remember when the market was down 700 points on election night it was because of uncertainty around NAFTA, what will Donald Trump do. And this is what we're seeing right here. Coming up this morning joining the conversation, Florida Congressman and House Freedom Caucus Member, Ron DeSantis is with us.

Remember the (INAUDIBLE) -- Caucus was among the first to say, we're not in on this bill, former FDIC Chairman and founder a Systemic Risk Council, Sheila Bair is with us this morning. Then the author of The Coming Collapse Of China, Gordon Chang will weigh in along with the CEO of Deloitte Cathy Engelbert is here. Plus elevation partner, cofounder, managing director and investor and Mark Zuckerberg's mentor, Roger McNamee, one of the leader shareholders in Facebook for some time. We're going to talk with Roger about what took place on Facebook and this market this week.

But first, we want to kick it off right now, with the trade war hitting global markets, stocks across Asia tumbled, following directions from Wall Street. Take a look at the numbers here, of course we know that all the majors in Asia were down between three and 4.5 percent. Japan being the worst down 4.5 percent.

Back in the U.S., the Dow closed down more than 700 points yesterday after President Trump proposed tariffs of up to $60 billion on imports from China along with tighter restrictions on the country's acquisition and technology transfers, It was in response to what the administration is calling China's unfair trading practices.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're doing things for this country that should've been done for many, many years. We've had this abuse by many other countries and groups of countries that were put together in order to take advantage of the United States and we don't want that to happen. We're not going to let that happen. I t's probably one of the reasons I was elected, maybe one of the main reasons.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Hours later the Chinese government fired back saying that it plans to roll out its own retaliatory tariffs of up to $3 billion on U.S. goods in response to the tariffs on steel and aluminum which go into effect today. The U.S. now says some allies including Canada, Mexico and the E.U. among others will get a brief exemption from the tariffs. Joining us right now to talk more about that is Congresswoman Claudia Tenney of New York, a former small business owner, congresswoman good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us. And I know you're back on a lot to talk about small business and about lending money get into that. But first, let's talk about these tariffs, good idea or are you against?

REP. CLAUDIA TENNEY (R), NEW YORK: I tend to be more on Gary's side. Gary B's got the idea. I think, the terms on to something, I did a Pentagon article last year 2016 about the problem we have with China. That was the tariffs hacking, what's happening overall in terms of currency. All this things affects small businesses. I'm a small business owner in upstate New York. And put together with the -- all the things that China's doing, I mean, we're trying to move in a direction that we're kind of correct, trying to correct this, I think, that's what you're seeing in the market, I hoping that's a correction, I hope Dagen's dire prediction here is not true.

BARTIROMO: What do you say about the fact that China is coming back now and saying, really, we're going to tariff you? And so now we are looking at a serious retaliatory story.

TENNEY: Yes, I think it's stupid, I mean, Kim Jong-un also reacted to President Trump, to some strong language. But think about what's happening here tough, China actually has the biggest marketplace in the world that you want to have access to, and that's the United States. We are where the consumers are and so, they want to get access to us too. So, that's something that they've got to weigh in to the negotiation. They're business model I think is flawed in the end. We know that they've set up these state-run businesses that -- and that's how they operate. I mean, much like what's done in New York State under our current governor, but we know that that kind of cronie is in that kind of set up of state-run businesses in the long run doesn't work which is why I tend to favor that we've got to do something now, how long are we going wait? How long are we going to let China cheat? How long are we going, you know, steeling our intellectual property from our steel companies and others and I think that's what Wilbur Ross and the President are recognizing and something has to be done and maybe this is a very short-term pain that may end up being, you know, long-term gain for us.

BRENBERG: What about the uncertainty this creates for small businesses? You are small business owners, you understand they're trying to make plans, now they're saying, you know, which of this 1300 products is going to be hit by a tariff, how big is the tariff? That's very hard for a small shop to deal with, is that a big concern here or do you think that's very, very temporary?

BARTIROMO: Prices will go up.

TENNEY: Right, it is a concern especially for the smaller businesses. We have some of the small business in area. We have a company called share manufacturing which took over the older night limited which went under and went to Asia where there's manufacturing, they're dependent on purchasing steel as well, but I also have another number of companies in my district that also are steel companies and they like to see a little bit of help. Well, it's the day for an IPO. The cloud storage company, Dropbox, bumping the price of its shares in its initial public offering to $21.00, that's the second hike for Dropbox. They had previously set a range of $16.00- $18.00 a pop. The bump up shows strong demand among the investors. Shares start trading today on the NASDAQ, the symbol is DBX, the company is valued at over $8 billion. So, we're talking about the big tech company struggling lately. How are the unicorns going to do?

BARTIROMO: Well, we'll see how the deal does today even in the face of a down market. Lauren, thank you so much. Dropbox -- I want to get your take on that later. Dagen, this subpoena, we knew this was coming. Bob Goodlatte told me on Sunday that it was coming. I find it extraordinary that they can request 1.2 million documents and only get 3000 back. How is it possible that the FBI just blows off the committee that has jurisdiction over it?

MCDOWELL: And I think some of the blame needs to be directed at Attorney General Jeff Sessions, that I think that it's the entrenched old-school lifelong government workers who are part of the problem here. But again, who's running the FBI? Jeff Sessions, I know, he's recused himself in any matters dealing with Russia, but what about Rod Rosenstein?

BARTIROMO: Well, you're right. I mean, somebody has got to enforce this.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And they've only received 3000 of the documents.

BRENBERG: The numbers look so ludicrous. I mean, 3000 over -- it looks like, forget about it, just told defiance. I think Americans feel like, there's a million document, let's give a big chunk of those and see what's there.

BARTIROMO: And by the way, don't forget when our friend, Jason Chaffetz, was running the Oversight Committee and he went into a hearing and said, you are officially served. He handed the subpoena to the FBI, months before this subpoena, and they still didn't comply. So, I don't know, but you're right, it's up to Jeff Sessions. Somebody has to enforce this to get those documents within this investigation.

MCDOWELL: I'm still -- I'm (INAUDIBLE) awaiting the inspector general's report, particularly. It's only been -- it's been less than a week since Andrew McCabe got fired.

SMITH: You're right about one thing: you're fighting the real backbone, which is the entrenched government employees, which typically lean to the left. And they're certainly as we've seen time and time after again, they're anti-Trump.

MCDOWELL: They only sleep on their left side.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: We're going to have Devin Nunes on.

MCDOWELL: You know, your hair is thin on the one side.

BARTIROMO: Yes, then your arm hurts you. We're going to have Devin Nunes on, on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", Chairman of the Intel Committee, to take more about that. We'll take a quick break right here. NFL Free Agent, Eric Reid, walking away from kneeling. We will tell you why a big supporter of Colin Kaepernick is saying now, what he's saying now about the pregame protest. Plus, the sting of the Hornets -- Charlotte makes NBA history with a massive blowout win. Sports is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right. Here's our -- four games, three upsets in the NCAA March Madness. Jared Max with the highlights, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: March Madness indeed, Maria. Out of 17.3 million brackets in ESPN's tournament challenge, you know how many picked all four that won last night? 349, which is actually somewhat remarkable considering the unlikelihood of these results -- a matchup of Wildcats. Kentucky favored to beat Kansas State, but K-state cats, scratched this tie breaking layup for Barry Brown with 19 seconds left, K- state scores the upset 61-58. One win for the first final four since 1964.

The number nine seeded Wildcats play Saturday in the elite eight? the 11- seated Ramblers from Loyola Chicago. When it's time for leaving, I hope you understand, I was born a rambling man in Rambler. Its town says, it's not time for leaving yet. Loyola Chicago beats Nevada, 69-68. They're in the elite eight for the first time in 55 years since 98-year-old Team Chaplan, Sister Jean. Getting lots of brotherly love from the Ramblers players. So, we're number nine seed one -- a number 11 seed one.

And another number nine, football powerhouse, Florida State knocked out last year's runner-up, Gonzaga. Seminoles win 75 to 60 in the regional finals for the third time. The only game that went as expect, third seed, Michigan, won its 12th straight. The Wolverines eliminated Texas A&M, 99- 72. Michigan plays Florida State four more games tonight, including the only number one seeds left, Kansas and Villanova in action.

Record-setting night in the NBA: Charlotte Hornets became only the sixth team ever to win a game by 60 points or more. Wild night, Dwight Howard, not part of the mix. He served the one-game suspension; didn't matter. As the Hornets did something we haven't seen in 20 years with this type of blowout. Kemba Walker hit 10, three-pointers, a team record. They win by 61 points. Walker at 46 points and only 28 minutes -- nobody had ever scored that many in so few minutes since the shot clock came to date.

Hey, Johnny Manziel, making a comeback, former high spin trophy winner, sober, looking healthy, full-faced, in football shape, attracted scouts from 13 NFL teams yesterday at a pro-day work at San Diego. Unemployed NFL free safety, Eric Reid, one of the original national anthem kneelers with former teammate, Colin Kaepernick, says he's not going to kneel anymore. He says, the message was understood that they didn't kneel to protest the national anthem. Question: when you and your significant other do yoga, do you ever try to re-create the scene in dirty dancing? As Patriots Quarterback, Tom Brady, Gisele Bundchen did. They've had the time of their lives and, Maria, they've never felt this way before.

BARTIROMO: Wow! Look at that.

BRENBERG: I don't want to know that, Jared. I just -- I don't what to know that last piece.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Tom Brady is pretty and tolerable, but somehow he just managed to become even more.

(LAUGHTER)

BRENBERG: Come on! Keep it to yourself.

BARTIROMO: He's doing yoga.

BRENBERG: Keep it to yourself.

SMITH: What you do in privacy of your yoga sessions. Johnny Manziel, you can't keep your eyes off of him. Is he going to sign with them or anything?

MAX: I think so. The 13 scouts there to watch throw. He looks healthy. He looks like he's ready to play football. Because he looks so sick for a while and not doing well.

BRENBERG: I love the comeback stories. I'd love to see it happen.

MAX: We love the comebacks. You know, Tiger Woods, we're all rooting for now.

MCDOWELL: Let's not compare Johnny Manziel to Tiger Woods.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Johnny Manziel has proved that --

MAX: Correct.

MCDOWELL: -- he can't play professional football.

BRENBERG: I want the comeback story here.

MCDOWELL: O wanted Tom Brady to fall on, still.

BARTIROMO: But he did it. They are perfect. You need to understand they're perfect. That's it, Dagen. Jared, thank you. Jared's sports reports Fox News Headlines 24/7 and SiriusXM 115, catch him. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good morning. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks for joining us this Friday. It is Friday, March 23rd, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VMJ-8831-F03R-N290-00000-00Global market strategists gave us 5 reasons tech giants will keep winning — even if they're broken up2019-03-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal market strategists gave us 5 reasons tech giants will keep winning — even if they're broken upMarley Jay

Mar 12, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Reuters / Rick Wilking Threats to big technology may seem like they're rising. But, over the long run, strategists are optimistic about Amazon, Facebook, and Google as well as the broader tech and communications sectors. Senator and presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren proposed breaking up Amazon, Google and Facebook, and said Apple should have to split off its App Store. Few expect that to take place.

But even if much more tech regulation is on the way, experts see big positives for those companies and for the sector in general. As Senator Elizabeth Warren proposes busting up four of the world's largest tech companies, Wall Street strategists aren't quaking in fear. Warren wants to break up Amazon, Google, and Facebook[1], and also says Apple should be forced to split off the App Store.[2] While investors don't want any of that to happen, they're also not that worried about what Warren's call means for tech. "[Breakups] would not be, over the longer term, a terrible thing for the tech sector," Kristina Hooper, the chief global market strategist for $946 billion Invesco, told Business Insider by phone. "Regulations are not what capitalists embrace, and with good reason, but it doesn't spell the end of the world for any sector." She added that the tech sector would eventually overcome those breakups much like the steel and telecom industries survived the splitting of US Steel and AT...respectively. Even if stock prices in the mega-cap tech space take an immediate hit, the longer-term impact is likely to be muted[3], according to Sameer Samana, the global equity and technical strategist for the Wells Fargo Investment Institute. That's because traders still bullish on tech fundamentals can use selling as an excuse to boost exposure at a discount. "If regulation was to create buying opportunities, that would probably only make us more favorable on the sector," Samana said. Carl Szabo, vice president of the e-commerce group NetChoice, said he's worried about rising hostility toward business and an increase in all sorts of regulation. But he's still optimistic about the companies' prospects in the longer term. "These businesses are generating incredible revenues and incredible profits," he said. "Even if regulation chips into some of that, they're still going to be significant engines of economic success." It's worth emphasizing that few on Wall Street think that Warren's proposals will be enacted as they face political and legal hurdles in the event she's elected. But even if a tech breakup does occur, or if regulatory oversight is expanded, there's still plenty to be optimistic about. Here are the five main reasons gleaned by Business Insider in conversations with a handful of Wall Street experts:1) Everything is going onlineThe changes in modern life that have helped these four companies soar in value in recent decades, like tremendous growth in online shopping and entertainment, are so powerful that new regulations won't diminish them. That leaves the strategists very optimistic about tech's future. "Tech is either at the forefront of, or it forms a backbone of, all those different big picture trends," Samana said.2) More efficient stocks winHooper says huge companies that spread into numerous businesses generally trade at a discount compared to more focused ones. That's because investors feel the larger companies are less nimble and efficient than pure plays — and it means investors might jump at the chance to invest in specific parts of Amazon, Google, or Facebook if they were split up. "Most companies that are conglomerates trade at a conglomerate discount," she says. Read more: The man who invented the web keeps puncturing Silicon Valley's self-aggrandizing ideas about how it's been great for humanity[4]3) Rivals get crushedWarren's proposals are aimed at a few huge companies, but it's possible they will create more trouble for newer and smaller competitors by adding to their costs and slowing their growth. "The larger tech companies will figure out ways to comply, but the real threat is for the smaller businesses and the startups," says Szabo. Szabo said that the costs of some of Warren's regulations will be "incredible," but the tech giants have more than enough cash to handle them. But smaller companies that don't make as much money will have a very hard time doing the same.4) The benefits of regulationSamana and Hooper both argue that new regulations might solve real problems in the technology industry by improving data privacy and making it easier for users to trust these companies after a slew of high-profile scandals[5]. While Hooper says most critics are focused on the idea that new rules could threaten growth or profits, she said continuing controversies over privacy and fake news might be just as damaging for the companies and their stocks. "Rising mistrust from consumers would also be a possible headwind," she said. Samana said consumers might feel better about their relationship with big tech if they had more chances to decide how they want their data to be used, and the companies could gain a new revenue stream if they give users an opportunity to pay them not to collect or sell some personal information. "It maybe ends up being a more fulfilling relationship for both sides," he said.5) Tech's other winnersSamana says that if new regulations are implemented, smaller tech companies might briefly rally on the expectation they will benefit. Over the longer term, he said new rules will create business opportunities for some companies. If the tech giants have to follow new data protection or privacy rules, Samana said, they may have to spend a lot of money on new security software and upgrades. "We are at a watershed moment for tech and data privacy," he said. "The technology almost hasn't kept pace with how consumers' preferences have shifted."NOW WATCH: Here's how North Korea's Kim Jong Un became one of the world's scariest dictators[6]See Also: The CEO of the world's largest miner details where he's investing as the world shifts away from fossil fuels —and he says it could lock in 100 years of profits[7]Bank of America has a simple solution for companies looking to boost their stocks: Put more women in charge. Here are the charts that prove it.[8]'China isn't going to implode': A Wall Street chief strategist breaks down why the nation's latest economic warning isn't a disaster and outlines the path higher for US stocks[9] SEE ALSO:'Another break point may be coming': On the 10th anniversary of the last stock market bottom, a $160 billion investment chief explains why traders should be getting very urn:contentItem:5VRY-5H51-JD33-J1R8-00000-00Global Medical Devices Key View2019-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal Medical Devices Key View

Despite posing significant obstacles, the healthcare market potential and trends will continue to attract big tech firms. Hitherto, tech companies have avoided heavy involvement in the medical device industry and have stayed closer to their field of expertise. Artificial intelligence and big data have the potential to cause the biggest changes.

Key View: Despite posing significant obstacles, the healthcare market potential and trends will continue to attract big tech firms. Hitherto, tech companies have avoided heavy involvement in the medical device industry and have stayed closer to their field of expertise. Artificial intelligence and big data have the potential to cause the biggest changes.

Source: National Statistics, Fitch Solutions Latest Updates And Key Forecasts We have revised slightly upwards our forecast CAGR and now project that the global medical device market will grow by a 2018-2023 CAGR of 5.8% in weighted local currency terms, slightly down from a 2013-2018 CAGR of 6.2%. Mid-single-digit market growth that is slightly below the historic average reflects a global economy being buffeted by various political and economic forces, and well as healthcare funding challenges in both developed and emerging markets. Diverging macroeconomic prospects across the different regions, in addition to the UK's separation from the EU and uncertainty under the Trump administration, makes a slight downgrade to our global medical device market a likely scenario. With well-developed healthcare systems and an evolving regulatory landscape, Western Europe remains the most attractive region in the world in which to commercialise a medical device, as reflected in our Medical Devices Risk/Reward Index. Asia, led by well-established markets such as Japan and rapidly growing emerging markets such as China, and the Americas, led by the weight of the US and Canada, have above average scores. Eastern Europe, MENA and SSA have below average scores, hit by political, economic and operational risks. In FY17, R&D expenditure of orthopaedic device companies remained flat with only a few companies reporting significant increases, unlike FY16, when the majority of orthopaedic companies increased their R&D expenditure in line with revenue growth. More specifically, Stryker led the way by far with a 10.1% increase in its R&D expenditure, followed by NuVasive, which increased its R&D expenses by 5.1%. Zimmer Biomet, Globus Medical, Medtronic and Wright Medical Group reported very small changes (less or equal to 1%) compared to their FY16 R&D expenses. Smith & Nephew reported a relatively higher decline, around 3% y-o-y.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y4C-P0H1-F03R-N234-00000-00Global mergers are off to a slow start in 20202020-02-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal mergers are off to a slow start in 2020Dan Primack

Feb 03, 2020( Axios: https://link.axios.com/join/am-signup?source=aci Delivered by Newstex) There was only $164 billion of announced global mergers and acquisitions in January, the slowest start to a year since 2013, per Refinitiv.Why it matters: This comes off a 2019 in which volume was down slightly from 2018, but still the fourth-largest dollar volume in history and sixth-straight year above $3 trillion. At first blush, this doesn't make a whole lot of sense.

CEO confidence is through the roof, companies are flush with stock thanks to buybacks, and private equity is sitting on Everest-like piles of dry powder. Three theories for the early 2020 lethargy:1. Regulatory pressures. All sorts of deals are being blocked, or at least put under very tough scrutiny, by a variety of governments in a variety of industries. It's not just about U.S. regulators and big tech (which, truth be told, has largely skated so far). The FTC this morning announced it will sue to block Edgewell, the maker of Schick razors, from buying Harry's for $1.3 billion in cash and stock.Harry's says it is "disappointed" and is "evaluating the best path forward." 2. Coronavirus. This won't permanently stop mergers that make strategic and financial sense, but it could slow announcements until both parties can get a better handle on what the spreading illnesses mean for their businesses (including for their supply chains). Axios' Dion Rabouin and Joann Muller go deeper on the growing global economic threat of coronavirus[1]. 3. Political uncertainty: It's mostly a CEO excuse for not pulling the trigger, but it's still being discussed. Particularly in a presidential election year in which two of the leading Democratic candidates are pledging to fundamentally restructure a healthcare industry that played host to many of last year's largest deals (including BMS buying Celgene for $74 billion).The bottom line: January may prove to have been an anomaly, and 2020 M&A volume could end up more closely resembling 2019 than 2013. But so far it's been all systems stop.Go deeper: Guitar-maker Fender gets new majority owner[2] [ 1]: https://www.axios.com/coronavirus-global-economic-threat-c7eeac4a-c2a4-4be2-9815-45ae7af117e5.html [ 2]:   https://www.axios.com/servco-pacific-fender-tpg-growth-d53db6b7-3dc1-4dad-bffe-0203834f1f15.html
