Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WNV-1FV1-F0J6-J3R0-00000-00GLOBAL NETWORKS AT WAR2019-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 36GLOBAL NETWORKS AT WARSandy Plunkett

Big data China and the United States are battling for control of networked technology. Australia has to find ways to avoid becoming a digital colony of either, writes Sandy Plunkett.

When we hear Australian business and political leaders say the world is more connected than ever, despite the current climate of Donald Trump's America First and the UK's Brexit, we know they're right.

But ask them to extrapolate on the socio-economic implications of that hyper-connectedness for their businesses and for Australians, the response is typically platitudes about inclusiveness, opportunity, jobs and growth.

What they won't talk about is the downside.

There are only two types of people in the world: those that own and control networks; and those that use them. And like crack addicts are to dealers, the users make the owners multibillionaires. Five of the eight richest people in the world are owners of networks. None are Australian.

The outsized wealth of network owners is why many Australian leaders - from bank CEOs to start-up founders - are all wanting to emulate a fraction of the success of the network platform giants.

"People love to criticise the tech giants, and there may be plenty to criticise, but every business leader would kill to have a piece of what Google, Facebook and Amazon have," says Richard White, CEO of ASX-listed logistics software darling WiseTech Global.

White's network savvy, particularly as it applies to understanding the physical to digital network dividend and leveraging Australian engineering talent to scale globally in the logistics space, has earned him an estimated net worth of $3.3 billion.

This winners-take-all "network effect" is as true for countries as it is for individuals and businesses.

In a regional and global context, Australia is a network user. The US and China are today's unrivalled network owners. Both are in an arms race for supremacy of a blitz-scaled world driven by big data and artificial intelligence.

Yet after more than two decades, most Australian leaders have been watching this unprecedented shift from the sidelines. The generalities they proffer are a clear tell their understanding of network science and the properties that cause networks to scale or wither, remains paper thin.

"It's a critical knowledge gap Australia needs to close. We've missed the first phase of the digital network revolution," says Adrian Turner, the CEO of Data61, the CSIRO's data science agency.

"Most people are late to understanding 21st-century network scale because they don't have a good grasp of history and they have far less of a grasp of network science," says celebrated economic historian Niall Ferguson, a Senior Fellow of Stanford's Hoover Institution, a geopolitical think tank.

"If you think that Lehman Bros failed because Dick Fuld [Lehman's last chairman] was an asshole, which was basically the thinking adopted at the time, you fail to see that Lehman was a hugely critical node in a highly complex network," says Ferguson with typical candour.

We need to study-up on network science and quickly, because in the digital age, no country is an island, networks never sleep and they are highly calibrated engines for profit for the few and tribalism for the many, he says.

"All these studies about inequality ... Thomas Picketty [author of the best-selling book Capital in the 21st Century] missed the point entirely. The story of today's massive inequality is a story about network structure. It has far less to do with the rate of profit being higher than the rate of growth."

If we don't understand network structures and theory, "egalitarian" Australia may be doomed to be a low-value player in a cut-throat networked global economy.

Since the revelations of Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election and numerous privacy breaches and censorship snafus, Facebook CEO and chairman Mark Zuckerberg has been trying to placate users and regulators for the unintended negative consequences of networked social media.

"Duh," says Ferguson. "From the birth of the internet, the tech titans have uttered versions of this utopian cyber babble: 'We're all going to be Netizens, and everything will be awesome'. But networks - digital or otherwise - have always been instruments for great inequality and tribalism."

In his book The Square and the Tower, Ferguson looks at the world through the lens of successive network revolutions, not just industrial ones.

"In the 15th century the chief disruptor was Martin Luther. He used the printing press to disrupt a corrupted Roman Catholic hierarchy in Europe.

"What happened was a Pandora's box had been opened and Europe was plunged into more than a hundred years of religious conflict, much of it staggeringly violent."

It was only the first of a succession of network propelled revolutions that followed, from the Enlightenment to the French and American revolutions to today's Silicon Valley-led digital version.

The 21st-century technocrats didn't invent networks, but they did automate and scale them. And despite calls for greater regulatory scrutiny and the break-up of big tech, they continue to do so at an alarmingly accelerated pace. They achieve this by harnessing a deep knowledge of network science and behavioural science.

Network scientists see people as nodes. We, the nodes, have edges in terms of our relationships, and those edges connect us to other nodes. Some people have more edges than others. When you look at network structure, the thing to note is which nodes have hub-like properties and hierarchies.

Network and data scientists see the complex interactions and dynamics of nodes, hubs and edges in every human endeavour.

So, if you want to understand inequality, look to the winners-take-all network properties; if you want to understand financial markets, Islamic extremism or the innovation of Silicon Valley, look into their networks and at their hubs, spokes and edges.

Networks are everywhere, all around us and inside us. The prevalence of networks is probably why we throw the word around so casually but so often miss the important stuff, like pollsters missing the rise of Trumpism; or predicting a Labor victory in the last Australian federal election.

Our brains are neural networks and while neuroscientists understand more of how the brain works, we still don't know how we arrive at an idea or an "Aha!" moment. Like "innovation", the output of many "Aha!" moments, the word "network" is overused and misunderstood.

The technocrats also know things don't go viral because they are good ideas, which is the common and dangerous assumption. Things go viral because of the properties of the network they enter.

It's also true of diseases and it turns out that ideas, good and bad, behave a lot like infectious diseases. Outrage, the inflamed language of fake news and hate speech spreads like wildfire and it is the structure of the networks that determines the speed of contagion.

As was clear in the spread of video from the Christchurch massacre, it is impossible to control without also negatively impacting far more benign and educationally important expressions of free speech.

Australia's domestic economy is a sub-network of a super global network. But economists obsessed with macro models generally don't think about the economy as a network.

One striking visualisation of the global networked economy is Harvard's Atlas of Economic Complexity.

Since 2011, a team at Harvard has been developing and refining this data visualisation tool that maps the dynamics of global trade and ranks countries according to industrial capabilities and knowhow.

It includes data from 250 countries and territories, classified into 20 categories of goods and five categories of services. Combined, this results in coverage of over 6000 products worldwide, with coloured dots representing exports of $100 million.

Some products, like medical imaging or Swiss watches, are far more complex than others, like iron ore. The world's most complex economies are Japan, Switzerland and Germany. How good is Australia? In terms of economic complexity, not very. It ranks 93 out of 140 countries assessed. More disturbing is that its ranking has dropped 23 places in a decade.

In a world of increasing product and market complexity the countries that show the fastest declines in the past decade have become increasingly dependent on commodities (like Australia), or were affected by political instability or civil war.

Our relatively low economic complexity and low penetration of international markets makes us vulnerable.

Seek Founder and venture capitalist Paul Bassett recently tweeted: "Most of our largest companies are focused mainly on the Australia and New Zealand market [banking and retail]. But in today's world many markets are won globally not locally. As a result, our national winners and our economy are vulnerable to disruption."

This has been true for some time and it's starting to bite. Australia is in per capita recession with low innovation output, low internationalisation, stagnant wages and high household debt crushing consumer confidence. We need to up our game with 21st-century skills, products that can scale globally.

There are pockets of network science expertise in Australian research and business, though this knowledge is not nearly diffused enough.

Many of the CSIRO's Data61 400-plus PhDs and researchers are experts in network science, machine learning and AI. Data61 even goes so far as to call itself a network and not an institution.

But on how wide and deep the agency's interactions are with business leaders about the properties of networks and how to apply them, CEO Adrian Turner admits it does not happen nearly as often, nor as structured as he would like. But not, he says, through lack of trying.

"To leap ahead in the next generation of the networked economy, we need to disrupt today's vertically integrated platforms with more open, federated, global data co-operatives. They allow for more participants in a value chain to share in the new value created from their data, and to train AI systems to remove the scale advantages of today's platform companies."

Turner says this "federated" model will allow access to larger-scale datasets.

This is important. Big data is critical to training artificial intelligence systems and countries with large populations and low privacy protections, like China have unassailable advantages.

A federated approach could help Australia to compete and to avoid becoming a mere colonial digital outpost of either China or the US. But it also presents enormous new complexities, not just in harnessing scarce skills and enterprise to pursue such a strategy, but also as it relates to myriad surveillance and privacy issues.

Last month, Data61's parent organisation, CSIRO, produced its four-yearly research treatise, the Australian National Outlook 2019 report. The 172-page CSIRO/NAB ANO models alternative futures for Australia to 2060. The ANO offers a binary choice: a business-as-usual path of slow decline, or a collective effort toward something called the Outlook Vision.

No prizes for guessing which future the CSIRO, NAB and its 21 additional partner companies want us to embrace.

But how we get there is unclear. The report has no policy recommendations or specific milestones and action items to pursue or monitor.

The two primary phases of network disruption between the first phase in the 15th-century printing press era and the second 1970s phase with the birth of the personal computer were separated by a return to hierarchy in the late 19th and 20th centuries.

Why? Because the technology of the period - steamship lines, railroads, the telegraph and telephone favoured centralised control.

The rise of Silicon Valley in the 1970s happened not just because of the technology but because the existing hierarchy was weak. The commercial internet flourished because the US government had little interest in innovating it beyond its research origins, allowing the venture capital and private tech sector to have at it.

"There was also a Soviet internet at the same time, but it failed because of Soviet hierarchy," says Ferguson.

China's 21st-century communist hierarchy is hell-bent on not repeating that mistake. Its aggressive digital and AI-driven global expansion ambitions have deeply unsettled the US.

It should unsettle Australians too. Although the rhetoric of today's big tech titans speaks of a flat world full of opportunity for all, the fact is that the global network platforms originating in both the US and China are highly centralised.

Australia is wedged between a tech war between these network superpowers. The intractable issues in the current trade war are about intellectual property rights and theft and technology transfer restrictions and obligations. We confront a choice between two worlds, says Ferguson. Neither very appealing.

"Silicon Valley's world in which data are available indirectly to the highest bidder because everything is about is essentially about advertising revenue; and a Chinese model in which everything is about maintaining the power of the Communist Party and your data are available on-demand to Xi Jinping. That's not a great choice."

History shows us that creating mass interconnectedness is not going to bring universal harmony to the world. It all comes down to friction between squares and towers and the relationships between networks and hierarchies.

How it turns out for Australia, a culture that has long believed in a social contract based on egalitarianism and the fair go is ours to answer.

The CSIRO ANO report was right to say a future prosperous Australia requires a cultural and intellectual shift. But just how do we maintain our democratic roots and values in a winners-take-all networked economy that we have had little role in designing and scaling is the key question of our time.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6088-HJY1-JBN8-N2KF-00000-00Global NGOs Denounce Google's USD2.1 Billion Fitbit Buyout2020-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisCompany SignificantGlobal NGOs Denounce Google's USD2.1 Billion Fitbit Buyout

(Alliance News) - An international group of consumer advocates and NGOs denounced Alphabet Inc's Google's bid for sports smartwatch-maker Fitbit Thursday, saying it would threaten privacy and grant Google unfair access to a new market.

Google's USD2.1 billion acquisition of the maker of smartwatches and fitness trackers was unveiled in November and rang alarms among global regulators over antitrust and privacy worries.

Fitbit is a pioneer in the market for connected watches and other physical activity sensors that measure the number of daily steps taken, calories burned or hours of sleep missed.

A group of 20 NGOs "have significant concerns" that the takeover "would be a game-changer not only for how people interact with the online world but also for digital and related health markets," a statement said.

"Regulators around the world... must therefore give it their utmost attention," they said, calling it a "test case" on facing down big tech firms.

The groups included BEUC, which unites EU consumer advocates, as well as the Consumer Federation of America in the US and digital rights groups in Mexico, Brazil and Australia.

EU regulators, who are to decide on the case by July 20, are especially concerned with Silicon Valley giants buying their way into new areas and then stifling competition.

"Wearable devices could replace smartphones as the main gateway to the internet, just as smartphones replaced personal computers," said a statement by 20 NGOs from around the globe.

"Google's expansion into this market, edging out other competitors would thus be significant," it said.

In February, the European Data Protection Board urged Google to make major assurances on privacy and data before it approved the buyout.

Shares in Alphabet closed 1.7% higher at USD1,442.00 on Wednesday in New York.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6088-7241-JBV1-X410-00000-00Global NGOs rap Google's Fitbit buyout2020-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal NGOs rap Google's Fitbit buyoutBrussels, July 2 2020

An international group of consumer advocates and NGOs denounced Google's bid for sports smartwatch-maker Fitbit Thursday, saying it would threaten privacy and grant Google unfair access to a new market.

Google's $2.1 billion acquisition of the maker of smartwatches and fitness trackers was unveiled in November and rang alarms among global regulators over antitrust and privacy worries.

Fitbit is a pioneer in the market for connected watches and other physical activity sensors that measure the number of daily steps taken, calories burned or hours of sleep missed.

A group of 20 NGOs "have significant concerns" that the takeover "would be a game-changer not only for how people interact with the online world but also for digital and related health markets," a statement said.

"Regulators around the world... must therefore give it their utmost attention," they said, calling it a "test case" on facing down big tech firms.

The groups included BEUC, which unites EU consumer advocates, as well as the Consumer Federation of America in the US and digital rights groups in Mexico, Brazil and Australia.

EU regulators, who are to decide on the case by July 20, are especially concerned with Silicon Valley giants buying their way into new areas and then stifling competition.

"Wearable devices could replace smartphones as the main gateway to the internet, just as smartphones replaced personal computers," said a statement by 20 NGOs from around the globe.

"Google's expansion into this market, edging out other competitors would thus be significant," it said.

In February, the European Data Protection Board urged Google to make major assurances on privacy and data before it approved the buyout.

GOOGLE

FITBIT

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TXY-W951-DY19-C2V1-00000-00Global policy makers are watching Australia over Google and Facebook2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal policy makers are watching Australia over Google and FacebookMatthew Knott & Nick Miller

The ACCC report into ways to regulate Facebook and Google has received plaudits in the UK and US, which are both grappling with similar issues.

New York/London: Senior US figures have welcomed the Australian competition regulator's controversial push to curtail the power of tech giants Google and Facebook and predict many of the ACCC's recommendations will be followed in other parts of the world.

Tom Wheeler, the former head of the Federal Communications Commission, which oversees US media and telecommunications companies, said American politicians and regulators would be "crazy" to ignore the recommendations in the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission report released this week.

Former Obama administration official Dipayan Ghosh, who served as privacy and public policy adviser at Facebook, said the report was already being shared and discussed by members of the US tech policy community.

And in the UK, the 378-page report drew enthusiastic approval from Conservative MP Damian Collins, chair of the UK parliament's Digital, Culture, Media and Sport select committee, who "absolutely agreed" with the ACCC that the era of self-regulation for tech companies should end.

The release of the world-first inquiry came a day before Google chief executive Sundar Pichai was due to appear before US politicians at a much-anticipated congressional hearing in Washington DC.

The preliminary report contains 11 recommendations include giving a new or existing regulatory body far-reaching powers to investigate and monitor how tech companies display advertising and news stories.

Wheeler, now a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution think tank, said the report could "absolutely" influence the policy debate in the US, where both Democratic and Republican politicians have been reluctant to crack down on the tech industry.

Wheeler headed the powerful Federal Communications Commission from 2013 to 2017 and is best known for establishing "net neutrality" laws to ensure internet service providers treat all data equally.

"I have personally felt the lobbying power of the big tech companies - they have controlled the debate in the US," Wheeler said.

"When new ideas are put forward by relevant and respected nation states you would be crazy not to pay attention and I hope our policy makers will.

"I think this is a big 'a-ha' moment for tech companies that deregulation does not mean no regulation."

He said he was particularly impressed by the ACCC's call for data collection settings on services from the likes of Facebook and Google to be switched to "off" by default.

"I am a strong advocate of an opt-in approach to data collection - that is a great idea," he said.

Ghosh, who served as a technology policy advisor during the Obama administration before moving to Facebook, said the proposed opt-in laws could "deflate their business model overnight".

"The suggestions in the ACCC report are very rigorous and robust," he said.

"These proposals are significant steps in the right direction."

Ghosh is now a fellow at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, where he recently published a major report calling for greater privacy protections, advertising transparency and stronger oversight of mergers in the tech sector.

Ghosh applauded the ACCC for framing its recommendations as an attempt to "restore the power of the individual in the face of an enormously powerful industry".

"That is exactly the way this issue has to be thought about if we are to make progress."

If anything he said the ACCC could have been more aggressive in its recommendations on reducing the market power of the dominant tech companies.

Justin Hendrix, who teaches a course in technology, media and democracy at New York University, said: "This is a significant document that contains a lot of very sensible and straightforward suggestions."

He said there was a growing consensus among regulators in the UK, Europe and Australia about the rules that should govern the tech sector and that they would eventually flow through to the US.

Mr Collins, whose UK parliamentary committee has been running an inquiry into disinformation and fake news in social media, said a statutory body should have the power to "go in and investigate data mishandling or deal with harmful content".

He also backed the ACCC's call for a broader investigation into whether the big online players were abusing their market dominance.

A spokesman for the UK's Competition and Markets Authority said the UK government had launched an expert panel into competition in digital markets led by US economist Jason Furman.

According to the government the review "will investigate the UK's competition regime in the context of the digital economy. It will look at how this affects consumers, and the impact of competition policy on the UK's growth, productivity, wages and labour markets."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TXX-WS11-JBJ7-N1J9-00000-00Global policy makers are watching Australia over Google and Facebook2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal policy makers are watching Australia over Google and FacebookMatthew Knott & Nick Miller

The ACCC report into ways to regulate Facebook and Google has received plaudits in the UK and US, which are both grappling with similar issues.

New York/London: Senior US figures have welcomed the Australian completion regulator's controversial push to curtail the power of tech giants Google and Facebook and predict many of the ACCC's recommendations will be followed in other parts of the world.

Tom Wheeler, the former head of the Federal Communications Commission, which oversees US media and telecommunications companies, said American politicians and regulators would be "crazy" to ignore the recommendations in the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission report released this week.

Former Obama administration official Dipayan Ghosh, who served as privacy and public policy adviser at Facebook, said the report was already being shared and discussed by members of the US tech policy community.

And in the UK, the 378-page report drew enthusiastic approval from Conservative MP Damian Collins, chair of the UK parliament's Digital, Culture, Media and Sport select committee, who "absolutely agreed" with the ACCC that the era of self-regulation for tech companies should end.

The release of the world-first inquiry came a day before Google chief executive Sundar Pichai was due to appear before US politicians at a much-anticipated congressional hearing in Washington DC.

The preliminary report contains 11 recommendations include giving a new or existing regulatory body far-reaching powers to investigate and monitor how tech companies display advertising and news stories.

Wheeler, now a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution think tank, said the report could "absolutely" influence the policy debate in the US, where both Democratic and Republican politicians have been reluctant to crack down on the tech industry.

Wheeler headed the powerful Federal Communications Commission from 2013 to 2017 and is best known for establishing "net neutrality" laws to ensure internet service providers treat all data equally.

"I have personally felt the lobbying power of the big tech companies - they have controlled the debate in the US," Wheeler said.

"When new ideas are put forward by relevant and respected nation states you would be crazy not to pay attention and I hope our policy makers will.

"I think this is a big 'a-ha' moment for tech companies that deregulation does not mean no regulation."

He said he was particularly impressed by the ACCC's call for data collection settings on services from the likes of Facebook and Google to be switched to "off" by default.

"I am a strong advocate of an opt-in approach to data collection - that is a great idea," he said.

Ghosh, who served as a technology policy advisor during the Obama administration before moving to Facebook, said the proposed opt-in laws could "deflate their business model overnight".

"The suggestions in the ACCC report are very rigorous and robust," he said.

"These proposals are significant steps in the right direction."

Ghosh is now a fellow at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, where he recently published a major report calling for greater privacy protections, advertising transparency and stronger oversight of mergers in the tech sector.

Ghosh applauded the ACCC for framing its recommendations as an attempt to "restore the power of the individual in the face of an enormously powerful industry".

"That is exactly the way this issue has to be thought about if we are to make progress."

If anything he said the ACCC could have been more aggressive in its recommendations on reducing the market power of the dominant tech companies.

Justin Hendrix, who teaches a course in technology, media and democracy at New York University, said: "This is a significant document that contains a lot of very sensible and straightforward suggestions."

He said there was a growing consensus among regulators in the UK, Europe and Australia about the rules that should govern the tech sector and that they would eventually flow through to the US.

Mr Collins, whose UK parliamentary committee has been running an inquiry into disinformation and fake news in social media, said a statutory body should have the power to "go in and investigate data mishandling or deal with harmful content".

He also backed the ACCC's call for a broader investigation into whether the big online players were abusing their market dominance.

A spokesman for the UK's Competition and Markets Authority said the UK government had launched an expert panel into competition in digital markets led by US economist Jason Furman.

According to the government the review "will investigate the UK's competition regime in the context of the digital economy. It will look at how this affects consumers, and the impact of competition policy on the UK's growth, productivity, wages and labour markets."

urn:contentItem:5TXY-2C91-JBJ7-N265-00000-00Global policy makers are watching Australia over Google and Facebook2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal policy makers are watching Australia over Google and FacebookMatthew Knott & Nick Miller

The ACCC report into ways to regulate Facebook and Google has received plaudits in the UK and US, which are both grappling with similar issues.

New York/London: Senior US figures have welcomed the Australian completion regulator's controversial push to curtail the power of tech giants Google and Facebook and predict many of the ACCC's recommendations will be followed in other parts of the world.

Tom Wheeler, the former head of the Federal Communications Commission, which oversees US media and telecommunications companies, said American politicians and regulators would be "crazy" to ignore the recommendations in the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission report released this week.

Former Obama administration official Dipayan Ghosh, who served as privacy and public policy adviser at Facebook, said the report was already being shared and discussed by members of the US tech policy community.

And in the UK, the 378-page report drew enthusiastic approval from Conservative MP Damian Collins, chair of the UK parliament's Digital, Culture, Media and Sport select committee, who "absolutely agreed" with the ACCC that the era of self-regulation for tech companies should end.

The release of the world-first inquiry came a day before Google chief executive Sundar Pichai was due to appear before US politicians at a much-anticipated congressional hearing in Washington DC.

The preliminary report contains 11 recommendations include giving a new or existing regulatory body far-reaching powers to investigate and monitor how tech companies display advertising and news stories.

Wheeler, now a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution think tank, said the report could "absolutely" influence the policy debate in the US, where both Democratic and Republican politicians have been reluctant to crack down on the tech industry.

Wheeler headed the powerful Federal Communications Commission from 2013 to 2017 and is best known for establishing "net neutrality" laws to ensure internet service providers treat all data equally.

"I have personally felt the lobbying power of the big tech companies - they have controlled the debate in the US," Wheeler said.

"When new ideas are put forward by relevant and respected nation states you would be crazy not to pay attention and I hope our policy makers will.

"I think this is a big 'a-ha' moment for tech companies that deregulation does not mean no regulation."

He said he was particularly impressed by the ACCC's call for data collection settings on services from the likes of Facebook and Google to be switched to "off" by default.

"I am a strong advocate of an opt-in approach to data collection - that is a great idea," he said.

Ghosh, who served as a technology policy advisor during the Obama administration before moving to Facebook, said the proposed opt-in laws could "deflate their business model overnight".

"The suggestions in the ACCC report are very rigorous and robust," he said.

"These proposals are significant steps in the right direction."

Ghosh is now a fellow at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, where he recently published a major report calling for greater privacy protections, advertising transparency and stronger oversight of mergers in the tech sector.

Ghosh applauded the ACCC for framing its recommendations as an attempt to "restore the power of the individual in the face of an enormously powerful industry".

"That is exactly the way this issue has to be thought about if we are to make progress."

If anything he said the ACCC could have been more aggressive in its recommendations on reducing the market power of the dominant tech companies.

Justin Hendrix, who teaches a course in technology, media and democracy at New York University, said: "This is a significant document that contains a lot of very sensible and straightforward suggestions."

He said there was a growing consensus among regulators in the UK, Europe and Australia about the rules that should govern the tech sector and that they would eventually flow through to the US.

Mr Collins, whose UK parliamentary committee has been running an inquiry into disinformation and fake news in social media, said a statutory body should have the power to "go in and investigate data mishandling or deal with harmful content".

He also backed the ACCC's call for a broader investigation into whether the big online players were abusing their market dominance.

A spokesman for the UK's Competition and Markets Authority said the UK government had launched an expert panel into competition in digital markets led by US economist Jason Furman.

According to the government the review "will investigate the UK's competition regime in the context of the digital economy. It will look at how this affects consumers, and the impact of competition policy on the UK's growth, productivity, wages and labour markets."

just a single organisation but different organisations and reporting the story so that people have a chance to make up their own minds. What can you do about governments when they are involved in misinformation? I won't go into the examples but we all kind of know on the accusations fly all over the place. There will be three words, invest in journalism.

It's not always possible in some environments, but investing in journalism and investing in education of that information consumer. There is a lot of discussion right now about throwing legal infrastructure at the problem, throwing technical infrastructure of the problem, but to me it's making the information consumer as savvy as possible, and that has to start really young but it also has to be thrown and provided for the older generations that are not digital natives. I am a huge advocate of education and investing in journalism. But there's not a lot to do with the government decides it will deny people access to various sites. There's not a lot you can do and that is where the wild wild west of the internet helps. It's a double-edged sword in ways. It is a big problem but the more we provide access to that information across the world as we mentioned in a previous question so far in this discussion that's one of the ways we can get at some of these things. So access to information despite its problems is what we should be after as well. Has the your question? Yes, I want to thank the panel. I was thinking that this misinformation, there are issues about our democracy. Thank you, Joey, from Shanghai in China. Let us go to our last question now and it is Anastasia from Ukraine. My question is, can misinformation be regulated at governmental level without the breaking of basic human rights? I'm very sceptical of that personally. We have a balance to strike between free expression and other human rights that most countries have signed up to, and I think there are good reasons to have legal limits on Hicks Beach and other forms of criminal speech but when it comes to misinformation I think very often misinformation is information that is to stir me an offensive and shocking and not necessarily true. -- hate speech. But this is traditionally covered by freedom of expression rules and we really need to be careful as several of you have pointed out your questions because a lot of misinformation concerns politics and governments and there will always be a temptation if we criminalise things that could be misleading, that they will be used by powerful people and institutions to silence the critics, as of course historically has happened, even in democracies, such rules are being used by powerful people. So we need to be very careful and I'm glad to see courts in free societies around the world express great scepticism towards attempts to regulate misinformation in the last couple of days. Before you answer that, Jeff a related issue about regulation. Some of the platforms themselves are trying to do things, Twitter for instance hid one tweet from President Trump that it said was a bit misleading and one which was a bit provocative when he said the looting starts, the shooting starts and so on, so they themselves are taking some responsibilities, so can governments and Googles and Facebooks step up to this challenge themselves? Imes optical. -- I am sceptical. I'm a huge advocate of freedom of expression and freedom of speech and big tech companies are doing their best to show that they can to this regulation and they are doing more so now than they ever have. I commend some of their efforts. There are certain things we should remove, child pornography for example or suicide videos, all sorts of things we should take down. urn:contentItem:5S03-T9G1-DYTG-40MD-00000-00GLOBAL SELL-OFF HAMMERS TECH COMPANIES FOR £30BN2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGLOBAL SELL-OFF HAMMERS TECH COMPANIES FOR £30BNBY PAUL THOMAS

ON BOTH sides of the Atlantic, shares in technology firms have been hit as the fallout from the Facebook data sharing scandal and Trump's trade war continued to spread.

A further £30.2bn ($42bn) was wiped off the value of the Silicon Valley giants Amazon, Apple and Netflix yesterday after the boss of Facebook agreed to testify to Congress about the crisis engulfing his firm. While Mark Zuckerberg has refused a similar request to appear before British MPs, he said he welcomed regulation of social media sites.

Investors are increasingly fearful that governments and regulators will clamp down on the way big tech firms use and sell the data they keep on their users. That would not just hit the profits of social media sites, but all types of technology firms.

Shares in FTSE 250-listed cyber-security specialists Sophos Group slumped 5.4pc, or 25.2p, to 444.6p, making it the biggest faller among British tech companies. IQE, the Cardiff company that makes chips for Apple's iPhone, fell 4.9pc, or 6.6p, to 126.9p while software firms Aveva (down 1.1pc, or 20p, to 1880p) and Sage (down 0.8pc, or 5.4p, to 643.8p) also lost ground.

The Polar Capital Technology Trust, which invests in dozens of tech firms, including Facebook, dived 4.5pc, or 50p, to 1062p as investors fled the sector.

But the FTSE 100 avoided negative territory as a result of strong showings for healthcare and utilities firms. It ended the day up 0.64pc, or 44.6 points, at 7044.74.

Water company United Utilities' shares soared near the top of the flagship index a day after it announced bullish revenue and profits forecasts. Its shares shot up 8.3pc, or 55.6p, to 724p.

Miners propped up the blue-chip index as the dollar strengthened and the price of oil and metals fell. Evraz had the toughest day of UK-listed miners, falling 6.1pc, or 27.4p, to 425.2p. It was followed by Antofagasta (down 3.9pc, or 37p, to 910.8p), Anglo American (down 3.8pc, or 64.2p, to 1616.8p) and Glencore (down 2.9pc, or 10.35p, to 353.15p).

On to the Aim index. Oil explorers Lansdowne Oil & Gas and Providence Resources have secured another partner for a project off the coast of Cork in Ireland. A consortium of Chinese firms, led by Apec Energy, has bought a 50pc stake.

Steve Boldy, Lansdowne's chief executive, said: The Chinese consortium brings a wealth of technical and operational expertise and experience and we look forward to finalising the details of the drilling programme that is expected to move the project forward to development.' Lansdowne shares jumped 26.4pc, or 0.35p, to 1.68p while Providence's leapt 17pc, or 1.6p, to 11p.

Esports firm Gfinity went cap in hand to investors to fund video game events. It will place more than 55.8m shares to raise the £6.7m it needs. But investors were not impressed and shares slid 3.1pc, or 0.38p, to 11.75p.

Stellar results heated up the shares of refrigerated warehouse provider Norish. The Aim-listed firm increased revenue by 31.5pc to £42.3m last year, while pre-tax profits shot up by 138pc to £1.5m.

Chairman Ted O'Neill said: We anticipate another strong year of profit growth in 2018, underpinned by the initiation of a continuous improvement programme.' Shares hopped 8.4pc, or 6.5p, to 84p.

A bullish update gave a boost to AB Dynamics, which supplies testing kit to the car industry.

Revenues and operating profit for the six months to February 28 are expected to be significantly ahead of the same period last year', while it boasted of a strong order pipeline. Its shares ticked up 6.9pc, or 60p, to 935p.
