<xhtml:span id="h2" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... These senators on both sides of the aisle are gunning for <xhtml:span class="hit">big tech</xhtml:span>.  And so, this  hearing is a start of that.  MCDOWELL:  Are they really gunning for <xhtml:span class="hit">big tech</xhtml:span>, though, Nick?  I mean, <xhtml:span class="hit">big  tech</xhtml:span> is -- you know, when you talk about Silicon Valley and ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h3" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... COMMITTEE: I don't want to hurt Facebook. I don't want to <xhtml:span class="hit">regulate</xhtml:span> them half to death. But, we have a problem. (END VIDEO ...</xhtml:span>

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S2X-YVB1-DY0W-440W-00000-00Global Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's Hearings2018-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's HearingsLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Peter Dickson, we appreciate you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And we appreciate you watching FBN:am this morning. We always appreciate seeing Dagen McDowell on a Monday. Good morning Dagen.

SIMONETTI: Hey Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK, ANCHOR: Ladies, I'll see you later. Good morning, great to see you as always. And great to see all of you. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Crisis in Syria, yet another suspected chemical weapons attack leaving dozens dead, the international community on high alert. As the world waits for a U.S. response, President Trump warning of a big price to pay.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM BOSSERT, WHITE HOUSE HOMELAND SECURITY ADVISOR: I wouldn't take anything off the table, these are horrible photos, we're looking into the attack at this point. I think the president's got a point that's been very clear and I'm going to reiterate that point. The pendulum has swung in the wrong direction for too long and the United States of America has been taken advantage of in their responsibility to provide security for the entire world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Despite the tension, stocks are pointing to a bounce back as concerns over a trade war with China eased a little bit, maybe it was the Sunday morning talk show's rhetoric being thrown out by the White House.

Futures are showing this, 172 point gain on the DOW Futures right now, it's losing week for the Blue Chips last week. This comes after that massive selloff on Friday with the DOW, Nasdaq, and S&P all falling more than two percent.

In Europe, you have some buying to report, the England, France, and Germany, we have gains across the board. In Asia overnight, stocks also moving higher. The biggest winner there, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Zuckerberg taking the Hill, Facebook CEO set to meet with lawmakers in Washington today as he prepares to face a grilling before the Senate tomorrow. The latest as the Cambridge Analytica whistleblower says more people's data could have been exposed.

And a change at the top, Deutsche Bank naming a new CEO, the details as shares jumped on the news.

And terrifying moments on a New York highway, a tour bus slamming into an overpass leaving six people seriously injured, more on their condition ahead.

And the DOJ stonewalling, why Congress Trey Gowdy is calling out the Justice Department over the investigation into alleged FISA abuses.

And orange going to love this, Bud Light going citrus for the summer, the new flavor hitting store shelves coming up. I think that's called a summer shandy.

All of that and so much more this morning, Pollster Maslansky and Partners President, Lee Carter. Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner, Mike Murphy. And the King's College Business and Economics Professor, Brian Brenberg.

I start with you, markets this week, we get bank earnings, worries about a trade war but, again, now geopolitical concerns that the focusing shifted to that.

BRIAN BRENBERG, KING'S COLLEGE AND BUSINESS ECONOMICS PROFESSOR: Yes. Yes, it has. Although it's interesting to watch these back and forth with the trade wars. You get some rhetoric out of the White House, we -- the talk on Thursday night, Friday morning stocks (INAUDIBLE) over the weekend, everybody's out there talking about how this is not a big deal, we don't want a trade war, you come back Monday morning, stocks up again.

We're seeing this pattern repeat again and again. It seems to take a day or two for markets to digest that you've got rhetoric and you've got reality on trade and the reality probably isn't going to be as bad or as harsh as a rhetoric sounds.

MCDOWELL: Mike, what are you watching this week?

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO, MANAGING PARTNER: Absolutely. So watching the volatility in the market, that's really spurn -- spurred by this trade war talk. And I think just a few months ago we were talking about there's no volatility in the market.

We haven't had a one percent move in so many months. Well now you're getting two percent move almost on a daily basis. I think the main thing for investors to do here is to try to block out the headlines and stick with their long-term plans. So we're going to get the down 500s, the bounces above 200s. Overall, there's not going to be a major trade war with China in my opinion, it will back to focus on the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: I think some of the White House officials needs some messaging help because you've got Secretary MNuchin on Friday talking about the potential of a trade war and then trying to walk back those comments yesterday saying, "I don't expect it at all in terms of a trade war." Don't have your Treasury Secretary utter the words trade war ever.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND MASLANSKY & PARTNERS PRESIDENT: That would be a good first step. But I think it's fascinating to see how the markets are reacting so much to the rhetoric rather than just the policy.

It's unbelievable, a tweet, one announcement can send the markets in a tailspin. And what's happened traditionally is that we've looked at the experts and say, "What are we really supposed to be looking at?" One tweet, one message, one interview can totally change the course of the markets and we're seeing that this week and certainly the White House rhetoric tone way back saying this has always been -- there's nothing new here, nothing's developed here, not a trade war and look, things are softening again.

MCDOWELL: And I'm looking forward to Mark Zuckerberg on Capitol Hill. Again, Facebook will reveal today to Facebook users whose data was accessed by Cambridge Analytica, it's about 70 million people. Estimates are in the United States alone.

And watch Mark Zuckerberg because back in 2010, he broke out into a Nixonian flop sweat when Walt Mossberg was interviewing him. And I mean sweat was dripping off of his face.

CARTER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So if you do that on Capitol Hill, watch your stock tank.

BRENBERG: His appearances are always so staged managed. This one absolutely cannot be. And so it's going to be interesting to see what he does under that kind of pressure.

MCDOWELL: We're trying to get the video but he had sweat dripping off his nose and his chin. I'm not kidding. It's --

CARTER: This is not where he's comfortable.

MURPHY: Yes. That was -- that was back in the days of the hoodie sweatshirt.

MCDOWELL: Yes. So you're saying he was hot.

MURPHY: So he's come a long way.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE) t-shirt.

MCDOWELL: He was -- he was just hot. OK. We're going to talk about that all morning. Also coming up, New York Congressman Chris Collins, South Dakota Senator Mike Rounds. Host of Michelle Malkin Investigates on CRTV.com, Michelle Malkin. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Legendary Soulman, my friend, Sam Moore. You don't want to miss any of them.

Our top story this morning, crossing the red line, the world awaiting the U.S. response to a suspected chemical weapons attack in Syria that killed dozens of citizens. Yesterday, warplanes bombing an airbase near the City of Homs. Russia and Syria have accused Israel of that strike. Meantime, President Trump sending a strong warning to the Assad Regime he tweeted this, "Many dead including women and children, in mindless chemical attack in Syria. Area of atrocity is in lockdown and encircled by Syrian Army, making it completely inaccessible to the outside world. President Putin, Russia, and Iran are responsible for backing animal Assad, big price to pay. Open area immediately for medical help and verification. Another humanitarian disaster for no reason whatsoever, sick."

Joining us now is -- this morning is former Commander of the USS Cole, Kirk Lippold. Commander, how do you -- what should the U.S. do to respond? And I should point out that we used that phrase red line that was famously a phrase used by President Obama back in 2010. Assad and Syria crossed that red line and we didn't do anything or we didn't attack. What should we do now?

COMMANDER KIRK S. LIPPOLD (RET), FORMER USS COLE COMMANDER: Good morning Dagen. I think the first thing we need to do is verify through intelligence channels that in fact took place who carried it out, where it was launched from, what was used to do it?

And then at that point, we take a step back, put together the military forces, and then decide whether we're going to react in a manner that is going to take away that capability not like we did last time with the Tomahawk missiles. But this time, on a more permanent basis and with the backing of the Security Council hopefully at the U.N.

MCDOWELL: Well Commander, you brought that up, so there was one -- it was a sarin gas attack last year, a one-time strike by the United States on a Syrian airbase. Why haven't we done more since then? There was a chlorine gas attack this past January which was the State Department and Rex Tillerson, then the Secretary of State basically attacked in a statement. But why haven't we done more to maybe take out all of Assad's air force, the entire air force?

LIPPOLD: Well, I think Dagen you have to look at it, what is going to be our engagement? What is the end state we want to have there? Assad is going to continue to exist as the president of Syria because the Russians are backing him, they now have the Iranians that are also providing technical knowledge and an ability to also establish their own basis there which Israel is not going to tolerate, which probably drove the attack into the T4 or Tiyas Airbase last night.

But we have to take a look and say, "OK, do we want to be the world's leader in this case where a low level attacks have occurred using chemical weapons?" This was absolutely a much larger scale one, it shows that they're taking out one of the last strongholds of the Syrians rebels. At this point, we need to say, "No, you either go for it conventionally or we will take out that capability." And if it does mean that we take out the Syrian air force, then we better be prepared for a little bit longer investment in time being in Syria with our forces despite what the president has said.

MURPHY: Commander, it's Mike Murphy. I love your opinion on the timing of this of attack because do you think it has to do with the fact that President Trump is fighting on many different fronts? We have North Korea, we have the issues here in the U.S., Russia. You think Syria and Putin got together and said, "Maybe this is a good time to test the president's medal?"

LIPPOLD: I don't think it was timing for that. I think that the president is going to react to it and how he reacts. I think once again, internationally bent will drive the decision-making process for the U.S. government as it always should especially where military force is involved.

I don't think this is going to be a tail-wagging, dog-type scenario, I think in fact we need to look at it and say what are our national security interest there? What is the end state we want to achieve? And if taking out the Syrian air force to send a signal to do that turns out to be the best option for us, then we execute it efficiently, ruthlessly, and with overwhelming force.

MCDOWELL: Brian, and I'll let you get in here but the timing, it does beg the question of this attack comes at -- right after President Trump says that we can't wait to get out of Syria, that we -- that -- but, again, he focus on ISIS and we see the threat to the Syrian people and children in the Assad Regime.

BRENBERG: Yes, absolutely. And the other timing issue that I'd like to ask you about Commander is you have the entrance this week now of John Bolton into the National Security Advisor role, that has to change things a little bit.

He's been critical of these one-off strikes, do we see the tide shift to a more permanent comprehensive approach here with Ambassador Bolton moving into that role?

LIPPOLD: Professor, that's a great question. And I think what you're going to see is Ambassador Bolton is now the National Security Advisor, not the executer but the advisor is going to say we need a much more comprehensive plan. We need a long range view. We need goals that we want to achieve for our national security objectives.

And he is going to take a more holistic approach into the execution of national security policy across the board. So I think that you're going to see a little bit more robust policy, I think you will see one with more defined objectives in there, and I think you will see one that will be executed in fairly short order because he is a decisive individual and he's going to recommend that to the president who obviously brought him in because he was a little frustrated that he was being held back in some of the execution of our policies.

MCDOWELL: The president did tweet because I mentioned the red line at the beginning, "If President Obama had crossed his stated red line in the sand, the Syrian disaster would have ended a long -- long ago. Animal Assad would have been history."

Maria spoke with House Homeland Security Committee Chairman, Michael McCaul yesterday and he agrees with the president. Listen to this Commander.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL MCCAUL (R-TX) HOUSE HOMELAND SECURITY COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: There has to be a consequence to this. And I think the president's absolutely right is that President Obama drew the red line, the red line was crossed, he did nothing.

And then he negotiate through John Kerry the settlement, this weapons convention. I remember John Kerry saying, "We took all their chemical weapons away." Obviously not. They still have this. And I also blame Russia and Iran, I think they're complicit with this as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Commander, I want to get your response to that. But as I mentioned earlier, we had that one-time airstrike last April but since then, there has been a chlorine gas attack that killed 20, mostly children, that happened in January, there was a statement from the State Department then but no enforcement. And Assad certainly knows that he would pay no price and now this, final thought.

LIPPOLD: I think you're absolutely right. There has to be consequences for this action. While there was a red line drawn and unfortunately we did not react to the red line when Syria crossed it. We did in fact have one positive development and that was getting rid of the vast majority of chemical weapons in there.

Had we attacked immediately, I doubt we would have ever gotten to that point with an agreement working with the Russians to make that happen. That is a positive thing to look at it. But nonetheless, if you draw a line as a state actor especially the United States, you have to hold it, enforce it, and do not waiver on it. And in doing that, it embolden people, the one-off strike, that's clearly going to be a test now whether we react to this in a manner that is much stronger, much more overwhelming and sends a signal, we will not tolerate this.

By the same token, going to Russia and Iran and saying, you're complicit in this, you have contributed to it, you have created the conditions that allowed it to happen, you must not do that anymore and there will be consequences and if your folks happen to be in the wrong place at the wrong time, that is not our responsibility, it's your decision to put them there.

MCDOWELL: Kirk, thank you so much. Kirk Lippold. Commander, be well. Thank you for being here.

LIPPOLD: Thank you Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Breaking news, President Trump just tweeting, "When a car is sent to the United States from China, there is a tariff to be paid of 2.12 percent. When a car is sent to China from the United States, there is a tariff to be paid of 25 percent. Does that sound like free or fair trade. No, it sounds like stupid trade going on for years."

Coming up, on the hot seat, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is in Washington today ahead of two intense days of questioning on Capitol Hill. This comes as the company had set to alert millions of users if their data was shared.

And tired of being patient? Congress Trey Gowdy calling out the Justice Department over the investigation into alleged FISA abuses.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: New week, new energy for Wall Street, DOW Futures right now are showing gains across the board, 167 point gain on the DOW Futures right now after what was a bruising week. Again, cooler heads prevailing I suppose when it comes to trade war talk. We'll see what comes out of the administration in the coming days. We're also watching the beginning of earning season this week.

Meantime, at least six teenagers from New York severely injured after a charter bus crashed. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, that's right Dagen. The bus packed with high school students returning from a spring break trip to Europe hit an overpass on Long Island last night. The impact was so strong, it tore the roof off the bus. This happened on the southern state parkway which restricts travel by commercial vehicles. Police say the driver did not seem to be familiar with that restriction.

Well, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joining thousands at a vigil honoring the junior hockey team involved in a tragic bus accident on Friday. The team president speaking to the crowd packed into the humble Broncos Arena.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN GARINGER, HUMBOLDT BRONCOS PRESIDENT: We will find strength in one another. Today and for every day forward, we are all Humboldt Broncos and we will be forever Humboldt Broncos strong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Fifteen people are now dead after that team's bus collided with a tractor trailer. Among those killed were the team's head coach, the driver of the bus, and several players. While the community in Saskatchewan tries to cope, support has been overwhelming. A victims fund for the Broncos has already exceeded $4.5 million.

Well Deutsche Bank is replacing its CEO. John Cryan is out and Christian Sewing is taking over. Sewing is a 47-year-old executive who's worked for Deutsche Bank for nearly three decades. Germany's biggest bank has been struggling since the 2008 financial crisis. Analysts say the change could signal a potential merger with another European bank. Shares of Deutsche Bank much higher in the premarket, up over three and a half percent right now.

And then finally there's this, Anheuser-Busch unveiling a new flavor of beer, Bud Light Orange. It is a light lagger that is brewed usually actual peels from oranges. The company says that you will, "taste the citrusy goodness." Bud Light Orange available for a limited time for, yes, the summer. Shares of Anheuser-Busch are down about three percent so far this year.

Dagen, if you ever put an orange in a beer like an orange slice, makes sense.

MCDOWELL: What you do with a Hefeweizen, wheat beer.

CASONE: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: I have a question, is this a shandy?

BRENBERG: It sounds like it. I don't like any of these kinds of beer. It sounds like a shandy, so I'm negative on it.

MCDOWELL: Shandy is tip -- do you know shandies?

MURPHY: I don't know shandy but I know this is like Budweiser and Fanta mixed together, I don't like it.

MCDOWELL: That actually sounds delicious.

CARTER: I know, right?

MCDOWELL: People tweet us, I think a shandy is the -- defined by, it is like a juice or some fruit flavor or like soda in a beer. Like, again, the Leinenkugel's summer shandy is quite delicious on a hot day on the golf course.

BRENBERG: I think beer goes well with beer and nothing else. So I wouldn't put any of those stuff, no peels, no nothing.

CARTER: My guess is you're not the target audience. (INAUDIBLE)

BRENBERG: I don't think I am. I don't think I am.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, Novartis as closed at $8.7 billion deal for a gene therapy company in the Midwest. Details on how the acquisition could boost the Swiss pharma giant's cancer innovations.

And Black Panther sailing past Titanic into the history books, another record shattering weekend for the Marvel movie.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Markets looking to start the new week with some gains, 178 point gain on the DOW Futures right now as concerns over a trade war with China ease a little bit. White House officials helping camp down those fears on the Sunday shows yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: Just technically, we have taken no action. It's a long process, there's several months here, so far no tariffs and no action has been enacted.

STEPHEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: I don't expect there will be a trade war, it could be but I don't expect it at all.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: President Trump tweeting this morning, " When a car is sent to the United States from China, there is a tariff to be paid of 2.12 percent. When a car is sent to China from the United States, there is a tariff to be paid of 25 percent. Does that sound like free or fair trade. No, it sounds like stupid trade going on for years."

Joining me now is Investmark Advisory Group Principal, Michael Lee. Mike, what's going to keep these trade concerns in the background for investors, the start of earnings potentially?

MICHAEL LEE, INVESTMARK ADVISORY GROUP PRINCIPAL: I think this is going to be one of the best earning seasons we've ever had, right? Not only from the actually result but we got to remember that earnings are a forward- looking tool and that's what matters -- I'm sorry, stocks are forward- looking tool.

So what earnings are going to look like for the rest of the year and then going out to 2019 when we start talking about 2019, I think a lot of people are going to sit back and say, "Well you know what, stocks are actually really cheap, they're not expensive." We're looking at one of the kind of the greatest growth periods we're going to see in our lifetimes, so.

MCDOWELL: But what if we do get into a back and forth, a tit-for-tat with China. Again, you heard from Larry Kudlow and Secretary of the Treasury, Steve MNuchin, they're trying to like wipe away some of the fears.

Like, "Oh, this might not happen." But, again, I just wish some of those guys would call people I grew up with, hog farmers, and people who grow soybeans that that impacts the real American economy, that's what the market is reflecting that the economy might not be growing as fast and earnings might not be growing as fast. And it's Boeing and Caterpillar last week.

LEE: So a couple of things, right? If you run a small business and your cost are going to go up 20 or 25 or 30 percent based on some tariff like this, this could be terrifying for you. However, on a larger scale, what can China really do to us if that they're not already doing?

What, are they going to steal our intellectual property? I mean, the trade imbalance from China or trade deficit, we're annualizing at just under $400 billion a share, OK? That is a much larger portion of their GDP than the $150 billion to $170 billion that we export to them every year. Again, problems for people whose (INAUDIBLE) cost are going to go up.

Our economy as a whole can withstand a trade war much easier than they can. The standard of living in China is no one near as high as they make it out to be. So if China were to -- if China gets into a trade war with us, chances are they'll go into recession. If they go into recession, there's a good probability of a popular uprising. So that could -- the only way that the Chinese government could go out of power is by a recession.

So the government props up their economy, it's held together with duct tape and elbow grease. So it's -- look, I -- it's -- I'm saying this but people much smarter than me and much more powerful than me know this. So what we're seeing is a lot of posturing. So I don't -- any selloff because of trade war fears I think is a good buying opportunity.

MURPHY: Totally agree completely on that because I think what you're seeing in the market though is you get these headlines and you're getting this big whip sauce back and forth and I think that's fine for the professional traders. But for the people at home, they could really get hurt in trading this type of market.

I believe a lot of those whip sauce have to do with computerize trading, with the algorithm of trading. So they're pulling headlines and then you're seeing these big drops in the market or these big rallies in the market. And I think it's important for -- and I love your take on that, a huge portion of the volume out there in a day-to-day basis is computerized. So individual people at home can really get hurt trying to get in front of that.

LEE: I would say for people over the last couple of years of markets is too high, the market is too high. Well you know what, every time you see an ugly tweet or an ugly headline or Stormy Daniels or something, the market's going to selloff. Here's your opportunity to take some of that cash and buy some stocks.

MCDOWELL: The market, do I have hope it doesn't selloff on Stormy Daniels. But go ahead. I hope investors are smarter than that or the computer.

LEE: If you start drilling down and looking at the U.S. economy, a durable goods are up year-over-year, almost nine percent, that's the highest number since the early 2000. You look at manufacturing is doing the best since the early 2000s.

Non-ISM manufacturing is the highest level it's been in 20 years. You look at the job market, weekly javas claims have been below 300,000 for almost three years. Longest period in almost the history of the entire United States.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, earnings. Earnings season starts this week, J.P. Morgan kind of the big one coming out on Friday, what do you expect overall growth for the quarter 17 percent but J.P. Morgan expected to put up even better numbers (INAUDIBLE).

LEE: You know, what I'm going to be looking for is the forward guidance. What's dragged a lot of these banks back particularly is sales of trading. And now with the return of volatility, I think sales and trading has kind of been the (INAUDIBLE) as you look at all the different business units in all these banks.

It's going to start to get better and then with the banks, as rates are going higher, their net interest margins are going to expand. As net interest margins are going to expand, banks are going to make a lot more money in their wallets. And let's face it, 10 years ago when the banks were in their hay days they were trading shops, now they get back to being traditional lenders.

So when you were -- when you have a $1 trillion of loans out there, you make an extra 25 basis points on each loan, it's a lot of money, right? So -- I mean, the forward guidance is what I'm looking at and as the conversation switches from 2018 earnings to 2019 earnings I think people are going to say, "Wow, stocks are really, really cheap. Something's going on here, like the market's going much higher."

MCDOWELL: Michael Lee, thank you sir. Good to see you. Come back soon.

LEE: Thanks very much guys. Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, facing the music, Facebook CEO is set to meet with lawmakers in Washington today as he prepares to face a grilling before the Senate and then the House tomorrow and Wednesday. Hear from a whistleblower about the data reveal, the reckless handling of your personal information, let's call it that.

And Dr. Seuss has bumped into a new beat, the Migos remix, "There's a Wocket in My Pocket," you've got to hear to believe.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern. Easing concerns over a trade war, sparking a rally on Wall Street, Futures are showing gains across the board, 176-point gain on the Dow Futures, this after that sharp selloff on Friday.

The major market gauges all down more than two percent, again, a little bit of a disappointing job's number. The chief of the feds speaking and then trade war worries. In Europe, the market is hovering near the flat line this morning. We still have gains across the board in England, France and Germany, and in Asia overnight, stocks moving up from Shanghai to the KOSPI in South Korea.

Facebook, under fire, CEO Mark Zuckerberg, gearing up for his trip to Capitol Hill, where he will be grilled over the company's privacy practices. What to expect from the congressional hearings, ahead. Calling for action, House Oversight Committee Chairman, Trey Gowdy, says the justice department is stonewalling when it comes to handing over documents tied to the FISA and Hillary Clinton investigations. Here's what he told Maria on Sunday Morning Futures.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. TREY GOWDY (R-SC), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE: I want to be able to support the FBI and the DOJ, but the world's premier law- enforcement agency can't seem to operate a damn copying machine. That is inexplicable.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We have the very latest, a strong message for Iran, hackers attacking the country's network, leaving an image of the American flag. Warning, don't mess with our elections. A little bit of a merger Monday on Wall Street, Novartis is getting big on gene therapy with its latest acquisition.

And a not so quite start for the box office for A Quiet Place, the horror film soaring passed expectations. We have the full box office recap, ahead, plus, a whole new tune for Dr. Seuss' Wocket in my Pocket, a rap of the childhood classic, going viral.

To our top story this half hour, the clock, ticking on the DOJ, Attorney General Jeff Sessions and FBI Director Christopher Wray, now, asking Federal Prosecutor John Lausch to help speed up the response to GOP demands for documents related to the surveillance of former Trump Campaign Advisor, Carter Page. The firing of Andrew McCabe from the FBI and the investigation into Hillary Clinton's private e-mail server, the request, coming after President Trump took to Twitter this weekend, to slam the DOJ and FBI, writing, what does the Department of Justice and FBI have to hide?

Why aren't they giving the strongly requested documents, unredacted, to the House Judiciary Committee? Stalling, but for what reason? Not looking good. House Oversight Committee Chairman Trey Gowdy who has been leading the charge, sounded off, yesterday, on Sunday Morning Futures.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOWDY: I have not seen a clean version and I need to know what's behind those black lines because it's really important how this investigation began, when it began and what is the -- what is the weight, what is the credibility of the evidence upon which this investigation was launched? And the Department of Justice and the FBI have that document, they won't let us see the clean version, and I'm struggling to understand why.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This all comes as the DOJ promises to turn over an additional 3600 pages from the FBI today, to the House panel. Joining us now is Editor-in-Chief of Axios, Nick Johnston, Nick, your reaction to these new developments and where do we go from here?

NICHOLAS JOHNSTON, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, AXIOS: Yes, I think it's really important to hear the frustration in Chairman Gowdy's voice what he told Maria, sort of, how angry he was about how they can't find the copy machine that could underscores the tension here and how these are Republicans on the Hill are still very much focused on getting this kind of information.

And this is a Republican justice department that they'd say hasn't been doing it fast enough, even the President, as you showed, has been tweeting that the document turnover hasn't happened fast enough. I think, the appointment of this new attorney, to facilitate that, will probably help. It might make some of these folks on the Hill, a little happier, but this is still a very important investigatory focus for them, and they're not going to give up until they get what they want.

MCDOWELL: Nick, how do the midterm elections factor into this, though, because even though we have a Republican president in the White House, and Republican leading the justice department as the Attorney General, you look at Trey Gowdy and the other heads, Devin Nunes, head of the House Intelligence Committee, really there, the time window is closing on them just, potentially, if the Democrats retake the House. How critical is that timing?

JOHNSTON: I think it's a really great point. A lot of what Republicans want to accomplish in the House today is set under the guise of what will happen in the midterms and Republicans are coming from a -- from a place of the underdogs, I think, in this election, and if they lose the gavels on these committees, these investigations go away. So I think, certainly, in the coming months, if they don't get the documents, this pressure will only increase because they know they have to finish this by the end of the year.

CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: No, Nick, I think, it's a really interesting conversation that's been have about whether or not the Republican hold strategy, is to undermine -- is undermine the DOJ and say that there's not going to be trust in these institutions that are so important. Do you think that's fair for them to criticize or do you think the Republicans have a fair, you know, have a real beef here?

JOHNSTON: Right. This is a really interesting point. We've done some pulling on this, in fact, quickly, after the President went after the (INAUDIBLE) investigation recently, and we saw favorability for the FBI plunge among Republicans which is something we haven't seen, essentially, ever, as long as the department had existed.

I think it's a very, sort of, dicey area to be, sort of, attacking these law enforcement agencies the way they ever remember, you know, these are members of congress. They have clear investigatory ability to get these kinds of documents, and you know what? If they subpoena them, you need to provide them.

MCDOWELL: I want to move on to Facebook (INAUDIBLE) send out notifications today to millions of affected users in this data mining scandal. This comes as congressional aides are confirming that CEO Mark Zuckerberg will hold meetings today on Capitol Hill, with several lawmakers ahead of this week's hearings. Take a listen to Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg and Senate Judiciary Committee, John Kennedy, both suggesting that things are about to change at the tech giant.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, COO, FACEBOOK: Mark's happy to go to congress because Mark wants to answer every question people have about the service we office. We weren't focused enough and being proactive enough and Mark is happy to say here's what we weren't doing and here's what we are doing now.

REP. JOHN KENNEDY (R-LA), MEMBER, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: I don't want to hurt Facebook. I don't want to regulate them half to death. But, we have a problem.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Yes, our problem. Meantime, a whistleblower, now warning that the millions of affected users' data could be stored in Russia, I think that it's going to be Mark Zuckerberg's performance because he's sending out Sheryl Sandberg in his stead, who clearly loves to tell women how to lean in, in this country, but when -- this is a very serious issue and I would argue that her performance, last week, in terms of giving interviews, was a little light, in terms of really grappling with the seriousness of it.

I point to a New York Post, the front page -- the front page of the post, on Saturday, we own you, pay us for your privacy, shocking, and then Mark Zuckerberg, famously, in 2010, was sweating like Richard Nixon, breaking out on a flop sweat-like none other. Again, it's just going to be Zuckerberg sitting there, whether the stocks sold off or not.

JOHNSTON: Right. This is a -- this is the main event here. All the pre- interviews last week with Sheryl Sandberg (INAUDIBLE) were opening acts. The real thing here, Zuckerberg is on the Hill -- on the Hill, today, preparing, tomorrow, 2:30, must-see TV. Zuckerberg, appearing before this committee, this is something he's never done before in this kind of hearing, and he doesn't have any natural allies on his committee. These senators on both sides of the aisle are gunning for big tech. And so, this hearing is a start of that.

MCDOWELL: Are they really gunning for big tech, though, Nick? I mean, big tech is -- you know, when you talk about Silicon Valley and technology, it is one of the most divided areas, politically, that all of the CEOs have historically been big givers to Democratic candidates. Their policies lean very far left. There's really not room, you saw with the firing of that Google employee, not room for conservative thought or speech. And so, I just wonder what kind of treatments he gets.

JOHNSTON: I would separate it from that. What this is, is the final -- the first time congress is really going to ask the questions, are these tech companies too big and if they know so much about their users and have they done a good job of explaining to users how much they know. For a lot of members of the Hill, this is a mystery to them. There are no natural allies for Facebook or rather these big technology companies. I want to look to see any friendly questions for Mark, tomorrow, when he's in congress.

MCDOWELL: We've known, Mike Murphy, that this was going on for years, in terms of Facebook not protecting user information, whether you're talking about RapLeaf or Cloud and their way of enforcement was to call up the company telling them, don't do that anymore.

MICHAEL MURPHY, FOUNDER, ROSECLIFF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And it's only because this was somehow related to the Trump campaign that people are now furious and up in arms.

MURPHY: I think what Mark Zuckerberg's going to talk about a lot, this week, is what Facebook used to do, and what they are doing now, to talk about how the company has shifted, how they're protecting your data, but you'll know when go on there, Dagen. You're giving up a lot of your information. If you don't want to give that up, you shouldn't be on Facebook. They may have a responsibility to not sell it but they -- once you're on there, that data is there, and they own it, they do, as the cover said.

BRENBERG,: Do they know what they're doing now? That's -- you said they're going to talk about what they're doing. Now, I think a lot of people look at this and say, do they know what they're doing now or are they really just, like, we actually have no idea what's going on and every single day now, we're seeing new revelations of more, you know, inappropriate data sharing, customers having their data used in ways that they didn't know. I don't think Facebook has a good handle on where they are.

MURPHY: I think this is years ago this is years ago when -- I think it was 2014, the Cambridge Analytica information ended up being given to the improper parties. So, I think, Facebook today, 2018, versus four years ago, is a vastly different company, it has run differently. So, I think that's what they want to underline, is how they are now doing their best to potentially protect their data the best possible.

BRENBERG: I think they're going to have you lift, kind of, show that, I really do. I don't think people think it's changed that much.

MCDOWELL: They knew that data, back in 2015, had been improperly accessed and they basically said, don't, you know, do away. Get rid of it, Nick, final word, real quick.

JOHNSTON: I think the key thing here is a lot of people who are, sort of, really into this issue know about how much Facebook has. This is the first time members of congress will learn how big that is.

MCDOWELL: And let's hope that they bone up in advance of this, because we know how this can go, if they're really not sure of the questions they are asking. But, again, WilmerHale, the law firm given Mark Zuckerberg some prep in advance to that, the Wall Street Journal reported that today. Nick, thank you so much.

JOHNSTON: Always.

MCDOWELL: Great to see you, Nick Johnston of Axios.

JOHNSTON: Thanks.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, hackers hit Iran with the cryptic warning, including an image of the American Flag and a message, don't mess with our elections, details on that. An intergalactic debut, the new Solo, a Star Wars story trailer, finally out. We'll give you a peek.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Iran hit hard by a global cyberattack with a strong message. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, they did, Dagen. Hackers targeting networks on a number of countries including data centers in Iran. The hackers let the image of an American flag on screen, saying "don't mess with our elections". The Iranian government says, about 3500 -- across that country.

Well, a deal in the pharmaceutical industry to tell you about -- Novartis is buying the AveXis, the price tag, nearly $9 billion. The deal is a bet that at least one promising drug that AveXis is developing to treat spinal muscular atrophy will turn into a blockbuster drug. Shares of Novartis are higher in the premarket, up more than one and quarter percent; AveXis shares are sharply higher as well.

Well, this is interesting -- one rapper on YouTube, drew some inspiration from a kind of unusual place while rhyming to the tune of Migos song "Walk it, Talk it".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Some of them are dreaming like that (INAUDIBLE), but that (INAUDIBLE) when the bottle some are fairly some are not. Let them (INAUDIBLE) on the table when they get under the chair. But that bump on the sofa when I wish she wasn't there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: So, you get it when you start watching it, right? This went viral. And instead of "Walk it, Talk it", the YouTuber was rapper "walk it in my pocket" but in the Migos style of rapping. It racks up over a million views on YouTube. So, I guess -- I don't know what's next, cat in the hat? Cinderella? Green eggs and ham? Bring it on!

MURPHY: I've had enough for 15 years.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: No, you've been doing -- did you rap Dr. Seuss, Theodore Geisel, for your kids?

MURPHY: For 15 years, straight, for every one of mine.

MCDOWELL: Give me some green eggs and ham. I want to hear it now.

MURPHY: It's on my YouTube channel.

MCDOWELL: You give us some green eggs and ham?

MURPHY: No.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE) like, when we first heard about this, is this the children that, you know -- like, no, this is a wrapper.

MURPHY: Wrapper, Migos. Yes!

CARTER: You're all in.

BRENBERG: This is how dads keep their kids engaged. I mean, you're reading your book, you've got do something like that. You can't just read the book; you got to rap, you got to sing it.

CARTER: You rap your books?

BRENBERG: I do something, maybe like an accent. You know, you got to do something to make it, and your kids are just to get bored and whatever. It's a hard job, right?

MURPHY: This is iconic, and you kind of bring it to 2018, I think it needs a little hip-hop in there, totally.

MCDOWELL: We will not eat green eggs and ham?

MURPHY: There you go.

MCDOWELL: Give me the next one.

MURPHY: Sam, I am.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Coming up, "A Quiet Place" making a big noise. The thriller is a big win by actors turned director, Emily Blunt and John Krisinski. A box office recap, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Another record-breaking weekend at the box office. Lauren Simonetti has more details.

SIMONETTI: All right. Good morning, happy Monday. This is the time we talk about what was a hit over the weekend. So, let's give you the list. In first place, "A Quiet Place". A surprise $50 million opening for this horror film -- and we're going to talk more about it in a second; let's get through the rest of the list. Steven Spielberg's "Ready Player One", 25 million in the second week; "Blockers", 21 million; "Black Panther", took the fourth-place spot, only $8 million this weekend but if you look at what "Black Panther" has done to date, it has unseated "Titanic". So, if you look at total domestic growth, for this movie, $665 million. There it is, number three of all time. "The Force Awakens", number one; "Avatar", number two; and "Titanic", now number four.

Let's go back to "A Quiet Place". This is a movie that cost $17 million to make; $50 million in its opening weekend. So, it was written and directed by -- of office fame, John Krisinki and his wife Emily Blunt starred, but it's basically a "A Quiet Place" -- there's no dialogue in the movie, and it's a huge win for Paramount who needed a big hit after about two years of not having a hit. So, there you have it. We're liking horror at the box office. And they got the trailer for the new "Star Wars".

MCDOWELL: What do you got, Lauren? Show me.

SIMONETTI: Let's watch it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I heard about a job. A big shot gangster putting together a crew.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm a driver. I'm a flyer.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've waited a long time for a shot like this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What is he saying? No, what do you know?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You got a line on a ship?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: It hit theaters on the 25th of May. See, it's the young Han Solo. Do we want to see the --

BRENBERG: That's a lot of -- it's a lot of pressure to play the young Han Solo. He's such a great character. I think the chances of failing are really high here. I'm excited to see. It looks good in the trailer, but that's a tough role, right?

SIMONETTI: Agreed.

CARTER: I like the original "Star Wars", I'm not into it.

SIMONETTI: It's disconnected. It's another one of the -- I think this one takes place before the first one, in 1977.

MURHPY: That tease makes -- while they're getting 600 and 700 million at the box office, you can count and see more and more "Star Wars" prequel, sequels, whatever.

BRENBERG: You're going to see Han Solo as a 5-year-old at some point --

MURPHY: Yes --

BRENBERG: I'm not looking forward to that one.

CARTER: If I like something or not, it's pretty much a not a good indicator about whether or not it's going to perform well.

MCDOWELL: It's called monetizing the franchise, just like Disney bought it in the first place. And so, they've done a pretty good job.

SIMONETTI: It's almost like one a year, right? There's been like one "Star Wars".

BRENBERG: One from the regular series, one of the, kind of the, in between --

SIMONETTI: In between.

BRENBERG: Yes, every single year for the next 20 years, at least, right?

SIMONETTI: They get some new characters in this one. And we'll see what the appetite is for a young Han Solo.

MCDOWELL: You only need to know one word -- Chewbacca.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: Makes an appearance in one of trailers.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

SIMONETTI: And his age?

MCDOWELL: 190 -- in the film.

MURHPY: (INAUDIBLE) like a long time.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: They sure do.

CARTER: I hope that's a good indicator. My dog just looks like him.

SIMONETTI: I wish our dogs are the same. Kevin -- someone who looks like him.

MCDOWELL: Her dog is named Kevin, just to clear that up. She has two dogs. Lauren, thank you so much. And Lauren is having a baby. Can you reveal the name while we're staying here?

SIMONETTI: I don't know if it's a boy or a girl. And we're not sharing names only because I don't care what anybody has to say about them anymore. Not a name. Not talking anymore suggestion,

BRENBERG: You don't need it, but yes, forget about.

SIMONETTI: Don't want your input. Thank you very much. But you can still guess if it's boy or girl.

MCDOWELL: We can segue from Han Solo to Lauren and her impending delivery. Still ahead, gas prices said to hit their higher level in years this summer. We have all the details for you, next on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th, your top stories at 7:30 a.m. Eastern. Crisis in Syria; yet another suspected chemical weapon attacked, leaving dozens dead. The international community on high alert. As the world waits for U.S. response, President Trump warning of a big price to pay. Despite the tensions, stocks reporting to a higher open, bouncing back 160-point on the Dow Futures right now after concerns over a trade war with China, seem to ease a bit -- you see the gains there.

END

urn:contentItem:5S2K-7SC1-JB20-G46Y-00000-00Global Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's Hearings2018-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTLee Carter, Mike Murphy, Brian Brenberg, Kirk Lippold, Michael Lee, Nicholas JohnstonNEWSFinancial040901cb.231Global Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's HearingsMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Peter Dickson, we appreciate you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And we appreciate you watching FBN:am this morning. We always appreciate seeing Dagen McDowell on a Monday. Good morning Dagen.

SIMONETTI: Hey Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK, ANCHOR: Ladies, I'll see you later. Good morning, great to see you as always. And great to see all of you. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Crisis in Syria, yet another suspected chemical weapons attack leaving dozens dead, the international community on high alert. As the world waits for a U.S. response, President Trump warning of a big price to pay.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM BOSSERT, WHITE HOUSE HOMELAND SECURITY ADVISOR: I wouldn't take anything off the table, these are horrible photos, we're looking into the attack at this point. I think the president's got a point that's been very clear and I'm going to reiterate that point. The pendulum has swung in the wrong direction for too long and the United States of America has been taken advantage of in their responsibility to provide security for the entire world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Despite the tension, stocks are pointing to a bounce back as concerns over a trade war with China eased a little bit, maybe it was the Sunday morning talk show's rhetoric being thrown out by the White House.

Futures are showing this, 172 point gain on the DOW Futures right now, it's losing week for the Blue Chips last week. This comes after that massive selloff on Friday with the DOW, Nasdaq, and S&P all falling more than two percent.

In Europe, you have some buying to report, the England, France, and Germany, we have gains across the board. In Asia overnight, stocks also moving higher. The biggest winner there, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Zuckerberg taking the Hill, Facebook CEO set to meet with lawmakers in Washington today as he prepares to face a grilling before the Senate tomorrow. The latest as the Cambridge Analytica whistleblower says more people's data could have been exposed.

And a change at the top, Deutsche Bank naming a new CEO, the details as shares jumped on the news.

And terrifying moments on a New York highway, a tour bus slamming into an overpass leaving six people seriously injured, more on their condition ahead.

And the DOJ stonewalling, why Congress Trey Gowdy is calling out the Justice Department over the investigation into alleged FISA abuses.

And orange going to love this, Bud Light going citrus for the summer, the new flavor hitting store shelves coming up. I think that's called a summer shandy.

All of that and so much more this morning, Pollster Maslansky and Partners President, Lee Carter. Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner, Mike Murphy. And the King's College Business and Economics Professor, Brian Brenberg.

I start with you, markets this week, we get bank earnings, worries about a trade war but, again, now geopolitical concerns that the focusing shifted to that.

BRIAN BRENBERG, KING'S COLLEGE AND BUSINESS ECONOMICS PROFESSOR: Yes. Yes, it has. Although it's interesting to watch these back and forth with the trade wars. You get some rhetoric out of the White House, we -- the talk on Thursday night, Friday morning stocks (INAUDIBLE) over the weekend, everybody's out there talking about how this is not a big deal, we don't want a trade war, you come back Monday morning, stocks up again.

We're seeing this pattern repeat again and again. It seems to take a day or two for markets to digest that you've got rhetoric and you've got reality on trade and the reality probably isn't going to be as bad or as harsh as a rhetoric sounds.

MCDOWELL: Mike, what are you watching this week?

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO, MANAGING PARTNER: Absolutely. So watching the volatility in the market, that's really spurn -- spurred by this trade war talk. And I think just a few months ago we were talking about there's no volatility in the market.

We haven't had a one percent move in so many months. Well now you're getting two percent move almost on a daily basis. I think the main thing for investors to do here is to try to block out the headlines and stick with their long-term plans. So we're going to get the down 500s, the bounces above 200s. Overall, there's not going to be a major trade war with China in my opinion, it will back to focus on the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: I think some of the White House officials needs some messaging help because you've got Secretary MNuchin on Friday talking about the potential of a trade war and then trying to walk back those comments yesterday saying, "I don't expect it at all in terms of a trade war." Don't have your Treasury Secretary utter the words trade war ever.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND MASLANSKY & PARTNERS PRESIDENT: That would be a good first step. But I think it's fascinating to see how the markets are reacting so much to the rhetoric rather than just the policy.

It's unbelievable, a tweet, one announcement can send the markets in a tailspin. And what's happened traditionally is that we've looked at the experts and say, "What are we really supposed to be looking at?" One tweet, one message, one interview can totally change the course of the markets and we're seeing that this week and certainly the White House rhetoric tone way back saying this has always been -- there's nothing new here, nothing's developed here, not a trade war and look, things are softening again.

MCDOWELL: And I'm looking forward to Mark Zuckerberg on Capitol Hill. Again, Facebook will reveal today to Facebook users whose data was accessed by Cambridge Analytica, it's about 70 million people. Estimates are in the United States alone.

And watch Mark Zuckerberg because back in 2010, he broke out into a Nixonian flop sweat when Walt Mossberg was interviewing him. And I mean sweat was dripping off of his face.

CARTER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So if you do that on Capitol Hill, watch your stock tank.

BRENBERG: His appearances are always so staged managed. This one absolutely cannot be. And so it's going to be interesting to see what he does under that kind of pressure.

MCDOWELL: We're trying to get the video but he had sweat dripping off his nose and his chin. I'm not kidding. It's --

CARTER: This is not where he's comfortable.

MURPHY: Yes. That was -- that was back in the days of the hoodie sweatshirt.

MCDOWELL: Yes. So you're saying he was hot.

MURPHY: So he's come a long way.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE) t-shirt.

MCDOWELL: He was -- he was just hot. OK. We're going to talk about that all morning. Also coming up, New York Congressman Chris Collins, South Dakota Senator Mike Rounds. Host of Michelle Malkin Investigates on CRTV.com, Michelle Malkin. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Legendary Soulman, my friend, Sam Moore. You don't want to miss any of them.

Our top story this morning, crossing the red line, the world awaiting the U.S. response to a suspected chemical weapons attack in Syria that killed dozens of citizens. Yesterday, warplanes bombing an airbase near the City of Homs. Russia and Syria have accused Israel of that strike. Meantime, President Trump sending a strong warning to the Assad Regime he tweeted this, "Many dead including women and children, in mindless chemical attack in Syria. Area of atrocity is in lockdown and encircled by Syrian Army, making it completely inaccessible to the outside world. President Putin, Russia, and Iran are responsible for backing animal Assad, big price to pay. Open area immediately for medical help and verification. Another humanitarian disaster for no reason whatsoever, sick."

Joining us now is -- this morning is former Commander of the USS Cole, Kirk Lippold. Commander, how do you -- what should the U.S. do to respond? And I should point out that we used that phrase red line that was famously a phrase used by President Obama back in 2010. Assad and Syria crossed that red line and we didn't do anything or we didn't attack. What should we do now?

COMMANDER KIRK S. LIPPOLD (RET), FORMER USS COLE COMMANDER: Good morning Dagen. I think the first thing we need to do is verify through intelligence channels that in fact took place who carried it out, where it was launched from, what was used to do it?

And then at that point, we take a step back, put together the military forces, and then decide whether we're going to react in a manner that is going to take away that capability not like we did last time with the Tomahawk missiles. But this time, on a more permanent basis and with the backing of the Security Council hopefully at the U.N.

MCDOWELL: Well Commander, you brought that up, so there was one -- it was a sarin gas attack last year, a one-time strike by the United States on a Syrian airbase. Why haven't we done more since then? There was a chlorine gas attack this past January which was the State Department and Rex Tillerson, then the Secretary of State basically attacked in a statement. But why haven't we done more to maybe take out all of Assad's air force, the entire air force?

LIPPOLD: Well, I think Dagen you have to look at it, what is going to be our engagement? What is the end state we want to have there? Assad is going to continue to exist as the president of Syria because the Russians are backing him, they now have the Iranians that are also providing technical knowledge and an ability to also establish their own basis there which Israel is not going to tolerate, which probably drove the attack into the T4 or Tiyas Airbase last night.

But we have to take a look and say, "OK, do we want to be the world's leader in this case where a low level attacks have occurred using chemical weapons?" This was absolutely a much larger scale one, it shows that they're taking out one of the last strongholds of the Syrians rebels. At this point, we need to say, "No, you either go for it conventionally or we will take out that capability." And if it does mean that we take out the Syrian air force, then we better be prepared for a little bit longer investment in time being in Syria with our forces despite what the president has said.

MURPHY: Commander, it's Mike Murphy. I love your opinion on the timing of this of attack because do you think it has to do with the fact that President Trump is fighting on many different fronts? We have North Korea, we have the issues here in the U.S., Russia. You think Syria and Putin got together and said, "Maybe this is a good time to test the president's medal?"

LIPPOLD: I don't think it was timing for that. I think that the president is going to react to it and how he reacts. I think once again, internationally bent will drive the decision-making process for the U.S. government as it always should especially where military force is involved.

I don't think this is going to be a tail-wagging, dog-type scenario, I think in fact we need to look at it and say what are our national security interest there? What is the end state we want to achieve? And if taking out the Syrian air force to send a signal to do that turns out to be the best option for us, then we execute it efficiently, ruthlessly, and with overwhelming force.

MCDOWELL: Brian, and I'll let you get in here but the timing, it does beg the question of this attack comes at -- right after President Trump says that we can't wait to get out of Syria, that we -- that -- but, again, he focus on ISIS and we see the threat to the Syrian people and children in the Assad Regime.

BRENBERG: Yes, absolutely. And the other timing issue that I'd like to ask you about Commander is you have the entrance this week now of John Bolton into the National Security Advisor role, that has to change things a little bit.

He's been critical of these one-off strikes, do we see the tide shift to a more permanent comprehensive approach here with Ambassador Bolton moving into that role?

LIPPOLD: Professor, that's a great question. And I think what you're going to see is Ambassador Bolton is now the National Security Advisor, not the executer but the advisor is going to say we need a much more comprehensive plan. We need a long range view. We need goals that we want to achieve for our national security objectives.

And he is going to take a more holistic approach into the execution of national security policy across the board. So I think that you're going to see a little bit more robust policy, I think you will see one with more defined objectives in there, and I think you will see one that will be executed in fairly short order because he is a decisive individual and he's going to recommend that to the president who obviously brought him in because he was a little frustrated that he was being held back in some of the execution of our policies.

MCDOWELL: The president did tweet because I mentioned the red line at the beginning, "If President Obama had crossed his stated red line in the sand, the Syrian disaster would have ended a long -- long ago. Animal Assad would have been history."

Maria spoke with House Homeland Security Committee Chairman, Michael McCaul yesterday and he agrees with the president. Listen to this Commander.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL MCCAUL (R-TX) HOUSE HOMELAND SECURITY COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: There has to be a consequence to this. And I think the president's absolutely right is that President Obama drew the red line, the red line was crossed, he did nothing.

And then he negotiate through John Kerry the settlement, this weapons convention. I remember John Kerry saying, "We took all their chemical weapons away." Obviously not. They still have this. And I also blame Russia and Iran, I think they're complicit with this as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Commander, I want to get your response to that. But as I mentioned earlier, we had that one-time airstrike last April but since then, there has been a chlorine gas attack that killed 20, mostly children, that happened in January, there was a statement from the State Department then but no enforcement. And Assad certainly knows that he would pay no price and now this, final thought.

LIPPOLD: I think you're absolutely right. There has to be consequences for this action. While there was a red line drawn and unfortunately we did not react to the red line when Syria crossed it. We did in fact have one positive development and that was getting rid of the vast majority of chemical weapons in there.

Had we attacked immediately, I doubt we would have ever gotten to that point with an agreement working with the Russians to make that happen. That is a positive thing to look at it. But nonetheless, if you draw a line as a state actor especially the United States, you have to hold it, enforce it, and do not waiver on it. And in doing that, it embolden people, the one-off strike, that's clearly going to be a test now whether we react to this in a manner that is much stronger, much more overwhelming and sends a signal, we will not tolerate this.

By the same token, going to Russia and Iran and saying, you're complicit in this, you have contributed to it, you have created the conditions that allowed it to happen, you must not do that anymore and there will be consequences and if your folks happen to be in the wrong place at the wrong time, that is not our responsibility, it's your decision to put them there.

MCDOWELL: Kirk, thank you so much. Kirk Lippold. Commander, be well. Thank you for being here.

LIPPOLD: Thank you Dagen.

LEE: So a couple of things, right? If you run a small business and your cost are going to go up 20 or 25 or 30 percent based on some tariff like this, this could be terrifying for you. However, on a larger scale, what can China really do to us if that they're not already doing?

What, are they going to steal our intellectual property? I mean, the trade imbalance from China or trade deficit, we're annualizing at just under $400 billion a share, OK? That is a much larger portion of their GDP than the $150 billion to $170 billion that we export to them every year. Again, problems for people whose (INAUDIBLE) cost are going to go up.

Our economy as a whole can withstand a trade war much easier than they can. The standard of living in China is no one near as high as they make it out to be. So if China were to -- if China gets into a trade war with us, chances are they'll go into recession. If they go into recession, there's a good probability of a popular uprising. So that could -- the only way that the Chinese government could go out of power is by a recession.

So the government props up their economy, it's held together with duct tape and elbow grease. So it's -- look, I -- it's -- I'm saying this but people much smarter than me and much more powerful than me know this. So what we're seeing is a lot of posturing. So I don't -- any selloff because of trade war fears I think is a good buying opportunity.

MURPHY: Totally agree completely on that because I think what you're seeing in the market though is you get these headlines and you're getting this big whip sauce back and forth and I think that's fine for the professional traders. LEE: I would say for people over the last couple of years of markets is too high, the market is too high. Here's your opportunity to take some of that cash and buy some stocks.

MCDOWELL: The market, do I have hope it doesn't selloff on Stormy Daniels. But go ahead. I hope investors are smarter than that or the computer.

LEE: If you start drilling down and looking at the U.S. economy, a durable goods are up year-over-year, almost nine percent, that's the highest number since the early 2000. You look at manufacturing is doing the best since the early 2000s.

Non-ISM manufacturing is the highest level it's been in 20 years. You look at the job market, weekly javas claims have been below 300,000 for almost three years. Longest period in almost the history of the entire United States.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, earnings. Earnings season starts this week, J.P. Morgan kind of the big one coming out on Friday, what do you expect overall growth for the quarter 17 percent but J.P. Morgan expected to put up even better numbers (INAUDIBLE).

LEE: You know, what I'm going to be looking for is the forward guidance. What's dragged a lot of these banks back particularly is sales of trading. And now with the return of volatility, I think sales and trading has kind of been the (INAUDIBLE) as you look at all the different business units in all these banks.

It's going to start to get better and then with the banks, as rates are going higher, their net interest margins are going to expand. As net interest margins are going to expand, banks are going to make a lot more money in their wallets. And let's face it, 10 years ago when the banks were in their hay days they were trading shops, now they get back to being traditional lenders.

So when you were -- when you have a $1 trillion of loans out there, you make an extra 25 basis points on each loan, it's a lot of money, right? So -- I mean, the forward guidance is what I'm looking at and as the conversation switches from 2018 earnings to 2019 earnings I think people are going to say, "Wow, stocks are really, really cheap. Something's going on here, like the market's going much higher."

MCDOWELL: This all comes as the DOJ promises to turn over an additional 3600 pages from the FBI today, to the House panel. Joining us now is Editor-in-Chief of Axios, Nick Johnston, Nick, your reaction to these new developments and where do we go from here?

NICHOLAS JOHNSTON, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, AXIOS: Yes, I think it's really important to hear the frustration in Chairman Gowdy's voice what he told Maria, sort of, how angry he was about how they can't find the copy machine that could underscores the tension here and how these are Republicans on the Hill are still very much focused on getting this kind of information.

I think, the appointment of this new attorney, to facilitate that, will probably help. It might make some of these folks on the Hill, a little happier, but this is still a very important investigatory focus for them, and they're not going to give up until they get what they want.

MCDOWELL: Nick, how do the midterm elections factor into this, though, because even though we have a Republican president in the White House, and Republican leading the justice department as the Attorney General, you look at Trey Gowdy and the other heads, Devin Nunes, head of the House Intelligence Committee, really there, the time window is closing on them just, potentially, if the Democrats retake the House. JOHNSTON: I think it's a really great point. CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: No, Nick, I think, it's a really interesting conversation that's been have about whether or not the Republican hold strategy, is to undermine -- is undermine the DOJ and say that there's not going to be trust in these institutions that are so important. JOHNSTON: Right. This is a really interesting point. I think it's a very, sort of, dicey area to be, sort of, attacking these law enforcement agencies the way they ever remember, you know, these are members of congress. They have clear investigatory ability to get these kinds of documents, and you know what? If they subpoena them, you need to provide them.

JOHNSTON: Right. This is a -- this is the main event here. All the pre- interviews last week with Sheryl Sandberg (INAUDIBLE) were opening acts. The real thing here, Zuckerberg is on the Hill -- on the Hill, today, preparing, tomorrow, 2:30, must-see TV. Zuckerberg, appearing before this committee, this is something he's never done before in this kind of hearing, and he doesn't have any natural allies on his committee. MCDOWELL: We've known, Mike Murphy, that this was going on for years, in terms of Facebook not protecting user information, whether you're talking about RapLeaf or Cloud and their way of enforcement was to call up the company telling them, don't do that anymore.

MURPHY: I think what Mark Zuckerberg's going to talk about a lot, this week, is what Facebook used to do, and what they are doing now, to talk about how the company has shifted, how they're protecting your data, but you'll know when go on there, Dagen. BRENBERG,: Do they know what they're doing now? That's -- you said they're going to talk about what they're doing.
