MCDOWELL: Coming up, hackers hit Iran with the cryptic warning, including an image of the American Flag and a message, don't mess with our elections, details on that. An intergalactic debut, the new Solo, a Star Wars story trailer, finally out. We'll give you a peek.

MCDOWELL: Iran hit hard by a global cyberattack with a strong message. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, they did, Dagen. Hackers targeting networks on a number of countries including data centers in Iran. The hackers let the image of an American flag on screen, saying "don't mess with our elections". The Iranian government says, about 3500 -- across that country.

Well, a deal in the pharmaceutical industry to tell you about -- Novartis is buying the AveXis, the price tag, nearly $9 billion. The deal is a bet that at least one promising drug that AveXis is developing to treat spinal muscular atrophy will turn into a blockbuster drug. Shares of Novartis are higher in the premarket, up more than one and quarter percent; AveXis shares are sharply higher as well.

Well, this is interesting -- one rapper on YouTube, drew some inspiration from a kind of unusual place while rhyming to the tune of Migos song "Walk it, Talk it".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Some of them are dreaming like that (INAUDIBLE), but that (INAUDIBLE) when the bottle some are fairly some are not. Let them (INAUDIBLE) on the table when they get under the chair. But that bump on the sofa when I wish she wasn't there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: So, you get it when you start watching it, right? This went viral. And instead of "Walk it, Talk it", the YouTuber was rapper "walk it in my pocket" but in the Migos style of rapping. It racks up over a million views on YouTube. So, I guess -- I don't know what's next, cat in the hat? Cinderella? Green eggs and ham? Bring it on!

MURPHY: I've had enough for 15 years.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: No, you've been doing -- did you rap Dr. Seuss, Theodore Geisel, for your kids?

MURPHY: For 15 years, straight, for every one of mine.

MCDOWELL: Give me some green eggs and ham. I want to hear it now.

MURPHY: It's on my YouTube channel.

MCDOWELL: You give us some green eggs and ham?

MURPHY: No.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE) like, when we first heard about this, is this the children that, you know -- like, no, this is a wrapper.

MURPHY: Wrapper, Migos. Yes!

CARTER: You're all in.

BRENBERG: This is how dads keep their kids engaged. I mean, you're reading your book, you've got do something like that. You can't just read the book; you got to rap, you got to sing it.

CARTER: You rap your books?

BRENBERG: I do something, maybe like an accent. You know, you got to do something to make it, and your kids are just to get bored and whatever. It's a hard job, right?

MURPHY: This is iconic, and you kind of bring it to 2018, I think it needs a little hip-hop in there, totally.

MCDOWELL: We will not eat green eggs and ham?

MURPHY: There you go.

MCDOWELL: Give me the next one.

MURPHY: Sam, I am.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Coming up, "A Quiet Place" making a big noise. The thriller is a big win by actors turned director, Emily Blunt and John Krisinski. A box office recap, next.

MCDOWELL: Another record-breaking weekend at the box office. Lauren Simonetti has more details.

SIMONETTI: All right. Good morning, happy Monday. This is the time we talk about what was a hit over the weekend. So, let's give you the list. In first place, "A Quiet Place". A surprise $50 million opening for this horror film -- and we're going to talk more about it in a second; let's get through the rest of the list. Steven Spielberg's "Ready Player One", 25 million in the second week; "Blockers", 21 million; "Black Panther", took the fourth-place spot, only $8 million this weekend but if you look at what "Black Panther" has done to date, it has unseated "Titanic". So, if you look at total domestic growth, for this movie, $665 million. There it is, number three of all time. "The Force Awakens", number one; "Avatar", number two; and "Titanic", now number four.

Let's go back to "A Quiet Place". This is a movie that cost $17 million to make; $50 million in its opening weekend. So, it was written and directed by -- of office fame, John Krisinki and his wife Emily Blunt starred, but it's basically a "A Quiet Place" -- there's no dialogue in the movie, and it's a huge win for Paramount who needed a big hit after about two years of not having a hit. So, there you have it. We're liking horror at the box office. And they got the trailer for the new "Star Wars".

MCDOWELL: What do you got, Lauren? Show me.

SIMONETTI: Let's watch it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I heard about a job. A big shot gangster putting together a crew.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm a driver. I'm a flyer.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've waited a long time for a shot like this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What is he saying? No, what do you know?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You got a line on a ship?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: It hit theaters on the 25th of May. See, it's the young Han Solo. Do we want to see the --

BRENBERG: That's a lot of -- it's a lot of pressure to play the young Han Solo. He's such a great character. I think the chances of failing are really high here. I'm excited to see. It looks good in the trailer, but that's a tough role, right?

SIMONETTI: Agreed.

CARTER: I like the original "Star Wars", I'm not into it.

SIMONETTI: It's disconnected. It's another one of the -- I think this one takes place before the first one, in 1977.

MURHPY: That tease makes -- while they're getting 600 and 700 million at the box office, you can count and see more and more "Star Wars" prequel, sequels, whatever.

BRENBERG: You're going to see Han Solo as a 5-year-old at some point --

MURPHY: Yes --

BRENBERG: I'm not looking forward to that one.

CARTER: If I like something or not, it's pretty much a not a good indicator about whether or not it's going to perform well.

MCDOWELL: It's called monetizing the franchise, just like Disney bought it in the first place. And so, they've done a pretty good job.

SIMONETTI: It's almost like one a year, right? There's been like one "Star Wars".

BRENBERG: One from the regular series, one of the, kind of the, in between --

SIMONETTI: In between.

BRENBERG: Yes, every single year for the next 20 years, at least, right?

SIMONETTI: They get some new characters in this one. And we'll see what the appetite is for a young Han Solo.

MCDOWELL: You only need to know one word -- Chewbacca.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: Makes an appearance in one of trailers.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

SIMONETTI: And his age?

MCDOWELL: 190 -- in the film.

MURHPY: (INAUDIBLE) like a long time.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: They sure do.

CARTER: I hope that's a good indicator. My dog just looks like him.

SIMONETTI: I wish our dogs are the same. Kevin -- someone who looks like him.

MCDOWELL: Her dog is named Kevin, just to clear that up. She has two dogs. Lauren, thank you so much. And Lauren is having a baby. Can you reveal the name while we're staying here?

SIMONETTI: I don't know if it's a boy or a girl. And we're not sharing names only because I don't care what anybody has to say about them anymore. Not a name. Not talking anymore suggestion,

BRENBERG: You don't need it, but yes, forget about.

SIMONETTI: Don't want your input. Thank you very much. But you can still guess if it's boy or girl.

MCDOWELL: We can segue from Han Solo to Lauren and her impending delivery. Still ahead, gas prices said to hit their higher level in years this summer. We have all the details for you, next on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th, your top stories at 7:30 a.m. Eastern. Crisis in Syria; yet another suspected chemical weapon attacked, leaving dozens dead. The international community on high alert. As the world waits for U.S. response, President Trump warning of a big price to pay. Despite the tensions, stocks reporting to a higher open, bouncing back 160-point on the Dow Futures right now after concerns over a trade war with China, seem to ease a bit -- you see the gains there.

urn:contentItem:5WCJ-3S61-JBHT-D4DH-00000-00Global Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's Hearings2018-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's HearingsLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Peter Dickson, we appreciate you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And we appreciate you watching FBN:am this morning. We always appreciate seeing Dagen McDowell on a Monday. Good morning Dagen.

SIMONETTI: Hey Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK, ANCHOR: Ladies, I'll see you later. Good morning, great to see you as always. And great to see all of you. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Crisis in Syria, yet another suspected chemical weapons attack leaving dozens dead, the international community on high alert. As the world waits for a U.S. response, President Trump warning of a big price to pay.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM BOSSERT, WHITE HOUSE HOMELAND SECURITY ADVISOR: I wouldn't take anything off the table, these are horrible photos, we're looking into the attack at this point. I think the president's got a point that's been very clear and I'm going to reiterate that point. The pendulum has swung in the wrong direction for too long and the United States of America has been taken advantage of in their responsibility to provide security for the entire world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Despite the tension, stocks are pointing to a bounce back as concerns over a trade war with China eased a little bit, maybe it was the Sunday morning talk show's rhetoric being thrown out by the White House.

Futures are showing this, 172 point gain on the DOW Futures right now, it's losing week for the Blue Chips last week. This comes after that massive selloff on Friday with the DOW, Nasdaq, and S&P all falling more than two percent.

In Europe, you have some buying to report, the England, France, and Germany, we have gains across the board. In Asia overnight, stocks also moving higher. The biggest winner there, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Zuckerberg taking the Hill, Facebook CEO set to meet with lawmakers in Washington today as he prepares to face a grilling before the Senate tomorrow. The latest as the Cambridge Analytica whistleblower says more people's data could have been exposed.

And a change at the top, Deutsche Bank naming a new CEO, the details as shares jumped on the news.

And terrifying moments on a New York highway, a tour bus slamming into an overpass leaving six people seriously injured, more on their condition ahead.

And the DOJ stonewalling, why Congress Trey Gowdy is calling out the Justice Department over the investigation into alleged FISA abuses.

And orange going to love this, Bud Light going citrus for the summer, the new flavor hitting store shelves coming up. I think that's called a summer shandy.

All of that and so much more this morning, Pollster Maslansky and Partners President, Lee Carter. Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner, Mike Murphy. And the King's College Business and Economics Professor, Brian Brenberg.

I start with you, markets this week, we get bank earnings, worries about a trade war but, again, now geopolitical concerns that the focusing shifted to that.

BRIAN BRENBERG, KING'S COLLEGE AND BUSINESS ECONOMICS PROFESSOR: Yes. Yes, it has. Although it's interesting to watch these back and forth with the trade wars. You get some rhetoric out of the White House, we -- the talk on Thursday night, Friday morning stocks (INAUDIBLE) over the weekend, everybody's out there talking about how this is not a big deal, we don't want a trade war, you come back Monday morning, stocks up again.

We're seeing this pattern repeat again and again. It seems to take a day or two for markets to digest that you've got rhetoric and you've got reality on trade and the reality probably isn't going to be as bad or as harsh as a rhetoric sounds.

MCDOWELL: Mike, what are you watching this week?

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO, MANAGING PARTNER: Absolutely. So watching the volatility in the market, that's really spurn -- spurred by this trade war talk. And I think just a few months ago we were talking about there's no volatility in the market.

We haven't had a one percent move in so many months. Well now you're getting two percent move almost on a daily basis. I think the main thing for investors to do here is to try to block out the headlines and stick with their long-term plans. So we're going to get the down 500s, the bounces above 200s. Overall, there's not going to be a major trade war with China in my opinion, it will back to focus on the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: I think some of the White House officials needs some messaging help because you've got Secretary MNuchin on Friday talking about the potential of a trade war and then trying to walk back those comments yesterday saying, "I don't expect it at all in terms of a trade war." Don't have your Treasury Secretary utter the words trade war ever.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND MASLANSKY & PARTNERS PRESIDENT: That would be a good first step. But I think it's fascinating to see how the markets are reacting so much to the rhetoric rather than just the policy.

It's unbelievable, a tweet, one announcement can send the markets in a tailspin. And what's happened traditionally is that we've looked at the experts and say, "What are we really supposed to be looking at?" One tweet, one message, one interview can totally change the course of the markets and we're seeing that this week and certainly the White House rhetoric tone way back saying this has always been -- there's nothing new here, nothing's developed here, not a trade war and look, things are softening again.

MCDOWELL: And I'm looking forward to Mark Zuckerberg on Capitol Hill. Again, Facebook will reveal today to Facebook users whose data was accessed by Cambridge Analytica, it's about 70 million people. Estimates are in the United States alone.

And watch Mark Zuckerberg because back in 2010, he broke out into a Nixonian flop sweat when Walt Mossberg was interviewing him. And I mean sweat was dripping off of his face.

CARTER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So if you do that on Capitol Hill, watch your stock tank.

BRENBERG: His appearances are always so staged managed. This one absolutely cannot be. And so it's going to be interesting to see what he does under that kind of pressure.

MCDOWELL: We're trying to get the video but he had sweat dripping off his nose and his chin. I'm not kidding. It's --

CARTER: This is not where he's comfortable.

MURPHY: Yes. That was -- that was back in the days of the hoodie sweatshirt.

MCDOWELL: Yes. So you're saying he was hot.

MURPHY: So he's come a long way.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE) t-shirt.

MCDOWELL: He was -- he was just hot. OK. We're going to talk about that all morning. Also coming up, New York Congressman Chris Collins, South Dakota Senator Mike Rounds. Host of Michelle Malkin Investigates on CRTV.com, Michelle Malkin. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Legendary Soulman, my friend, Sam Moore. You don't want to miss any of them.

Our top story this morning, crossing the red line, the world awaiting the U.S. response to a suspected chemical weapons attack in Syria that killed dozens of citizens. Yesterday, warplanes bombing an airbase near the City of Homs. Russia and Syria have accused Israel of that strike. Meantime, President Trump sending a strong warning to the Assad Regime he tweeted this, "Many dead including women and children, in mindless chemical attack in Syria. Area of atrocity is in lockdown and encircled by Syrian Army, making it completely inaccessible to the outside world. President Putin, Russia, and Iran are responsible for backing animal Assad, big price to pay. Open area immediately for medical help and verification. Another humanitarian disaster for no reason whatsoever, sick."

Joining us now is -- this morning is former Commander of the USS Cole, Kirk Lippold. Commander, how do you -- what should the U.S. do to respond? And I should point out that we used that phrase red line that was famously a phrase used by President Obama back in 2010. Assad and Syria crossed that red line and we didn't do anything or we didn't attack. What should we do now?

COMMANDER KIRK S. LIPPOLD (RET), FORMER USS COLE COMMANDER: Good morning Dagen. I think the first thing we need to do is verify through intelligence channels that in fact took place who carried it out, where it was launched from, what was used to do it?

And then at that point, we take a step back, put together the military forces, and then decide whether we're going to react in a manner that is going to take away that capability not like we did last time with the Tomahawk missiles. But this time, on a more permanent basis and with the backing of the Security Council hopefully at the U.N.

MCDOWELL: Well Commander, you brought that up, so there was one -- it was a sarin gas attack last year, a one-time strike by the United States on a Syrian airbase. Why haven't we done more since then? There was a chlorine gas attack this past January which was the State Department and Rex Tillerson, then the Secretary of State basically attacked in a statement. But why haven't we done more to maybe take out all of Assad's air force, the entire air force?

LIPPOLD: Well, I think Dagen you have to look at it, what is going to be our engagement? What is the end state we want to have there? Assad is going to continue to exist as the president of Syria because the Russians are backing him, they now have the Iranians that are also providing technical knowledge and an ability to also establish their own basis there which Israel is not going to tolerate, which probably drove the attack into the T4 or Tiyas Airbase last night.

But we have to take a look and say, "OK, do we want to be the world's leader in this case where a low level attacks have occurred using chemical weapons?" This was absolutely a much larger scale one, it shows that they're taking out one of the last strongholds of the Syrians rebels. At this point, we need to say, "No, you either go for it conventionally or we will take out that capability." And if it does mean that we take out the Syrian air force, then we better be prepared for a little bit longer investment in time being in Syria with our forces despite what the president has said.

MURPHY: Commander, it's Mike Murphy. I love your opinion on the timing of this of attack because do you think it has to do with the fact that President Trump is fighting on many different fronts? We have North Korea, we have the issues here in the U.S., Russia. You think Syria and Putin got together and said, "Maybe this is a good time to test the president's medal?"

LIPPOLD: I don't think it was timing for that. I think that the president is going to react to it and how he reacts. I think once again, internationally bent will drive the decision-making process for the U.S. government as it always should especially where military force is involved.

I don't think this is going to be a tail-wagging, dog-type scenario, I think in fact we need to look at it and say what are our national security interest there? What is the end state we want to achieve? And if taking out the Syrian air force to send a signal to do that turns out to be the best option for us, then we execute it efficiently, ruthlessly, and with overwhelming force.

MCDOWELL: Brian, and I'll let you get in here but the timing, it does beg the question of this attack comes at -- right after President Trump says that we can't wait to get out of Syria, that we -- that -- but, again, he focus on ISIS and we see the threat to the Syrian people and children in the Assad Regime.

BRENBERG: Yes, absolutely. And the other timing issue that I'd like to ask you about Commander is you have the entrance this week now of John Bolton into the National Security Advisor role, that has to change things a little bit.

He's been critical of these one-off strikes, do we see the tide shift to a more permanent comprehensive approach here with Ambassador Bolton moving into that role?

LIPPOLD: Professor, that's a great question. And I think what you're going to see is Ambassador Bolton is now the National Security Advisor, not the executer but the advisor is going to say we need a much more comprehensive plan. We need a long range view. We need goals that we want to achieve for our national security objectives.

And he is going to take a more holistic approach into the execution of national security policy across the board. So, if you look at total domestic growth, for this movie, $665 million. There it is, number three of all time. "The Force Awakens", number one; "Avatar", number two; and "Titanic", now number four.

Let's go back to "A Quiet Place". This is a movie that cost $17 million to make; $50 million in its opening weekend. So, it was written and directed by -- of office fame, John Krisinki and his wife Emily Blunt starred, but it's basically a "A Quiet Place" -- there's no dialogue in the movie, and it's a huge win for Paramount who needed a big hit after about two years of not having a hit. So, there you have it. We're liking horror at the box office. And they got the trailer for the new "Star Wars".

MCDOWELL: What do you got, Lauren? Show me.

SIMONETTI: Let's watch it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I heard about a job. A big shot gangster putting together a crew.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm a driver. I'm a flyer.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've waited a long time for a shot like this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What is he saying? No, what do you know?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You got a line on a ship?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: It hit theaters on the 25th of May. See, it's the young Han Solo. Do we want to see the --

BRENBERG: That's a lot of -- it's a lot of pressure to play the young Han Solo. He's such a great character. I think the chances of failing are really high here. I'm excited to see. It looks good in the trailer, but that's a tough role, right?

SIMONETTI: Agreed.

CARTER: I like the original "Star Wars", I'm not into it.

SIMONETTI: It's disconnected. It's another one of the -- I think this one takes place before the first one, in 1977.

MURHPY: That tease makes -- while they're getting 600 and 700 million at the box office, you can count and see more and more "Star Wars" prequel, sequels, whatever.

BRENBERG: You're going to see Han Solo as a 5-year-old at some point --

MURPHY: Yes --

BRENBERG: I'm not looking forward to that one.

CARTER: If I like something or not, it's pretty much a not a good indicator about whether or not it's going to perform well.

MCDOWELL: It's called monetizing the franchise, just like Disney bought it in the first place. And so, they've done a pretty good job.

SIMONETTI: It's almost like one a year, right? There's been like one "Star Wars".

BRENBERG: One from the regular series, one of the, kind of the, in between --

SIMONETTI: In between.

BRENBERG: Yes, every single year for the next 20 years, at least, right?

SIMONETTI: They get some new characters in this one. And we'll see what the appetite is for a young Han Solo.

MCDOWELL: You only need to know one word -- Chewbacca.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: Makes an appearance in one of trailers.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

SIMONETTI: And his age?

MCDOWELL: 190 -- in the film.

MURHPY: (INAUDIBLE) like a long time.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: They sure do.

CARTER: I hope that's a good indicator. My dog just looks like him.

SIMONETTI: I wish our dogs are the same. Kevin -- someone who looks like him.

MCDOWELL: Her dog is named Kevin, just to clear that up. She has two dogs. Lauren, thank you so much. And Lauren is having a baby. Can you reveal the name while we're staying here?

SIMONETTI: I don't know if it's a boy or a girl. And we're not sharing names only because I don't care what anybody has to say about them anymore. Not a name. Not talking anymore suggestion,

BRENBERG: You don't need it, but yes, forget about.

SIMONETTI: Don't want your input. Thank you very much. But you can still guess if it's boy or girl.

MCDOWELL: We can segue from Han Solo to Lauren and her impending delivery. Still ahead, gas prices said to hit their higher level in years this summer. We have all the details for you, next on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th, your top stories at 7:30 a.m. Eastern. Crisis in Syria; yet another suspected chemical weapon attacked, leaving dozens dead. The international community on high alert. As the world waits for U.S. response, President Trump warning of a big price to pay. Despite the tensions, stocks reporting to a higher open, bouncing back 160-point on the Dow Futures right now after concerns over a trade war with China, seem to ease a bit -- you see the gains there.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S2X-YVB1-DY0W-441N-00000-00Global Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's Hearings2018-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal Stocks Higher as Trade War Concerns Ease; Syria Red Line Response; DOJ And FBI Asks Federal Prosecutor to Speed Up GOP Document Demands; Facebook is Expected to Send Out Notifications Today to Affected Users; Facebook Whistleblower Millions of User Data Could Be Stored in Russia; Zuckerberg Meeting with Lawmakers Ahead of Tomorrow's HearingsLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Peter Dickson, we appreciate you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And we appreciate you watching FBN:am this morning. We always appreciate seeing Dagen McDowell on a Monday. Good morning Dagen.

SIMONETTI: Hey Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK, ANCHOR: Ladies, I'll see you later. Good morning, great to see you as always. And great to see all of you. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, April 9th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Crisis in Syria, yet another suspected chemical weapons attack leaving dozens dead, the international community on high alert. As the world waits for a U.S. response, President Trump warning of a big price to pay.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM BOSSERT, WHITE HOUSE HOMELAND SECURITY ADVISOR: I wouldn't take anything off the table, these are horrible photos, we're looking into the attack at this point. I think the president's got a point that's been very clear and I'm going to reiterate that point. The pendulum has swung in the wrong direction for too long and the United States of America has been taken advantage of in their responsibility to provide security for the entire world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Despite the tension, stocks are pointing to a bounce back as concerns over a trade war with China eased a little bit, maybe it was the Sunday morning talk show's rhetoric being thrown out by the White House.

Futures are showing this, 172 point gain on the DOW Futures right now, it's losing week for the Blue Chips last week. This comes after that massive selloff on Friday with the DOW, Nasdaq, and S&P all falling more than two percent.

In Europe, you have some buying to report, the England, France, and Germany, we have gains across the board. In Asia overnight, stocks also moving higher. The biggest winner there, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Zuckerberg taking the Hill, Facebook CEO set to meet with lawmakers in Washington today as he prepares to face a grilling before the Senate tomorrow. The latest as the Cambridge Analytica whistleblower says more people's data could have been exposed.

And a change at the top, Deutsche Bank naming a new CEO, the details as shares jumped on the news.

And terrifying moments on a New York highway, a tour bus slamming into an overpass leaving six people seriously injured, more on their condition ahead.

And the DOJ stonewalling, why Congress Trey Gowdy is calling out the Justice Department over the investigation into alleged FISA abuses.

And orange going to love this, Bud Light going citrus for the summer, the new flavor hitting store shelves coming up. I think that's called a summer shandy.

All of that and so much more this morning, Pollster Maslansky and Partners President, Lee Carter. Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner, Mike Murphy. And the King's College Business and Economics Professor, Brian Brenberg.

I start with you, markets this week, we get bank earnings, worries about a trade war but, again, now geopolitical concerns that the focusing shifted to that.

BRIAN BRENBERG, KING'S COLLEGE AND BUSINESS ECONOMICS PROFESSOR: Yes. Yes, it has. Although it's interesting to watch these back and forth with the trade wars. You get some rhetoric out of the White House, we -- the talk on Thursday night, Friday morning stocks (INAUDIBLE) over the weekend, everybody's out there talking about how this is not a big deal, we don't want a trade war, you come back Monday morning, stocks up again.

We're seeing this pattern repeat again and again. It seems to take a day or two for markets to digest that you've got rhetoric and you've got reality on trade and the reality probably isn't going to be as bad or as harsh as a rhetoric sounds.

MCDOWELL: Mike, what are you watching this week?

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO, MANAGING PARTNER: Absolutely. So watching the volatility in the market, that's really spurn -- spurred by this trade war talk. And I think just a few months ago we were talking about there's no volatility in the market.

We haven't had a one percent move in so many months. Well now you're getting two percent move almost on a daily basis. I think the main thing for investors to do here is to try to block out the headlines and stick with their long-term plans. So we're going to get the down 500s, the bounces above 200s. Overall, there's not going to be a major trade war with China in my opinion, it will back to focus on the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: I think some of the White House officials needs some messaging help because you've got Secretary MNuchin on Friday talking about the potential of a trade war and then trying to walk back those comments yesterday saying, "I don't expect it at all in terms of a trade war." Don't have your Treasury Secretary utter the words trade war ever.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND MASLANSKY & PARTNERS PRESIDENT: That would be a good first step. But I think it's fascinating to see how the markets are reacting so much to the rhetoric rather than just the policy.

It's unbelievable, a tweet, one announcement can send the markets in a tailspin. And what's happened traditionally is that we've looked at the experts and say, "What are we really supposed to be looking at?" One tweet, one message, one interview can totally change the course of the markets and we're seeing that this week and certainly the White House rhetoric tone way back saying this has always been -- there's nothing new here, nothing's developed here, not a trade war and look, things are softening again.

MCDOWELL: And I'm looking forward to Mark Zuckerberg on Capitol Hill. Again, Facebook will reveal today to Facebook users whose data was accessed by Cambridge Analytica, it's about 70 million people. Estimates are in the United States alone.

And watch Mark Zuckerberg because back in 2010, he broke out into a Nixonian flop sweat when Walt Mossberg was interviewing him. And I mean sweat was dripping off of his face.

CARTER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So if you do that on Capitol Hill, watch your stock tank.

BRENBERG: His appearances are always so staged managed. This one absolutely cannot be. And so it's going to be interesting to see what he does under that kind of pressure.

MCDOWELL: We're trying to get the video but he had sweat dripping off his nose and his chin. I'm not kidding. It's --

CARTER: This is not where he's comfortable.

MURPHY: Yes. That was -- that was back in the days of the hoodie sweatshirt.

MCDOWELL: Yes. So you're saying he was hot.

MURPHY: So he's come a long way.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE) t-shirt.

MCDOWELL: He was -- he was just hot. OK. We're going to talk about that all morning. Also coming up, New York Congressman Chris Collins, South Dakota Senator Mike Rounds. Host of Michelle Malkin Investigates on CRTV.com, Michelle Malkin. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Legendary Soulman, my friend, Sam Moore. You don't want to miss any of them.

Our top story this morning, crossing the red line, the world awaiting the U.S. response to a suspected chemical weapons attack in Syria that killed dozens of citizens. Yesterday, warplanes bombing an airbase near the City of Homs. Russia and Syria have accused Israel of that strike. Meantime, President Trump sending a strong warning to the Assad Regime he tweeted this, "Many dead including women and children, in mindless chemical attack in Syria. Area of atrocity is in lockdown and encircled by Syrian Army, making it completely inaccessible to the outside world. President Putin, Russia, and Iran are responsible for backing animal Assad, big price to pay. Open area immediately for medical help and verification. Another humanitarian disaster for no reason whatsoever, sick."

Joining us now is -- this morning is former Commander of the USS Cole, Kirk Lippold. Commander, how do you -- what should the U.S. do to respond? And I should point out that we used that phrase red line that was famously a phrase used by President Obama back in 2010. Assad and Syria crossed that red line and we didn't do anything or we didn't attack. What should we do now?

COMMANDER KIRK S. LIPPOLD (RET), FORMER USS COLE COMMANDER: Good morning Dagen. I think the first thing we need to do is verify through intelligence channels that in fact took place who carried it out, where it was launched from, what was used to do it?

And then at that point, we take a step back, put together the military forces, and then decide whether we're going to react in a manner that is going to take away that capability not like we did last time with the Tomahawk missiles. But this time, on a more permanent basis and with the backing of the Security Council hopefully at the U.N.

MCDOWELL: Well Commander, you brought that up, so there was one -- it was a sarin gas attack last year, a one-time strike by the United States on a Syrian airbase. Why haven't we done more since then? There was a chlorine gas attack this past January which was the State Department and Rex Tillerson, then the Secretary of State basically attacked in a statement. But why haven't we done more to maybe take out all of Assad's air force, the entire air force?

LIPPOLD: Well, I think Dagen you have to look at it, what is going to be our engagement? What is the end state we want to have there? Assad is going to continue to exist as the president of Syria because the Russians are backing him, they now have the Iranians that are also providing technical knowledge and an ability to also establish their own basis there which Israel is not going to tolerate, which probably drove the attack into the T4 or Tiyas Airbase last night.

But we have to take a look and say, "OK, do we want to be the world's leader in this case where a low level attacks have occurred using chemical weapons?" This was absolutely a much larger scale one, it shows that they're taking out one of the last strongholds of the Syrians rebels. At this point, we need to say, "No, you either go for it conventionally or we will take out that capability." And if it does mean that we take out the Syrian air force, then we better be prepared for a little bit longer investment in time being in Syria with our forces despite what the president has said.

MURPHY: Commander, it's Mike Murphy. I love your opinion on the timing of this of attack because do you think it has to do with the fact that President Trump is fighting on many different fronts? We have North Korea, we have the issues here in the U.S., Russia. You think Syria and Putin got together and said, "Maybe this is a good time to test the president's medal?"

LIPPOLD: I don't think it was timing for that. I think that the president is going to react to it and how he reacts. I think once again, internationally bent will drive the decision-making process for the U.S. government as it always should especially where military force is involved.

I don't think this is going to be a tail-wagging, dog-type scenario, I think in fact we need to look at it and say what are our national security interest there? What is the end state we want to achieve? And if taking out the Syrian air force to send a signal to do that turns out to be the best option for us, then we execute it efficiently, ruthlessly, and with overwhelming force.

MCDOWELL: Brian, and I'll let you get in here but the timing, it does beg the question of this attack comes at -- right after President Trump says that we can't wait to get out of Syria, that we -- that -- but, again, he focus on ISIS and we see the threat to the Syrian people and children in the Assad Regime.

BRENBERG: Yes, absolutely. And the other timing issue that I'd like to ask you about Commander is you have the entrance this week now of John Bolton into the National Security Advisor role, that has to change things a little bit.

He's been critical of these one-off strikes, do we see the tide shift to a more permanent comprehensive approach here with Ambassador Bolton moving into that role?

LIPPOLD: Professor, that's a great question. And I think what you're going to see is Ambassador Bolton is now the National Security Advisor, not the executer but the advisor is going to say we need a much more comprehensive plan. We need a long range view. We need goals that we want to achieve for our national security objectives.

And he is going to take a more holistic approach into the execution of national security policy across the board. So I think that you're going to see a little bit more robust policy, I think you will see one with more defined objectives in there, and I think you will see one that will be executed in fairly short order because he is a decisive individual and he's going to recommend that to the president who obviously brought him in because he was a little frustrated that he was being held back in some of the execution of our policies.

MCDOWELL: The president did tweet because I mentioned the red line at the beginning, "If President Obama had crossed his stated red line in the sand, the Syrian disaster would have ended a long -- long ago. Animal Assad would have been history."

Maria spoke with House Homeland Security Committee Chairman, Michael McCaul yesterday and he agrees with the president. Listen to this Commander.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL MCCAUL (R-TX) HOUSE HOMELAND SECURITY COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: There has to be a consequence to this. And I think the president's absolutely right is that President Obama drew the red line, the red line was crossed, he did nothing.

And then he negotiate through John Kerry the settlement, this weapons convention. I remember John Kerry saying, "We took all their chemical weapons away." Obviously not. They still have this. And I also blame Russia and Iran, I think they're complicit with this as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Commander, I want to get your response to that. But as I mentioned earlier, we had that one-time airstrike last April but since then, there has been a chlorine gas attack that killed 20, mostly children, that happened in January, there was a statement from the State Department then but no enforcement. And Assad certainly knows that he would pay no price and now this, final thought.

LIPPOLD: I think you're absolutely right. There has to be consequences for this action. While there was a red line drawn and unfortunately we did not react to the red line when Syria crossed it. We did in fact have one positive development and that was getting rid of the vast majority of chemical weapons in there.

Had we attacked immediately, I doubt we would have ever gotten to that point with an agreement working with the Russians to make that happen. That is a positive thing to look at it. But nonetheless, if you draw a line as a state actor especially the United States, you have to hold it, enforce it, and do not waiver on it. And in doing that, it embolden people, the one-off strike, that's clearly going to be a test now whether we react to this in a manner that is much stronger, much more overwhelming and sends a signal, we will not tolerate this.

By the same token, going to Russia and Iran and saying, you're complicit in this, you have contributed to it, you have created the conditions that allowed it to happen, you must not do that anymore and there will be consequences and if your folks happen to be in the wrong place at the wrong time, that is not our responsibility, it's your decision to put them there.

MCDOWELL: Kirk, thank you so much. Kirk Lippold. Commander, be well. Thank you for being here.

LIPPOLD: Thank you Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Breaking news, President Trump just tweeting, "When a car is sent to the United States from China, there is a tariff to be paid of 2.12 percent. When a car is sent to China from the United States, there is a tariff to be paid of 25 percent. Does that sound like free or fair trade. No, it sounds like stupid trade going on for years."

Coming up, on the hot seat, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is in Washington today ahead of two intense days of questioning on Capitol Hill. This comes as the company had set to alert millions of users if their data was shared.

And tired of being patient? Congress Trey Gowdy calling out the Justice Department over the investigation into alleged FISA abuses.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: New week, new energy for Wall Street, DOW Futures right now are showing gains across the board, 167 point gain on the DOW Futures right now after what was a bruising week. Again, cooler heads prevailing I suppose when it comes to trade war talk. We'll see what comes out of the administration in the coming days. We're also watching the beginning of earning season this week.

Meantime, at least six teenagers from New York severely injured after a charter bus crashed. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, that's right Dagen. The bus packed with high school students returning from a spring break trip to Europe hit an overpass on Long Island last night. The impact was so strong, it tore the roof off the bus. This happened on the southern state parkway which restricts travel by commercial vehicles. Police say the driver did not seem to be familiar with that restriction.

Well, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joining thousands at a vigil honoring the junior hockey team involved in a tragic bus accident on Friday. The team president speaking to the crowd packed into the humble Broncos Arena.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN GARINGER, HUMBOLDT BRONCOS PRESIDENT: We will find strength in one another. Today and for every day forward, we are all Humboldt Broncos and we will be forever Humboldt Broncos strong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Fifteen people are now dead after that team's bus collided with a tractor trailer. Among those killed were the team's head coach, the driver of the bus, and several players. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5DYM-NMR1-F11P-X195-00000-00Global support mounts for Microsoft in Ireland case2014-12-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal support mounts for Microsoft in Ireland case

A year-long battle between Microsoft and the United States Department of Justice has begun to draw international attention as Ireland and Europe weigh in on the validity of a search warrant issued for data housed in an Irish data center in Dublin.


Microsoft has been fighting a warrant obtained by the DOJ last year from a U.S. court under the Electronic Communications Privacy Act. The DOJ - as well as U.S. courts - claim that the warrant is sufficient to force Microsoft to hand over data stored on its server in Ireland. Microsoft, a host of other big tech companies, and now Ireland disagree.
Earlier this year, a group of tech giants like Cisco and Verizon signed briefs disputing the legal authority of the warrant, claiming that the U.S. has no jurisdiction over a company's data stored in another country even if the company in question is American. The Irish government has now issued an amicus brief in support of Microsoft, while admitting that existing contracts between Ireland and the U.S. technically allow for the sharing of data. The brief says:
Ireland has a genuine and legitimate interest in potential infringements by other states of its sovereign rights with respect to its jurisdiction over its territory...Ireland does not accept any implication that it is required to intervene into foreign court proceedings to protect its sovereignty. Second, Ireland continues to facilitate cooperation with other states, including the United States, in the fight against crime and, in this regard, Ireland and the United States are parties to a treaty addressing the subject of this appeal.
Jan Albrecht, a member of the European Parliament, has also issued an amicus brief with a pointed message for U.S. courts:
European citizens are highly sensitive to the differences between European and U.S. standards on data protection. Such concerns are frequently raised in relation to the regulation of cross-border data flows and the mass-processing of data by U.S. technology companies. The successful execution of the warrant at issue in this case would extend the scope of this anxiety to a sizeable majority of the data held in the world's data centers outside the U.S. (most of which are controlled by U.S. corporations) and would thus undermine the protections of the EU data protection regime, even for data belonging to an EU citizen and stored in an EU country.
This case is a critical one for setting a precedent for data ownership and the jurisdiction of countries over their data housed overseas. As support for Microsoft mounts on a global scale, all eyes will be on U.S. courts and the DOJ as they consider their next moves. 2014 Legal Monitor Worldwide.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VHV-7911-JD34-V2GJ-00000-00GLOBAL TAX TRIBES GO TO WAR2019-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 36GLOBAL TAX TRIBES GO TO WARJohn Kehoe

International regulation | As the OECD works on the biggest global tax shake-up in more than 50 years, Australian expat David Bradbury is at the forefront of efforts to avoid an international tax battle, writes John Kehoe.

When Australian expat and international tax diplomat David Bradbury hosts business meetings in Paris, he is often surrounded by counterparts from titans of the world economy who spar over how to tax multinational companies.

As the head of tax policy at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Bradbury has been at the negotiating table with executives from Silicon Valley technology giants, President Donald Trump's US Treasury, European firms and bureaucrats, and occasionally counterparts from Canberra.

Bradbury - a former Sydney-based corporate tax lawyer and minister in the Rudd and Gillard Labor governments - is at the epicentre of a global tussle over the taxation of the rapidly emerging digital economy.

The OECD is trying to pull off the biggest global tax shake-up in more than 50 years. Such is the magnitude of the job, Bradbury - as the head of the OECD's digital economy taskforce secretariat - was named in December by by the International Tax Review as the equal-most influential person in global tax.

In an interview with The Australian Financial Review, Bradbury says from Paris that the potential global tax reforms could "redefine who has taxing rights in a way that is even more profound" than originally envisaged by world leaders when they set up the project. For the past six years the OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project has had a big focus on how to collect more tax from digital firms such as Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet's Google.

In the data-rich modern economy, tech giants have sometimes tried to avoid having a physical presence (in tax jargon known as a permanent establishment) in jurisdictions to pay minimal tax in lucrative developed markets like Europe and Australia.

How to tax the provision of online advertising by Facebook and Google, Amazon's cloud services and advertising, and subscription and freemium streaming services by Netflix and Spotify is a vexed issue for tax authorities around the world. With American tech and other intellectual property-intensive darlings in the firing line, the Obama and Trump administrations have bitten back.

The US is concerned anti-American forces in Europe are attempting a revenue heist and regulatory attacks on Silicon Valley giants at the expense of Uncle Sam. There has been a stalemate on forging international consensus on taxing the digital economy after the US last year effectively vetoed proposals.

Yet in a surprise twist, the global tax debate was recently turned on its head. Trump's top Treasury international tax official, former PwC and Baker McKenzie tax adviser Chip Harter, offered an olive branch to other countries. The US may be prepared to do a deal on global tax.

The Trump administration argues the vulnerabilities in the global tax base are not limited to highly digital firms but are more widespread for intangible assets owned by the likes of McDonald's, Starbucks and Nike. The American quid pro quo is that the original BEPS project be expanded beyond the digital economy to the rules on taxing IP and intangible assets more broadly.

Under the US proposal, a larger share of the profits would be taxed where a product is consumed - potentially delivering valuable revenue to big consumer markets like the US.

"It's potentially bigger than the BEPS project because it would redefine who has taxing rights," Bradbury says.

The 127 members of BEPS in January agreed to examine proposals involving two pillars that might form the basis of a long-term consensus. The first focuses on the allocation of taxing rights between countries and the second addresses other issues.

"Under the first pillar, which focuses on the allocation of taxing rights among countries, several proposals have been made that would allocate more taxing rights to market-user jurisdictions in the case of highly digitalised firms," Bradbury says. "These proposals would require a reconsideration of existing transfer pricing rules and contemplate solutions that go beyond the arm's length principle - which has been the key principle underpinning the transfer pricing rules.

"The second pillar will consider granting new taxing rights that would strengthen the ability of jurisdictions to tax profits where other jurisdictions with taxing rights apply a low effective tax rate to those profits."

Opinions diverge widely. The US wants to allocate some of the residual profit from intangibles to the consumer market, such as the US. The United Kingdom is keen to expand the taxing rights on big tech firms but wants to restrain the advancement into other industries that might hit its own multinationals.

The UK is also less interested in taxing where the "consumer" is, and is keener on taxing where the "user" is. A "user" of a digital platform may upload photos, make social media posts or sign up friends to a service, without paying any money. Though they are technically not a "consumer", arguably these users add value to the digital company, even if no money changes hands.

To complicate matters, the Germans and French believe if the system is going to move beyond taxing digital firms, then a global minimum corporate tax should be imposed - a change the US corporate tax reforms in 2016 effectively imposed on US-headquartered multinationals.

Bradbury is in the thick of all this. To be sure, the OECD working on behalf of the Group of 20 world leaders faces an uphill task to finalise a compromise by a deadline of 2020.

With impatient governments in Australia and the UK rolling out unilateral tax laws to hit multinational tax avoidance, tax experts are worried a failure to achieve a breakthrough could lead to an international tax war. Others argue unilateral action by Australia may encourage countries to work out a global solution.

Bradbury, who as a Labor assistant treasurer did some of the early work on Australia's multinational tax-avoidance laws, is diplomatic: "Australia has been closely engaged in this work and this will be increasingly important as we move into the next phase of deliberations."

Many private-sector tax advisers believe the OECD's task is nigh on impossible, given the intractable political fight over how to carve up the global tax pie.

"It is hard to see how the OECD will be able to achieve a consensus by 2020 and if they don't I think we will see more unilateral measures becoming permanent," says Clayton Utz tax partner Niv Tadmore. "That would create ambiguity and incoherence in the international tax system."

Bradbury won't concede he has the impossible in front of him. In fact, the father of four teenage students recently signed a three-year contract extension at the OECD in Paris, which would take him to eight years in the job. He is ensconced in Parisian life, musing that his bilingual children are much more fluent in French than he.

It's a long way for the former western Sydney MP from the time he climbed aboard a patrol boat in Darwin with then-prime minister Julia Gillard to showcase his border security credentials before the 2010 election. Bradbury shows little interest in resuming a Canberra political life, but admits politics is part of the job at the OECD.

"We are trying to achieve consensus with 127 jurisdictions at the table, all contributing on an equal footing," he says. "Our work is not like a parliament where you need 50 per cent plus one. You need to understand the various interests and perspectives of countries. That requires an even greater understanding of the positions of the countries and national interests. It's a technical exercise but also a political one."

In comparison to a breakdown in multilateralism on trade and immigration, Bradbury at least thinks tax has the potential underpinnings for a deal.

"At a time when there seems to be almost complete intractability on so many global issues, this seems to be one area where countries are constructively engaging with a strong desire to make progress," he says.

"In my experience there is a pretty strong degree of political will among countries to try to address these issues. Where that leads us in the next couple of years remains to be seen."AFR

urn:contentItem:5VTG-BW31-DXCW-D48Y-00000-00Global team needed to tackle eCommerce rules, data2019-04-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal team needed to tackle eCommerce rules, data

Geneva, Switzerland: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development has issued the following press release: Governments and industry grappled with the tension between digital trade regulation and on-the-ground realities of data collection and use at the UNCTAD eCommerce Week ministerial roundtable on trade, data and digitalization. The session paired the two to address pressing digital economy prospects and problems at a crucial juncture where both e-commerce and data regulation are needed but require extraordinary global collaboration. Navigating this complex digital terrain is the preserve of public sector, policy-makers and the private sector and requires ample inputs from all to make it work. The issues are far from simple. They also have knock-on effects across value chains, countries, consumers and all commerce – and they impact everything from the nebulous, such as trust, to the nefarious, such as hacking and data theft.

Amani Abou-Zeid Amani Abou-Zeid, Commissioner for Infrastructure and Energy at the African Union Commission [Photo Gallery on Flickr] The data-driven economy gives rise to new opportunities for wealth creation and addressing sustainable development challenges. It also raises concerns such as data privacy and security, the regulation of cross-border data flows, market concentration and taxation. As such, rules are important, attendees at the fifth UNCTAD eCommerce Week, at the United Nations’ European headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland on 2 April heard. “As with other areas of trade, rulemaking about data and e-commerce will need to achieve a balance between potential trade disciplines and national policy objectives,” said UNCTAD Deputy Secretary-General Isabelle Durant. Call and response Understanding how digital data and trade interact requires different perspectives to bring a complex picture into focus. The African Union’s (AU) infrastructure and energy commissioner, Amani Abou-Zeid, said aside from physical infrastructure, mobile money, and a better understanding of the informal economy, one of the biggest challenges in Africa is data. The lack of it, how it differs, and the inability to analyze it when it does exist, are all concerns. “When we talk about data for trade, there is an assumption that this data exists,” Ms. Abou-Zeid said. “Lack of up-to-date data is recognized as one of the impacts of lower intra-African trade. When there is data, it can differ from agency to agency and sometimes even within agencies.” The AU is working to address the data issue, she said, saying it would establish a trade observatory located within the AU Commission with funding from the International Trade Centre and the European Union. The observatory would deal with the issue of not having a central trade data repository at a continental level and quantitative information to make decisions. The term data though, said Deborah Elms, founder and executive director of the Asian Trade Centre, has been used too loosely, which makes it confusing and complicated. “Data is used to describe everything, so it ends up describing nothing,” she said. “We have to be more precise.” “The more complicated you make it, the more difficult you make it for small businesses operating in the digital world.” With data and trade at the core of the wide-ranging discussion, the definitional issue was central. Governments are grappling with this, said Lantosoa Rakotomalala, Madagascar’s industry, trade and crafts minister. “We have all the challenges relating to (digital) connection, data storage and ensuring this data is secure. “But on the other hand, we also have research and development policies which today are not yet allowing us to fully appreciate the usage of data in terms of economic development,” she said, but added there were costs especially in machine learning, new equipment and the rights to a private life. She said an additional challenge is identifying how to process and analyze data in Africa. The case of Paraguay is heartening for other developing nations, but also demonstrates that connectivity alone is not enough. Pedro Mancuello, Paraguay’s vice minister of trade, said while more that 86% of people in Paraguay have internet, only 14.3% buy online. This connectivity is a testament to its investment in digital infrastructure, but also a portend of what’s required to get entrepreneurs selling, and consumers buying, online. But getting online is a challenge for many says, said Joãozinho Mendes of the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA). “Because of the digital divide an awful lot of our producers are simply not able to have such a high online profile for economic, infrastructure or indeed educational reasons.” He said he doesn’t believe data collection is a bad thing and contributes to development. “Digital technologies do generate a great deal of information, but we need to be in a position to process, collect, analyses, and store it to implement development strategies. Hence the need to develop competencies that allow us to manage data,” Mr. Mendes said. The data divide On the industry and civil society side, there was emphasis on the difference between consumer and business data and its use. Consumers International’s director general Helena Leurent said data benefits consumers daily, citing the example of TripAdvisor. But she said there is a dark side that needs to be considered. “The value that companies and nations gain from data originates from individuals. Our ability to create a rich personal profile which helps aid decision-making and recommendations is the same thing that then creates the challenges.” “For consumers there is a fear that (their data) is being used against them, which stops them wanting to engage in a digital world,” she said. Meanwhile Ms. Elms’ view is that while big data may be the preserve of big tech companies, the 2,500 companies in her network simply don’t see business information as data that needs major protections. “It’s just information that is needed to do business. If you want to move goods from country A to country B, companies need to be able to use your address and credit card to do that,” Ms. Elms said. Indeed, data can be a force for good, a point made by Xiaofei Yao, founder and CEO of Rogrand E-commerce, China’s largest pharmaceutical supply chain management company. She said: “Data has become an essential thing for business.” “Many describe data as the oil of the future – but it’s more than just oil, it’s the engine and currency in the digital economy – and is much more powerful than its fiscal counterparts as it helps us understand more about ourselves, our country and our civilization.” “It will fundamentally enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of production and services.” “We are all desperate to get more data. Despite the concerns we should look into the uniqueness of the data to overcome these, and design by industry and sector around the purpose of the data use.” The meeting agreed data can be a force for good, but it needs to be better defined and understood ahead of regulation efforts, which could damage the engines of economic growth it aims to help. “Whatever the outcome of trade negotiations, it is clear that more support is needed to ensure that no one is left behind in the digital era,” Ms. Durant added. The fifth edition of eCommerce Week – an annual gathering that draws leading e-commerce figures, start-ups, policy makers and officials from around the world – is taking place in Geneva from 1 to 5 April. The theme of this year’s week, which comprises dozens of sessions, is "From Digitalization to Development".

urn:contentItem:5VT4-0KS1-DYTH-G3TB-00000-00GLOBAL TEAM NEEDED TO TACKLE ECOMMERCE RULES, DATA - 03 APR -2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGLOBAL TEAM NEEDED TO TACKLE ECOMMERCE RULES, DATA - 03 APR -States News ServiceGeneva, Switzerland

The following information was released by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development:

Everyone is affected by the rules and the realisms of trading business or personal data online, but unprecedented cooperation is needed to manage this impact.

Governments and industry grappled with the tension between digital trade regulation and on-the-ground realities of data collection and use at the UNCTAD eCommerce Week ministerial roundtable on trade, data and digitalization.

The session paired the two to address pressing digital economy prospects and problems at a crucial juncture where both e-commerce and data regulation are needed but require extraordinary global collaboration.

Navigating this complex digital terrain is the preserve of public sector, policy-makers and the private sector and requires ample inputs from all to make it work.

The issues are far from simple.

They also have knock-on effects across value chains, countries, consumers and all commerce and they impact everything from the nebulous, such as trust, to the nefarious, such as hacking and data theft.

Amani Abou-Zeid, Commissioner for Infrastructure and Energy at the African Union Commission

The data-driven economy gives rise to new opportunities for wealth creation and addressing sustainable development challenges.

It also raises concerns such as data privacy and security, the regulation of cross-border data flows, market concentration and taxation.

As such, rules are important, attendees at the fifth UNCTAD eCommerce Week, at the United Nations' European headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland on 2 April heard.

"As with other areas of trade, rulemaking about data and e-commerce will need to achieve a balance between potential trade disciplines and national policy objectives," said UNCTAD Deputy Secretary-General Isabelle Durant.

Call and response

Understanding how digital data and trade interact requires different perspectives to bring a complex picture into focus.

The African Union's (AU) infrastructure and energy commissioner, Amani Abou-Zeid, said aside from physical infrastructure, mobile money, and a better understanding of the informal economy, one of the biggest challenges in Africa is data.

The lack of it, how it differs, and the inability to analyze it when it does exist, are all concerns.

"When we talk about data for trade, there is an assumption that this data exists," Ms. Abou-Zeid said. "Lack of up-to-date data is recognized as one of the impacts of lower intra-African trade. When there is data, it can differ from agency to agency and sometimes even within agencies."

The AU is working to address the data issue, she said, saying it would establish a trade observatory located within the AU Commission with funding from the International Trade Centre and the European Union.

The observatory would deal with the issue of not having a central trade data repository at a continental level and quantitative information to make decisions.

The term data though, said Deborah Elms, founder and executive director of the Asian Trade Centre, has been used too loosely, which makes it confusing and complicated.

"Data is used to describe everything, so it ends up describing nothing," she said. "We have to be more precise."

"The more complicated you make it, the more difficult you make it for small businesses operating in the digital world."

With data and trade at the core of the wide-ranging discussion, the definitional issue was central.

Governments are grappling with this, said Lantosoa Rakotomalala, Madagascar's industry, trade and crafts minister.

"We have all the challenges relating to (digital) connection, data storage and ensuring this data is secure.

"But on the other hand, we also have research and development policies which today are not yet allowing us to fully appreciate the usage of data in terms of economic development," she said, but added there were costs especially in machine learning, new equipment and the rights to a private life.

She said an additional challenge is identifying how to process and analyze data in Africa.

The case of Paraguay is heartening for other developing nations, but also demonstrates that connectivity alone is not enough.

Pedro Mancuello, Paraguay's vice minister of trade, said while more that 86% of people in Paraguay have internet, only 14.3% buy online. This connectivity is a testament to its investment in digital infrastructure, but also a portend of what's required to get entrepreneurs selling, and consumers buying, online.

But getting online is a challenge for many says, said Joozinho Mendes of the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA).

"Because of the digital divide an awful lot of our producers are simply not able to have such a high online profile for economic, infrastructure or indeed educational reasons."

He said he doesn't believe data collection is a bad thing and contributes to development.

"Digital technologies do generate a great deal of information, but we need to be in a position to process, collect, analyses, and store it to implement development strategies. Hence the need to develop competencies that allow us to manage data," Mr. Mendes said.

The data divide

On the industry and civil society side, there was emphasis on the difference between consumer and business data and its use.

Consumers International's director general Helena Leurent said data benefits consumers daily, citing the example of TripAdvisor.

But she said there is a dark side that needs to be considered.

"The value that companies and nations gain from data originates from individuals. Our ability to create a rich personal profile which helps aid decision-making and recommendations is the same thing that then creates the challenges."

"For consumers there is a fear that (their data) is being used against them, which stops them wanting to engage in a digital world," she said.

Meanwhile Ms. Elms' view is that while big data may be the preserve of big tech companies, the 2,500 companies in her network simply don't see business information as data that needs major protections.

"It's just information that is needed to do business. If you want to move goods from country A to country B, companies need to be able to use your address and credit card to do that," Ms. Elms said.

Indeed, data can be a force for good, a point made by Xiaofei Yao, founder and CEO of Rogrand E-commerce, China's largest pharmaceutical supply chain management company.

She said: "Data has become an essential thing for business."

"Many describe data as the oil of the future but it's more than just oil, it's the engine and currency in the digital economy and is much more powerful than its fiscal counterparts as it helps us understand more about ourselves, our country and our civilization."

"It will fundamentally enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of production and services."

"We are all desperate to get more data. Despite the concerns we should look into the uniqueness of the data to overcome these, and design by industry and sector around the purpose of the data use."

The meeting agreed data can be a force for good, but it needs to be better defined and understood ahead of regulation efforts, which could damage the engines of economic growth it aims to help.

"Whatever the outcome of trade negotiations, it is clear that more support is needed to ensure that no one is left behind in the digital era," Ms. Durant added.

The fifth edition of eCommerce Week an annual gathering that draws leading e-commerce figures, start-ups, policy makers and officials from around the world is taking place in Geneva from 1 to 5 April. The theme of this year's week, which comprises dozens of sessions, is "From Digitalization to Development".

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60WN-4JD1-F0J5-8375-00000-00Global Telecommunications Key View2020-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:20ZLexisNexisGlobal Telecommunications Key View

Our regional analyses this quarter focused on telecommunications companies' strategies and opportunities in different regions of the world, as well as on the effects that the covid-19 pandemic will have on the global Fintech industry. One of the major long term trends we foresee for the technological arena is the increasing demand for greater bandwidth and the subsequent adoption of 5G and fibre, albeit in a slower pace than originally anticipated. Q220 results for the Big Tech companies have shown they're the main beneficiaries to Covid-19, with all showing growth with the exception of Google with 2% revenue decrease. Amazon was the main winner, reporting 40% growth but all Big Tech companies are facing regulatory scrutiny. In terms of business areas, cloud remains the big winner. Netflix remained a winner in Q220, adding a further 10m subscribers totaling nearly 26m however its challenge will be to retain these new customers, particularly as other streaming channels such as Disney+ are made more available. While we don't see the Splinternet being inevitable, further moves in the past quarter mean that three out of six steps have already been taken; most notably the US enforcing an executive order banning Chinese companies TikTok and WeChat from the US market. Saudi Arabia is becoming a greater investment target for technology companies as the NEOM 'cognitive city' project has initiated consultation to open up new frequencies for commercial use. Joint ventures between GIC and Equinix will improve its long-term economic control of real estate assets and encourage the company to double-down on asset ownership and multi-cloud service offerings, in order to compete with AWS and Google in the hyperscale ecosystem. Orange has transitioned to its Engage2025 strategy, with a focus on sustainability and technological innovations. Advanced connectivity will be the main focus in Europe, while the MEA region will increasingly benefit the group’s revenues through its accelerating growth. Cybersecurity and financial services are Orange’s two biggest bets outside its traditional telecoms space. The Covid-19 pandemic is highlighting interesting opportunities for growth in the cloud computing and cybersecurity segments.

Key View: Our regional analyses this quarter focused on telecommunications companies' strategies and opportunities in different regions of the world, as well as on the effects that the covid-19 pandemic will have on the global Fintech industry. One of the major long term trends we foresee for the technological arena is the increasing demand for greater bandwidth and the subsequent adoption of 5G and fibre, albeit in a slower pace than originally anticipated. Q220 results for the Big Tech companies have shown they're the main beneficiaries to Covid-19, with all showing growth with the exception of Google with 2% revenue decrease. Amazon was the main winner, reporting 40% growth but all Big Tech companies are facing regulatory scrutiny. In terms of business areas, cloud remains the big winner. Netflix remained a winner in Q220, adding a further 10m subscribers totaling nearly 26m however its challenge will be to retain these new customers, particularly as other streaming channels such as Disney+ are made more available. While we don't see the Splinternet being inevitable, further moves in the past quarter mean that three out of six steps have already been taken; most notably the US enforcing an executive order banning Chinese companies TikTok and WeChat from the US market. Saudi Arabia is becoming a greater investment target for technology companies as the NEOM 'cognitive city' project has initiated consultation to open up new frequencies for commercial use. Joint ventures between GIC and Equinix will improve its long-term economic control of real estate assets and encourage the company to double-down on asset ownership and multi-cloud service offerings, in order to compete with AWS and Google in the hyperscale ecosystem. Orange has transitioned to its Engage2025 strategy, with a focus on sustainability and technological innovations. Advanced connectivity will be the main focus in Europe, while the MEA region will increasingly benefit the group's revenues through its accelerating growth. Cybersecurity and financial services are Orange's two biggest bets outside its traditional telecoms space. The Covid-19 pandemic is highlighting interesting opportunities for growth in the cloud computing and cybersecurity segments.

5G Enters The Spotlight

Global 5G Forecasts, 2019 - 2029

f = Fitch Solutions forecast. Source: Fitch Solutions

Latest Updates And Industry Developments Advanced services will be heavy users of bandwidth and we forecast multi-purpose fixed/mobile broadband accesses to grow to 1.859bn by 2029. Dedicated mobile broadband connections will gradually become more ubiquitous, but less retail subscription-oriented; broadband subscriptions would otherwise be more numerous by 2029. In time, subscription numbers will become less relevant as an indicator of growth. As operators pursue connected strategies, so the number of devices linked to a single account-holder will proliferate. Connected cars, smart homes, smart meters, smart prosthetics and clothing will be just a few of a myriad of 'things' connecting to the internet. Monetising connected services will be operators' new priority, although many will struggle unless they are prepared to abandon their legacy business models. Although it has become heavily commoditised and, therefore, less attractive as a paid-for service, voice still has an important role to play. It will be included in multi-product bundles and will, therefore, count in operators' reported connection numbers, especially in developed markets where triple-play uptake is developing rapidly. In less developed markets, voice will continue to be required as a stand-alone product although, increasingly, it will migrate to less transparent IP offerings.
